title: Festival of Trees raises $50K for Compass Hospice
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
Festival of Trees raises $50K for Compass Hospice

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 891
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Dozens of donated, decorated evergreen trees at the Towers Family Historical Museum in Hobbs were not just a beautiful display of Christmas cheer. They prompted $50,000 in donations for Compass Hospice's work in Caroline County.Despite the rainy weather, the annual Festival of Trees the first weekend of December attracted almost two dozen corporate sponsors who raised over $25,000 of the total proceeds. Sponsorship levels ranged from $5,000 or more to $250.
About 130 people attended the preview party Friday, Dec. 1, to put in their bids for tiny, tabletop trees to elaborately decorated trees with extras, and everything in between.
I think it's the best year yet," said Compass Hospice CEO Heather Guerieri Sunday afternoon.
"A lot of the same people do trees and sponsor over and over, and they just get more talented and more creative every year." Co-chairs of this year's festival were Melanie McMahan and Dave Whaley.
When all the receipts were counted, the result was "the most successful Festival of Trees to date," Baird wrote in a Dec. 15 email.
"It's been great," said Compass Hospice Development Director Shelly Baird Sunday afternoon.
"We have 76 trees, which is the most we've ever had." This is the sixth year the event has been held at the Towers Family Historical Museum on Sennett Road.
Owners Bill and Gail Towers "are so generous," Baird said. "They host this and they donate and they're amazing." "We just want the bids to go up," Gail Towers said, laughing as she imitated the chiming sound of new bids on the Trice Auctions website.
"I just can't wait till it starts bing, bing, bing, bing, bing." The preview party's "Pick of the Tree Lot" raffle raised $3,000. The winner, who could choose any tree in the display, chose "Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire," a snowy, woodland-themed tree and extras donated by the Strzempka family. It was won by Jill Pugh of Shore Industries of Denton, one of the festival's sponsors.
The Strzempka family's 2022 tree won the raffle as well. Along with this year's tree, they donated a fire pit and supplies, as well as decorations created by family members from across the country.
Created in memory of the family patriarch who had been cared for by Compass Hospice at the end of his life, "the whole family came three different days to get it perfect," Baird said.
"One of the granddaughters, I believe in Seattle, donated these hand blown icicles. Another grandchild made the skirts. These are handmade mittens by another family member," she said.
"I don't know all the stories, but I'm sure many of these other trees have a story," Baird said.
About four trees sported a Grinch theme. Some trees were rustic, other elegant.
Several tabletop trees were made of seashells. North Caroline High School's Spanish IV class created a "We are Bulldogs!" tree while Choptank Electric Cooperative honored 100 years of Disney.
Some creators donated several trees; florist Sherry Councell created a dozen.
Festival attendees picked up information for online bidding hosted by Trice Auctions of Denton. Bidding ended at 4 p.m. Sunday, and winners picked up their trees the following Monday and Tuesday.
The festival "proceeds stay in Caroline County for hospice services and grief services," Guerieri said. "We don't turn people away based on ability to pay if they don't have insurance for hospice." Baird said fundraisers like the Festival of Trees provides for Compass Hospices services in Caroline, Kent and Queen Anne's counties.
"We have to raise about $500,000 to $700,000 a year through donations" because insurance doesn't cover every hospice service," Baird said.
"Our entire grief services support department is not covered by insurance, so all of about $400,000 of that goes to that department. We provide counseling to close to 800 people a year, and a lot of them were not even involved with hospice." Among them are children in each of the three counties' schools.
Compass Hospice, based in Centreville, provides hospice and supportive care in-home and at the Barnette Center in Centreville and Arcadia Assisted Living in Denton; community grief support; and veterans services.
"This is just such a heartwarming experience to be able to volunteer and be among such a special group of people that do care, and their heart is in it," volunteer Connie Calloway Hutson said. "That's the reason I do it. I'm just so proud that I can do it." Bill Towers said they sponsor fundraisers for hospice "because it's an organization that needs some support." "And he has a heart of gold," Gail Towers said.
"They do a great job.
We've never had to use hospice," Bill Towers said, as his wife added, "It's one of those things that you're glad that they have it." "But you hope you never have to use it," he said. 
 
 Caption: CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 From left, Compass Hospice Development Director Shelly Baird, volunteer Connie Calloway Hutson, volunteer Jody Herb and CEO Heather Guerieri wrap up the Festival of Trees Dec. 3 at Towers Family Historical Museum in Denton.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 This detail is from the "What a Treasure" tree, donated by the Cory Family.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 This Christmas Tree Farms tree was one of a dozen donated by Sherry Councell to Compass Hospice's Festival of Trees.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Compass Hospice's Shelly Baird poses with this "God Bless America" tree donated by Nagel Farm Service.

 CONNIE CONNOLLY/STAR DEMOCRAT

 Bill and Gail Towers host the 2023 Compass Hospice Festival of Trees at their Towers Family Historical Museum in Denton. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a fundraiser for Compass Hospice, a health care provider, making the health sector the most relevant category despite the event’s fundraising aspect.

title: Trans patients face barriers to care
author: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service
content:
Trans patients face barriers to care

 December 21, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tommy Tucker; Capital News Service | Page: A9 | Section: News 
 
 840
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS - Paisley Parsons is 10 years into his medical gender-affirming transition, and a majority of that time he's spent looking for a good team of doctors in Maryland.Parsons, from near Hagerstown, had limited access to nearby care when starting his transition. Driving to Philadelphia, the District of Columbia or Baltimore were the best options to receive what he needed.
"It took me probably six or seven years to find a team of doctors that I felt like was up to par, but prior to that, finding someone educated and competent was few and far between," Parsons said. "A lot of it was a proximity issue, and most doctors around me just had no idea about anything trans related." While access to gender-affirming care has improved since Parsons first started his transition, it still varies across Maryland.
"Some of my patients travel hours to see me," said Dr. Helene Hedian, the director of Clinical Education at Johns Hopkins' Center for Transgender and Gender Expansive Health in Baltimore. "There has been an increased demand for services in the past year, which at times has led to long wait times." There is a concentration of qualified doctors in urban areas like D.C. and Baltimore, with less access the farther a patient is from a major city.
For those looking for a doctor with experience in gender-affirming care, Hedian recommends looking through the provider directory on GLMA: Health Professionals Advancing LGBTQ Equality's website.
The directory confirms the concentration of doctors in urban areas. For example, a search for gender-affirming hormone therapy in Easton, shows the closest doctor is over an hour away in Baltimore, D.C. or Odenton, Maryland.
"Baltimore City is probably the nexus of the trans community in terms of access, but the wait times are really long for our experienced providers," said Lee Blinder, the executive director of Trans Maryland, a trans-led community organization.
"Many people in our more rural areas of the state, or even in some of our counties in our suburban areas, are not able to access an affirming provider." Blinder is a founder of Trans Maryland, formerly known as Trans Healthcare MD, which started as a community resource for connecting trans and non-binary residents to qualified practitioners.
"Trans Maryland started out of my own and our other co-founders' lack of access to gender-affirming care," said Blinder. "We are extraordinarily lucky to be based in Maryland, certainly looking at the national landscape." In May this year, Gov.
Wes Moore signed the Trans Health Equity Act, which requires the state's medical assistance program and Medicaid to provide coverage for gender-affirming care beginning Jan. 1.
Moore also signed an executive order in June, protecting anyone seeking gender-affirming care in Maryland from legal punishment by other states.
"Those two events in the past year have contributed to increased demand for gender care in the state of Maryland," said Hedian. "People are traveling into the state, especially because in many states they're not able to receive the care that they used to get." As of 2022, 24,000 transgender adults live in Maryland, with an estimated 6,000 enrolled in Medicaid, according to a study by the Williams Institute on Medicaid coverage for gender-affirming care.
The Maryland Department of Health estimated that the number of Medicaid enrollees seeking gender-affirming treatment under the bill would increase by approximately 25 individuals per year, up from 98 in 2022.
"We're aware of the issue and we know that being able to address health care shortages, (is) something that has been long standing within the state," Moore said to Capital News Service. "I also know that things like the Trans Health Care Act was the right thing, in the right manner, and we want to make sure that our state is welcoming." Moore said that having the medical facilities and personnel to treat people is a priority, and that doctor and nursing shortages extend to other areas of medicine.
To adjust to the demand, Dr. Julius Joi Johnson-Weaver, a board-certified family physician, offers gender-affirming care through a program at their private practice. Johnson-Weaver is transgender and non-binary and has experienced many of the care-access issues their patients have dealt with.
It sparks a lot of anxiety, Johnson-Weaver said, when someone is ready to transition "in whatever way it typically starts to feel urgent," and they are told, "Oh yeah, it's gonna be six months, you know, or it's gonna take a long time to get an appointment." Del. Bonnie Cullison, D-Montgomery, vice-chairman of the House Health and Government Operations Committee, cosponsored the Trans Health Equity Act.
She said she is aware of the access issues and works closely with Trans Maryland to solve them. And, she said, she agrees with Moore that the bill was the right step for protecting health care for trans Marylanders.
Cullison encourages transgender constituents to reach out about these issues: "Talk to us, keep us informed. Let us know what we can do policy-wise, or advocacy-wise." 
 
 Caption: TOMMY TUCKER/CA PITAL NEWS SERVICE

 A poster at the University of Maryland Health Center in College Park reminds students to update their name and gender marker in the school's system, Friday, Dec. 1. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses barriers to gender‑affirming medical care, Medicaid coverage, and health policy, which are core health‑related issues.

title: Local children affected by addiction receive holiday gifts through Nicole's Promise
author: CONTRIBUTED
content:
Local children affected by addiction receive holiday gifts through Nicole's Promise

 December 22, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CONTRIBUTED | Page: 8 | Section: News 
 
 509
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - More than 70 children with parents lost to, struggling with or in recovery from addiction got Christmas gifts this month, thanks to a new program in Easton.Nicole's Promise, a program from Grace Street, a recovery community organization in Easton, directly supported young people who have lost a parent to addiction with a special shopping trip hosted by Talbot County Sheriff's Office deputies.
Nicole's Promise also includes a Christmas gift drive for children and teens with a parent struggling with or in early recovery from substance use disorder.
Bri S., a peer support specialist at Grace Street, thought of the program in honor of her best friend, Nicole, who died of an overdose last March. Nicole left behind six children.
Last week, 19 children and teens aged 3 to 16 who lost one or both parents to addiction met at the Talbot County Sheriff's Office in Easton for the Christmas event.
After a visit and gift from Santa, the group rode in a caravan with Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble and his deputies and staff to Target, where each child had $150 to spend and teens had $200 to spend any way they chose.
The kids fanned out with the sheriff and his crew and had a blast deciding what to buy. Target donated wrapping paper, bows and popcorn.
After a generous Secret Santa paid for the gifts, the group headed back to the sheriff's office for a visit with an elf, hot chocolate and cookies, pizza and gift wrapping, plus an impromptu game of soccer with the sheriff.
Nicole's Promise also provided top wished-for gifts for 22 children in Talbot County and 30 children in Caroline County, thanks to Mid-Shore Restoring Hope in Women. In total, Nicole's Promise provided gifts this holiday season to 71 children and teens.
Grace Street is the area's first recovery community organization. RCOs are a nationally recognized model that help bridge the gap between professional treatment and a successful life in long-term recovery through enhanced supports and services.
Chesapeake Charities received a one-year grant from Maryland's Opioid Operational Command Center to establish the Grace Street RCO.
Easton's center delivers an assortment of non-clinical, community-centered, peer recovery support services, harm reduction resources, workforce training and development, youth programming, overdose prevention activities and resources and support groups. The center helps people establish healthy lifestyles and reacclimate into society while building recovery capital and working to reduce stigma often associated with addiction.
Grace Street serves people in Easton and Talbot County and in neighboring counties across the Mid-Shore. Referrals are not necessary and services are free. The center is open weekdays and Sundays, 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. and Saturdays, 2 to 7 p.m. Daytime hours vary.
For more information, visit GraceStreetRecovery.org. 
 
 Caption: CONTRIBUTED

 Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble, along with some of his deputies and staff, pose with Grace Street Program Director Kate Dulin and several children during Nicole's Promise in Easton.

 CONTRIBUTED

 Grace Street volunteer Michele Dyott, left, smiles during gift wrapping with Trent Acree, 11, and a Christmas elf during Nicole's Promise in Easton.

 CONTRIBUTED

 Talbot County Sheriff's Office Capt. John Bollinger wraps gifts during the Nicole's Promise program.

title: 'This is a game-changer' - Caroline moves forward with mobile health plans
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content:
'This is a game-changer' - Caroline moves forward with mobile health plans

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com | Page: A1 | Section: News 
 
 1074
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON - Caroline County is one step closer to a mobile integrated health program.Data compiled in a 71-page needs analysis report has set the stage for a grant request approved by the Caroline County Commissioners at their Dec. 5 meeting.
Presenting highlights of the report were four members of an executive committee focused on the program and finding funding for it. They included Director of the Department of Emergency Services Mark Sheridan, Health Officer Robin Cahall, EMS Chief Kathy Jo Marvel and County Health Department Director of Nursing Holly Trice.
Executive committee members who were absent from the meeting are Chrissy Bartz, of the Basic Life Support Committee, and Dr. Jeffrey Uribe, Caroline County Medical Director.
The report describes the current medical needs of county residents, how and where emergency medical teams respond to them and how they can be better served by a more efficient and effective program.
"We don't want to just focus on reoccurring ambulance calls because that is a small part of it," Sheridan said. "We want to look at the health of all the people in Caroline County and how can we provide that point of care that they may need." The goal of the mobile integrated healthcare program is "a huge partnership with all of us coming together to basically take care of people," Sheridan said.
The report, initiated in spring 2023, was compiled by Annapolis-based Tetra Tech and funded by the Caroline County Basic Life Support Committee.
It substantiated what EMS has experienced, but it provided the data needed to seek grant funding from the Maryland Department of Health to create a mobile integrated health program.
Following a nationwide trend, "911 calls are getting more and more primary care-related and less emergency," Marvel said. Many of the calls EMS receives are from people who "don't really need to go to the ER, which now has compounded into long ER wait times because they're using the ambulance and the ERs to treat what could be treated with primary care." Tetra Tech compiled call data and discovered "69 unique addresses that generated the bulk of calls; 558 repeat calls, to be exact, to just 69 different addresses," Marvel said. "It was a total of 70 individuals within those addresses that we could identify right now, just out of EMS, that are prime candidates for a mobile integrated health program." "We don't want you to think we don't want to do 911 calls, but 911 is built for the emergency calls; they're not built for us to be going out into the public and taking care of these people," Marvel said. "These people need other resources. The ER isn't good for them either, because you'd see a doctor once for blood pressure medicine, and then 30 days later you're out of that prescription and then you're going back to the ER for another 30 days for blood pressure medicine." The problem is "the health care system as a whole," she said, not a single department or agency.
A map of high density response areas verified what Sheridan and Marvel suspected. Most of the emergency responses were directed to "high populated areas of foreign descent that came here and don't know how to ask for help or don't know how to get help." "What we found through the study was 63% of the contacts that we do annually don't need a paramedic at all," Marvel said. "We have limited access to health care
We have long transport times because we don't have a hospital." Lack of transportation to primary care has prompted Commission President Travis Breeding to call for a mobility on demand program.
"We have lack of follow up with primary care, and then the big one is always that transportation piece," Marvel said.
"So, what's our purpose and goal? We want to reduce those high-frequency EMS repeat callers, improve access to preventive health care in Caroline County - people need the right care when it's needed (and) a whole community effort" as well as support from the county commission, Marvel said.
"All the resources have to be on the same page and somebody is going to have to manage this data," she said.
"And then we have to figure out what that sustainable funding is going to look like because we can't do it on our own." Armed with data from the Tetra Tech report, the executive committee is seeking a Community Health Resource Commission grant, so Cahall and Trice created a Health Equity Resource Communities request for proposal, which funds up to $1 million a year for five years.
Specifically, the committee is applying for "a little over $2.7 million for a 5-year period," Cahall said. "What we're looking at (is) five years' worth of personnel and training, vehicle purchase and maintenance, community outreach education, technology upgrades, and quality assurance and program evaluation." Instead of a trip to an emergency room or urgent care, a nurse or EMS clinician potentially will be able to assess a client's needs at home, possibly through a telehealth visit with a doctor, and then follow up with appropriate resources from other community partners, like the departments of health or social services.
Letters of support for the grant application have come from University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, Choptank Community Health, the Mid-Shore Local Health Improvement Coalition, the BLS Committee, Caroline County Behavioral Health, DES, Dr. Uribe and others.
Even if that funding doesn't come through, the committee is committed to moving forward with a mobile integrated health program in the county. "We're going to keep going," Cahall said. "We're still doing a strategic plan." The committee should hear if they've received the funding by mid-February.
The full report is online at www.carolinemd.org/DocumentCenter/View/9045/Caroline-County-MIH-Needs-Analysis.
To view the full Dec. 5 presentation to the County Commissioners, visit www.carolinemd.org/667/Live-Meetings, and click on the video link. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT

 Presenting highlights of the report to the Caroline County Commissioners Dec. 5 are four members of an executive committee focused on creating a mobile integrated health program. Inset from left are: Health Officer Robin Cahall, EMS Chief Kathy Jo Marvel and County Health Department Director of Nursing Holly Trice and, out of frame, Director of the Department of Emergency Services Mark Sheridan.

 COURTESY OF CAR OLINE COUNTY

 A map in the Mobile Integrated Health Program Needs Analysis report shows the location and types of emergency medical response in Caroline County.

 COURTESY OF CAR OLINE COUNTY

 Data compiled in this 71-page needs analysis report has set the stage for a grant request approved by the Caroline County Commissioners at their Dec. 5 meeting. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: 'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting
author: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com
content:
'We have a lot to do' - Maryland Commission on Public Health holds inaugural meeting

 December 27, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid; mreid@somdnews.com | Page: 2 | Section: News 
 
 469
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Maryland's Commission on Public Health met virtually for the first time as a group on Dec. 14 and spent much of the time in the organizational phase.The commission will be tasked with making recommendations to improve the delivery of foundational public health services, assessing the foundational health capabilities of the Maryland Department of Health as well as local health departments and make recommendations for reform.
It will also address foundational public health areas, including as they relate to behavioral health, and respond to COVID-19, overdoses, maternal and infant mortality and other major public health challenges.
"Our main task ultimately is reporting; it's not just meeting, discussing, working in our work groups, coming up with recommendations, analyzing," said Lushniak, who added that assessing, analyzing and recommendations are key features.
The commission will be in effect until June 30, 2025, when it must submit its final report.
An interim report was due Dec. 1, which was submitted by the co-chairs who were able to meet a few times "as we didn't want to be late with our homework assignment," Lushniak said.
That report was sent with a few amendments, one of which was a request for an extension to June 30, 2025, for its final report. Though the commission took effect last June 1, appointments were not completed until late October.
The commission also requested the ability to seek financial support mechanisms as it believes "there may be opportunities in public health foundation-level support through grant mechanisms." The commission members requested the establishment of maryland.gov emails as well as the establishment of a website. The members also officially recognized the contributions of staff providing subject matter expertise and noted "government-involved staffing helps facilitate the logistics and work of this commission." "I think we all experienced the incredible challenge of the pandemic of the century in the past few years, and during that challenge recognized how incredibly strenuous the task was ahead of our public health force in particular, and the roadblocks and the gaps in public health, funding and resources really restricted our ability," said Dr. Meena Brewster, one of three co-chairs on the state board.
"We have a lot to do to be out there and be a part of this," said Lushniak, who added the commission has no hidden agendas and will be "transparent." The next meeting will be held at 2 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 4, at the Baltimore County Department of Health. There will also be a virtual option.
For more information on the Commission of Public Health, email MD.CoPG@maryland.gov or go to smchd.org/commissiononpublichealth/. 
 
 Caption: SCREENSHOT BY MICHAEL REID/SOUTHERN MARY LAND NEWS

 Maryland Commission on Public Health Co-Chair and St. Mary's County Health Officer Dr. Meena Brewster, top left, speaks to, clockwise from top right, Dr. Boris Lushniak, Dr. Oluwatosin Olateju, Sen. Ariana Kelly (D) and Dr. Nicole Rochester during the commission's inaugural meeting Dec. 14. 

 © Copyright © 2023 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the inaugural meeting of Maryland's Commission on Public Health and its role in assessing and improving public health services, which directly aligns with the Health topic.

title: UM Shore Easton employee wins CAPE Award
author: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com
content:
UM Shore Easton employee wins CAPE Award

 January 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom Mccall; tmccall@chespub.com | Page: 4 | Section: News 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON - Debra Powell, an Environmental Services team member at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton, recently won the Cintas Corporation's CAPE Award, which honors team members for their dedication in keeping patients, team members and visitors safe and stopping the spread of infection through Hospital Acquired Infections.UM Shore Medical Center at Easton is a University of Maryland Shore Regional Health hospital.
Powell was one of 10 national winners of the award, which is sponsored annually by the Cintas Corporation to celebrate EVS team members in acute and long-term care facilities. They are at the frontline of patient care, providing clean and safe facilities for health care workers, patients, residents and visitors across the country.
CAPE stands for Cleaning to Advance the Patient Experience.
Nominations for this award honor heroic EVS technicians "who might not wear a cape, but who play critical roles in cleaning and sanitizing health care facilities to eliminate viruses, germs and hospital-acquired infections," said Aaron Reddick, unit director of EVS for UM Shore Regional Health.
"Out of 700 nominations, Debra was selected as one of the winners at different hospitals in the United States for showing exemplary hard work to mitigate HAIs and keep our patients and team members safe from infection," Reddick said.
"I have watched Debra go above and beyond in her work, training new team members, and teaching others the ropes of how the job is done and the reason we are so important and vital in health care," he said. "She recently celebrated 40 years of service to UM Shore Regional Health, and we can't thank her enough for her dedication to her role as a housekeeper and to the well-being of our patients and team members."
"EVS staff play an increasingly vital role in infection control, but their hard work often goes unnoticed," Reddick said.
Chad Poeppelmeier, Cintas' vice president of healthcare said "We're proud to honor these unsung heroes who display empathy and courage and spend countless hours cleaning and maintaining public and private spaces to prevent infection." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a hospital environmental services employee recognized for preventing infections, which directly relates to healthcare and patient safety, making the Health topic the most appropriate.

title: Health team makes significant progress over the past year
author: Contributed
content:
Health team makes significant progress over the past year

 January 4, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 5 | Section: News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON. Working in collaboration with primary and specialty care providers throughout the region, University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's Population Health team has made significant progress in the past year toward the goal of helping people with chronic diseases manage their conditions to maintain optimal health in their home settings."Population Health's case managers, transitional nurse navigators and pharmacists, and Shore Community Outreach team members are making a positive difference in the health and well-being of residents across the five-county region served by Shore Regional Health," said Nancy Bedell, director of Population Health.
"In addition to working with providers, they have established working relationships with many community organizations, government entities and employers, and maintained a strong presence at health fairs and other events where they can share information and resources to help individuals maintain their best health." Highlights of the Population Health team's activities in the past year include:
▪ Community Case Management (Shore Community Outreach Team). This team, known at SCOT, enrolled 115 patients and conducted 920 home visits in Kent County. After six months, 75 patients identified as "high utilizers" realized an average decrease in health care charges of $5,919 per patient.
▪ Medication Management. Visiting 10 senior centers throughout the five-county region every month, Population Health's transitional care pharmacist provided more than 500 consults to 1,500 participants, and additionally responded to more than 1,200 medication alerts.
▪ Transitional Nurse Navigators (TNNs). Follow-up phone calls and home visits made by TNNs reached more than 20,000 patients and resolved more than 3,500 alerts. 75 percent within three days. They also followed 649 patients, many of whom ultimately transferred into support programs for those with heart failure, COPD and diabetes.
▪ Heart Failure and Diabetes Continuums. 182 patients were enrolled in the HF Continuum, which includes acute care, cardiac rehab, rehab, cardiology and follow-up by the TNNs. In the Diabetes Continuum, inpatients with HgA1c greater than 9 were identified, provided a consult with a diabetes educator, and at discharge, referred to our Diabetes and Endocrinology Center.
Patients retested six months later realized a 10 percent or more reduction in their HgA1c.
▪ Health Equity. Population Health team members provided on-site screenings and education at Amick Farms and Angelica Nurseries. employers with a high percentage of employees from underserved populations. focusing on diabetes and heat-related illnesses. In Kent County, SCOT has worked with local church leaders to establish the African-American Women's Advisory Committee, which is offering health-related educational program targeted to the African American community.
▪ Advance Directives. Population Health team members have partnered with a host of senior-focused organizations and residential care communities throughout the region to enable individuals to complete their advance directives and have them scanned into their electronic medical records (EMR). This ongoing initiative resulted in more than 1,000 advance directives completed and filed last year. 
 
 Caption: Alma White of Calvert Heights Apartments in Chestertown, was among the local residents to get a blood pressure check from Shore Community Outreach Team Nurse Coordinator Emily Welsh in May 2023.

 University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Pharmacist Melanie Chapple, PharmD (left) is shown with Amick Farms Health Center team members Valerie Kriegisch, PA and Heather Bautista, CMA. Chapple has visited Amick Farms, located in Hurlock, to provide diabetes screening, education and support to their employees

 PHOTOS BY UM SHORE

 Population Health team members Kathy Sellers (left) and Terry Satchell (right) deliver a gift basket to Angela Shenton, manager of Homestead Manor Assisted Living in Denton. Homestead Manor is one of several residential care communities that participated in Population Health's Advance Directives Campaign.

title: Where life begins at the Talbot County Free Library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
Where life begins at the Talbot County Free Library

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In an article published in the Guardian in 2004, Sandi Toksvig recalled a lecture she attended while studying anthropology at Cambridge University.At one point, the professor held up a photograph of an antler bone with 28 markings on it. The lecturer told the assembled students that scholars considered the antler "to be man's first attempt at a calendar." But the professor, a woman, wasn't finished. "Tell me," she went on, "what man needs to keep track of when 28 days have passed?"
I came across this delightful story in Leah Hazard's new book "Womb: The Inside Story of Where We All Began" (612.627 HAZA), now available for check-out at the Talbot County Free Library.
I have to admit, when I first saw the work sitting on the library's New Books shelf, my initial, perfectly male response was to look away, as if I had inadvertently caught sight of something I shouldn't have.
I had a similar response as a pre-med student eons ago, when I saw my first illustration of the female reproductive organs. I remember taking one look at that cascade of complex anatomical structures — ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix, vagina — and thinking that Ob-Gyn was not in the cards for me. All over the world, women sighed in relief.
But I'm considerably older now and, hopefully, a tad wiser. And so, bravely and forthrightly, I removed the volume from its shelf, held its cover to my chest, walked over to the desk, checked it out to myself, and then smuggled it, unseen, out of the building.
And I'm so glad I did.
Hazard is a Harvard graduate who works now as a midwife in the U.K. She is also an excellent writer with a wicked sense of humor.
Reading her book, I discovered that I was not the only male to take one look at the inner workings of the female reproductive system and pale.
Since men came to dominate the field of obstetrics, their patients have been subjected to any number of pejorative diagnoses ("hostile uterus," "irritable uterus," "incompetent cervix," etc.) that reflect this male discomfort with any anatomy other than their own: but it was not always thus.
Thirty-some-odd years ago, I read Laurel Thatcher Ulrich's ground-breaking history "A Midwife's Tale," based on a diary Ulrich discovered in a long-forgotten corner of the Maine State Library.
The diary was maintained from 1785 to 1812 by a midwife named Martha Ballard. Ballard used the diary as a sort of ledger, keeping meticulous, coded records of her methods, successes and failures as she rode back and forth across the frontiers of New England delivering babies.
From Ulrich's book I learned that when male doctors began to encroach in the early nineteenth century upon the heretofore feminine domain of birthing, infant and maternal mortality soared. It wasn't until the first decades of the twentieth century that "modern medicine" began to achieve the same success rate midwives had enjoyed for hundreds of years.
From Hazard's book I learned many of the reasons why.
A midwife like Martha Ballard didn't just attend at a birth. She moved in with her patient; cooked her meals; administered soothing, effective herbs; delivered the baby and then remained in place until she was certain both patient and child could survive on their own — her entire visit often lasting days, even weeks.
The French word for midwife is accoucheur — literally "the person at the bedside." But with the advent of male physicians, the caregiver moved from the woman's side to her feet. The word "obstetrics" comes from the Latin obstare, "to stand opposite."
Male doctors first began "to stand opposite" women giving birth as the Industrial Revolution was getting underway, and unsurprisingly their approach to the process took on a decidedly industrial air. Speed was of the essence.
In 1807, Yale-trained physician Joseph Stearns admitted in a letter to a colleague that he had learned about ergot (a fungus found on wheat crops) from "an ignorant Scottish midwife," but went on to report, "It expedites lingering parturition, and saves … a considerable portion of time …. Since I have adopted the use of this powder I have seldom found a case that detained me more than three hours."
Soon, in their rush to speed up the process, doctors were using — with increasingly deleterious effects — much higher doses than the "diluted thimbleful" of ergot recommended by midwives.
But Hazard's book serves as more than just a corrective to the customary patriarchal view of the female reproductive system. In the images she conjures of the inner workings of the womb — the little unseen miracles of cervical crypts, blastulae, uterine milk and even menopause — she returns to us the mystery and majesty of what a woman, being a woman, lives through and accomplishes. We men can only look on in awe. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a book about female reproductive anatomy, midwifery, and historical medical practices, focusing on health and gender-related aspects, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school
author: LAURA TAYMAN
content:
Health department recommends making condoms available at local high school

 January 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: LAURA TAYMAN | Section: News 
 
 643
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Last month, Kent County Board of Education members were provided stark facts about the rise in sexually transmitted diseases (STD) in the community, the state, and the country at its recent monthly meeting.Ashley Minietta, communicable disease and family planning contact for the Kent County Department of Health, made a presentation to the board before the holiday break, saying the solution to reversing the trend is "to provide ground support, monitor trends, and turn data into action."
"While 20% of Marylanders have an STD, almost half of the cases are ages 15-24," Minietta said, citing the 2020 U.S. census map — putting Maryland in the South region of the country, "It's one of the highest rates in the region."
Minietta said the barriers to effectively preventing both STDs and teenage pregnancies in Kent County are lack of education, the cost of birth control, parental resistance to alternatives, lack of public transportation, the geographic barriers of the rural area and lack of health care options.
Teen pregnancy rates are down, Minietta said, because parents have been proactive with putting teenage daughters on birth control. But pills and IUDs do not allow the prevention of STDs that can lead to long-term health consequences.
"Research in 2020 shows only 9% of sexually active high school students used a condom," Minetta said. "That has only increased."
Minetta shared various ways local school systems are providing a condom availability program to meet the needs of their high school students, including those in Queen Anne's, Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot and Wicomico counties, and counties on the western shore.
While some have availability through the school's nurse's office, others provide a "brown bag" approach, where students can pick up a paper bag on an anonymous basis.
Board member Aretha Dorsey said that as a parent she was concerned that a program like that would encourage secrets among parents and their children.
"I feel like parents' rights are being taken away," Dorsey said. "I believe that kids might form a lack of respect for their parents and think they can do things their own way."
Board member Francois Sullivan said Kent County and its rural location is a valid argument for such a program.
"There is a difference between a nurse providing condoms and a cashier."
When asked to share her opinion, student board member Madison Messick said she couldn't even remember her sex education class.
"I think this is really important," she said. "There is a stigma. We can't go to Walgreens because we know the cashier. I know kids that would definitely benefit from this."
Vienna Walker, supervisor of student services for the Board, said she recommended the board adopt a policy where Kent County students can meet with a high school nurse and ask for information and guidance.
Superintendent Karen Couch said she had been asked by parents how students could be opted out of a program if they don't approve. Walker said she would need to check with the state's Department of Education to see how that could be handled.
"Some students have much more open communication with school nurses than their parents," Walker said. "Their office is much less threatening to students who then become comfortable enough to come back if they are not feeling great."
That is Walker's goal. She recommended the board consider approving a program that requires students to visit nurses who can provide education and guidance on condom use.
"Nurses also encourage students to be open and honest with their parents," Walker said.
Messick agreed.
"Students will participate not because kids don't trust their parents," she said. "The program encourages conversations between parents and their children. It's like therapy where they can't tell parents what their child is talking about. This actually helps to form a better relationship between students and parents."
School Board President Joe Goetz said he would like for Walker to get information from other districts on how they manage parent objections.
"I think real life examples would help," Goetz said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on STD rates, condom distribution, and teen health concerns, which are core health issues, though it also involves school policy and education.

title: Endurance athlete dominates diabetes: Rock Hall resident raises over $1,000 for the cause
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Endurance athlete dominates diabetes: Rock Hall resident raises over $1,000 for the cause

 January 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 1133
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ROCK HALL — Early in 2023, Phil Anderson, a Rock Hall resident of 10 years, underwent open heart surgery, a triple bypass, due to uncontrolled diabetes.He went into the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia with feelings of anger at his predicament. As a former Gold's Gym owner, a participant in countless endurance races and someone who was confident of being one of the fittest people in the room, the situation confounded him.
With support from his family, he had a successful surgery. His doctor assured him that for a man like him, who spent years exercising and practicing good dietary habits, the surgery would be like giving a tune-up to a car.
With that confidence, and a mindset of setting goals and overseeing steps to carry them through, he asked himself how he could give back.
How could he help society based on his current experience?
Four months out of surgery, he signed up for the American Diabetes Association's Tour de Cure, a "metric century," a 62-mile bicycle ride to raise funds for the organization. The beauty of the Tour de Cure for Anderson was the ride was completed independently at any place and time chosen by the rider.
Training for it began in Rock Hall.
Anderson's goal was to cycle five miles the first week, then each following week he'd tack on five extra, until, after 12 weeks he'd reach 60 miles.
While he trained, he fundraised. Rock Hall locals frequently saw him at the grocery store with a table set up, or holding a raffle at the Pirates and Wenches event on Aug. 11.
He planned to do the metric century in September on a Saturday, but anticipating storms over the weekend, he bumped it to Friday.
That day was windy, he recalled.
Pedaling his Gary Fisher hybrid bike, he made the circuit all around Kent County.
Starting in Rock Hall, Anderson headed east to Chestertown, cycled north to Kennedyville, took some of the large hills at Galena, stopped at Massey Air Museum to take a photo, back to Chestertown, then home to Rock Hall.
He rode 65 miles in five hours.
For Anderson, it was one of many endurance races and events, but this was special in a different way.
He raised $1,260, placing 18th nationally, becoming one of 30 nationwide tour champions.
Anderson thanked all the businesses and private donors that reached out to him, impressed with the way Kent County gave; Rock Hall specifically.
There were many to thank, but some of the most generous contributions came from Donna Walls at Harbor Shack restaurant, Suzanne Einstein at Blue Crab Sailing Charters, Andrew Carroll at Bayside Market and Amy Mitchell and Jim Rich at Java Rock, key supporters.
"All of this came from a town of less than 2,000 people," Anderson said.
Always setting new, reachable goals for himself, he didn't stop at the Tour de Cure.
After that, with a good friend, he completed the Chestertown Challenge, a half marathon.
Then on Veteran's Day, Nov. 11, he hiked 11 miles through Rock Hall. Anderson wore a 22-pound weighted vest representing the 22 veterans who commit suicide every day.
He chose to walk an extra mile to symbolize the extra mile veterans go to secure our freedoms.
"To everyone who served, thank you," Anderson said.
Adding creativity to his planning strategies and good health, Anderson extends his hand to help those in need. He does it because diabetes was an eye-opener for him that started a lifelong journey to wellness.
Despite having his surgery later in life, he was diagnosed with diabetes in his 30s, driven by a lifestyle of being on the road while working for various publications and newspapers throughout Pennsylvania. When he received his diagnosis, he asked his doctor what he should do.
Diet and exercise, the doctor suggested.
Anderson did just that. He lost 100 pounds, then started exercising. He became a competitive runner and cycler, competing in duathlons and snowboard competitions. He recalled cycling from Orlando to Miami, 250 miles, in three days.
During his health pursuit, he learned about what his body needed, how to build and maintain muscle and how to avoid unhealthy habits.
"That started a second career path. So in my 40s, I told myself, I know just as much as the average guy in the gym," Anderson said.
Using that knowledge, he ran his own personal training studio.
However, the habits to maintain his health went to the wayside when he moved to the Eastern Shore. As stated on his fundraising page, as a Type 2 diabetic, he never made a real effort to treat his condition, thinking that diet and exercise would be enough to suppress the effects of the disease.
Diabetes, Anderson described, was like an invisible slide.
He assumed since he was always exercising, and not overweight, he'd be alright. Any symptom he had, he could attribute it to something else.
If he was always thirsty, it was because he was an athlete, exerting himself. If his eyesight was worsening, it was typical of old age.
Then in October, 2022, thinking he had really bad heartburn, he sat on the couch, in pain. Like a cycler biking against the wind, he tried to ride it out. He even started thinking he might have had a heart attack.
Later, doing tests, talking with his doctor, he learned it was out-of-control diabetes.
"In the hospital, I found out my blood sugar level was four times the normal person's, and three out of four arteries were blocked."
This was a shock to him, especially since in that condition, he had hiked 19 miles of the Appalachian trail with a 30-pound backpack.
How could he do that with three blocked arteries? he asked.
No other choice, the surgery had to happen.
It sobered him further about diabetes, and strengthened his resolve to help people accomplish their health goals.
Of all the things Anderson's learned, he said there are four things to prevent that invisible slide he experienced. Pay attention to your body. Try and move more. Get better sleep. And find a hobby to reduce stress.
Perhaps for Anderson this is a resurgence in his second career. He's planning on getting back in the wellness industry where he'll instruct clients how to develop a base level setting goals then optimizing it for efficiency.
He says it is crucial to have a vision before starting any exercise or nutrition plans.
"It may be to kick around the soccer ball with your grandkids," Anderson said. "Whatever it is, it needs to begin with an image. Then it's following the rules of your routine."
Anderson, as he's demonstrated in his life, has the results to prove these methods work.
As of right now, he's off insulin shots, only taking a few pills a day. His most recent tests indicate he's at the range of high to normal.
Diabetes can be prevailed over.
It takes vision, effort, and making a promise to yourself, Anderson said.
"If you can't keep a promise to yourself," he added, "then how can anybody else trust you?" 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the subject's diabetes diagnosis, surgery, and ongoing health advocacy, making health the primary focus, with sports mentioned as the means of fundraising.

title: Time to quit
author: KEN CLENDANIEL Pastor Bethlehem Wesleyan Church
content:
Time to quit

 January 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KEN CLENDANIEL Pastor Bethlehem Wesleyan Church | Section: Time To Quit 
 
 284
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I went to the gym yesterday for the first time since before the holidays.Apparently, I was not the only one who had this idea because the gym was packed full of people. Many use this time to make New Years resolutions — promises to do better. Start going to the gym. Start eating right. Start going to church more often. These are all good things.
But too often these resolutions are short-lived.
I believe that in order to continue pursuing our resolutions and goals, there are three significant things in 2024 that we must also be challenged to quit. It is time to quit making excuses, quit procrastinating and quit complaining.
Most likely you can look back and find many occasions last year where you found yourself making excuses by saying, "I cannot do this because I am too old, too young, too tall, too overwhelmed, too poor, too busy, not smart enough, not prepared enough."
"So, I'll put it off until tomorrow. I'll do it later. I'll start when I have more time or energy or money."
This then leads to complaining. We complain because we aren't where we want to be or because we don't have what we want or because life hasn't given us what we feel we deserve. We complain because we are too old, too young, too tall, too overwhelmed, too poor, too busy, not smart enough, not prepared enough. And it becomes an endless cycle: make excuses, procrastinate, complain.
What if this year we were to quit making excuses, quit procrastinating and quit complaining about our situation and instead took action with God's help to continue pursuing the significant changes in our lives.
I believe that 2024 could be our best year so far. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal wellness, gym attendance, and lifestyle changes, which align most closely with the Health topic.

title: Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Department of Aging funding anticipated to remain flat, secretary says

 January 14, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: General Assembly 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Funding for the Maryland Department of Aging is expected to remain flat over the coming year, according to Maryland Secretary of Aging Carmel Roques.The secretary's comment came after Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) asked if there were concerns about the department's budget outcome during an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.
Concerns are not with losing funding, but with an anticipated inability to grow funding.
"The okay news is we don't anticipate our funding to be cut, but we're not going to have additional funding," Roques said. "And the way we're going to try and make that a better situation is the way we engage with, in a collaborative fashion, … our health and our housing agencies."
The majority of the department's funding comes from the federal government. State funding comprises a smaller portion of the dollars the department has to distribute.
In fiscal year 2024, Upper Shore Aging, the designated area agency on aging for Talbot, Caroline and Kent counties, received almost $782,000 from the state Department of Aging.
Queen Anne's County received about $333,000, and Cecil County received roughly $554,000.
MAC Inc., which is the area agency for Dorchester, Somerset, Wicomico and Worcester counties, received just over $1.3 million.
Knowing the funding was unlikely to grow, the department took steps early on to maximize the funding available to direct it more effectively at the local level, Roques said.
Those steps included working with stakeholder groups to look at three state programs — subsidized assisted living, congregate living and senior care money — to think about redesigning the long-term services and supports system in place from the state funding.
According to Roques, the work being done now will not "dramatically" change anything about fiscal year 2025, but it will in the coming years.
The Administration on Community Living, a federal agency that increases access to community supports for older adults and those with disabilities, also recently changed regulations to include guidance that will impact equity, she said.
Roques said the update to the regulations is "good news" for the rural elderly population, their families and care providers.
The state's rural communities have the highest populations of adults age 50 and older, according to data shared during her presentation.
The rural counties on the Eastern Shore have some of the highest numbers. In 2020, 50.8% of Talbot County's population was over age 50.
Maryland's overall population is rapidly growing older. In the next six years, the state will see more residents over 60 than under 18 — a first, Roques said.
"...What's being baked into that guidance is that rural communities need to be more heavily weighted in the formula for distribution of funds to recognize that their challenges are very different," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses funding for the Maryland Department of Aging, senior care programs, and health-related services, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award
author: TOM MCCALL
content:
Dorman receives Rotary's highest service award

 January 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TOM MCCALL | Section: Life 
 
 617
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons, was honored with Rotary's highest award, the J. Howard Anthony Community Service Award.For All Seasons is a behavioral health and rape crisis center. They are also the only agency in Talbot County doing this work in Spanish and English.
They bring in 20 to 25 new people a week for their new no wait five-days-a-week services. Because of COVID-19 they got skillful at telehealth and now offer services in all 24 jurisdictions in Maryland.
According to Beth Spurry, the president and owner of Wye Finanicial Trust and a mentor of Dorman's, in the past decade, Dorman has taken the organization from just 24 employees to over 100, most of whom are women.
"Because those nearly 100 employees that are meeting the mental health, the rape crisis needs of our community are the employees that are handling the toughest of the tough and doing it with a smile on their face. I have a smile on my face because of them. So thank you for this award," Dorman said.
A few days after the award was announced, she reflected.
"It is their largest award. I was first a part of Rotary when I first got out of college. It was called a group study exchange," Dorman said. "The group study is a professional exchange. I was given the opportunity to apply to be a part of a group that traveled to Japan. I was there for six weeks. I visited higher ed places in the Ibaraki Prefecture."
It is a specialized award. You cannot have been in Rotary for 10 years. You have to have lived and worked in the community in which you were serving for 10 years.
"It is a big deal for them. They have an opportunity to pick one person from the community. So I was blown away when he (Tom Hill) called me and told me that it was going to be me," Dorman said.
"I think it brings to light the importance of living through service in your community. That is the core of who I am, as far as servant leadership. I am as good as the team I have put together. We continue to serve in the community. It spurs a conversation about the importance of service no matter how big or small," Dorman said.
For All Seasons hosts many events throughout the year, like the backpack giveaway and Frosty's Holiday Village, that reach thousands of people.
"In all of that, the biggest piece for me is providing an example for my children, for women, for girls, for young people. My kids know I am busy and on my phone all the time, but they always know I am doing really important work. And that plants in them that they can be someone in the community," Dorman said.
She said she has a supportive team that helps her. Starting with her husband and her kids, Dave and Melinda Finley at Anchor Church on Goldsboro, Alice Ryan of the Women and Girls Fund, and Spurry.
"I was given a huge gift at the awards ceremony in having her (Spurry) be the person to present me the award. Beth has not only been a guiding light, but a pretty strong mentor. She will say, 'I think you can do better and here is why.' She has been an incredibly encouraging mentor," Dorman said.
She said this was a really important moment in her career.
"If all fell away tomorrow, this is the community that has supported me as I am supporting them. I will have a part of the Anthony family legacy forever and be able to say here is the impact I had in the community, which I call home," she said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a behavioral health and rape‑crisis center and its leader receiving a community service award, making the health sector the most relevant category.

title: Certificate of need approved for new regional medical center in Easton
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Certificate of need approved for new regional medical center in Easton

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 880
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Maryland Health Care Commission unanimously approved the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's certificate of need application on Thursday, marking a significant step forward in bringing the new regional medical center in Easton to reality.The approval came the day after Gov. Wes Moore released his fiscal year 2025 budget proposal with $100 million in funding for the hospital over four years.
The newly approved certificate of need authorizes UM Shore Regional Health to implement its regional medical center project with the approved spending outlined in its application.
However, the application was approved with several conditions imposed by the commission. These ask the health system to provide patients with information, upon inquiry or as required by law, concerning an estimate of out-of-pocket charges prior to arriving for surgery and to provide detailed updates on its progress toward obtaining state funding.
If UM Shore Regional Health fails to secure the in projected state funding by July 2027, the system must request a project change to amend its source of funding. The money in the governor's budget must be approved by the state legislature to clear that hurdle.
This isn't the first application the hospital system has submitted to the Maryland Health Care Commission.
A certificate of need application was filed in 2012 for a similar project on the same site. Though that application was docketed, it was withdrawn in mid-2018 because the project had changed significantly after the docketing.
A second similar certificate of need application was filed in September 2018, but the commission's review was deferred at the health system's request, according to the 2023 certificate of need application submitted by UM Shore Regional Health.
The estimated cost of the project is $539.5 million.
Improvements to the new medical center include all private rooms (a change from the predominantly semi-private rooms in the current hospital), heartbeat monitoring in all rooms, a dedicated 25-bed observation unit, three behavioral health holding rooms and larger operating rooms, according to Moira Lawson, the program manager for the commission's certificate of need division.
The six-story 325,000-square-foot, 147-bed hospital will replace the existing hospital on Washington Street in Easton, a majority of which was built between 1955 and 1975, according to Maryland Health Care Commission documents.
The new facility is slated to occupy just over 235 acres off of Longwoods Road near U.S. Route 50 in Easton, about 3.5 miles from the hospital's current location.
Easton Mayor Megan Cook said the approval of UM Shore Regional Health's certificate of need was "a significant step forward in our mission of getting a new, state-of-the-art, regional medical center in Easton."
"I'm grateful to Gov. Moore and his administration for their support in our journey in building a new facility that will serve our community for decades to come," she said in an email.
Cook also extended gratitude to UM Shore Regional Health President and CEO Ken Kozel and his team for their "tireless efforts" in moving the project forward.
"This has been a top priority for the residents of our town, and I know they'll be excited to hear this news," she said.
The Town of Easton is ready to help support the planning and construction of the new hospital, Cook added.
The governor's capital budget proposes allocating $20 million in funding every year for the next three fiscal years and a $30 million allocation in fiscal year 2028.
The proposed funding for the regional medical center adds on to the $10 million received in the state's fiscal year 2024 budget, which must be spent by the end of June.
Kozel called the news an "incredible step forward," thanking the governor, lieutenant governor and the "dedicated" delegation to the General Assembly.
"This commitment from the Moore-Miller Administration and the state of Maryland reflects a remarkable pledge to the future of rural health care and to the people of the Eastern Shore of Maryland," Kozel said in a news release Thursday. "Our patients and communities will benefit from this investment for generations, as will our team members who will have the opportunity to deliver world-class care in a modern facility."
Talbot County Council President Chuck Callahan also expressed gratitude to the governor for the funding allocation.
"I can't thank him enough," he said. "I personally talked to him several months ago and asked him to be beside us and work with us here on the Shore, and that's what he did — he looked out for us, and I can't thank him enough, and this council can't thank him enough, and the citizens of Talbot County (can't thank him enough)."
Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Talbot, Caroline, Dorchester, Wicomico) said the funding was a step in the right direction.
In December 2022, former Gov. Larry Hogan earmarked $100 million for the project in his fiscal year 2024 budget recommendation announcement — a number that wasn't quite reached when last year's budgeting process was completed.
The hospital system began engaging with the Hogan administration in early to mid-2022 and originally asked for $100 million, according to Trena Williamson, the regional director of communications and marketing for UM Shore Regional Health. That work continued with Moore's administration last January.
"It isn't (the) $100 million that's being requested; however, it is a pledge, and I think it's a good faith effort on behalf of the administration to move the project," Mautz said.
Late last year, hospital officials said they hope to begin construction in late spring 2024. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the approval of a certificate of need for a new regional medical center, detailing health‑care planning, funding, and services, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Plans for new Regional Medical Center in Easton advance with governor’s budget announcement
author: Staff Writer
content:
Plans for new Regional Medical Center in Easton advance with governor’s budget announcement

 January 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: General Assembly 
 
 244
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During his Fiscal Year 2025 budget announcement yesterday, Governor Wes Moore introduced a State budget that includes a significant funding commitment of $100 million in capital commitments for the construction of the new regional medical center in Easton."This commitment from the Moore-Miller Administration and the State of Maryland reflects a remarkable pledge to the future of rural health care and to the people of the Eastern Shore of Maryland," said Ken Kozel, UM SRH president and CEO. "Our patients and communities will benefit from this investment for generations, as will our team members who will have the opportunity to deliver world-class care in a modern facility.
"Today's news is an incredible step forward, and we offer our most sincere thanks to the governor, lieutenant governor and our dedicated delegation to the General Assembly."
The Regional Medical Center will bring a new standard of patient-centered care to the Eastern Shore, according to UM SRH.
The six-floor, 325,000 square foot, 147-bed hospital will replace the existing hospital in Easton. It will feature expanded services in recognized areas of medical expertise and health care needs on the Shore.
The new Regional Medical Center campus is slated to occupy 200-plus acres off Longwoods Road near the intersection of U.S. Route 50, adjacent to the Talbot County Community Center.
This more centralized location will provide greater visibility, easier and safer access for ambulance and helicopter transport as well as ample parking for patients, staff and visitors living in our mid-shore region.
