title: Use Leap Day's extra time to change your life for good
author: Robin Donovan Food Drink Life
content:
Use Leap Day's extra time to change your life for good

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Robin Donovan Food Drink Life | Section: Entertainment 
 
 1126
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Once every four years, we get a bonus day on February 29. Don't make the mistake of letting Leap Day pass you by. Learn how to use this rare extra time as a springboard to personal change, turning a single day's action into lifelong habits.The Leap Day mindset: Embracing the extra day
If you struggle with making time for yourself, set aside this day for self-growth activities. An extra 24 hours can make all the difference with the right mindset. By viewing Leap Day as a chance for a mini-reboot, you're setting the foundation for transformational change.
Taking opportunities to make changes builds new neural pathways, which helps protect cognitive function. Reflect on your goals, struggles and needs through purposeful activities like journaling, meditation or booking a session with a therapist. With how busy life gets, it can be a rare opportunity to get the time to sit with yourself and check in on how you're doing. That's all the reason to leverage Leap Day as a launchpad for personal development.
"If you don't take out time to focus on your own enrichment, sit with yourself and begin to tune into your inner voice, this can get harder and harder to do over time, " says Julia L. Pressman, LCSW.
Small leaps, big gains: Micro-changes with macro impact
The idea of change can be daunting, but it doesn't always have to be drastic. Start implementing small, manageable changes on Leap Day, like eating a healthy breakfast or taking a 15-minute walk after lunch.
Don't underestimate the power of micro-changes, as they can lead to significant, positive shifts in your life. By taking that brisk walk on Leap Day, you may find that it's something you enjoy and can easily incorporate into your routine. That one small change will slowly become a habit that promotes a healthier lifestyle.
"Over time, micro-changes increase our perception of what choices are available to us," Pressman says. "When we try to do things differently than we typically do them, we learn more about ourselves and what works for us."
Leap of faith: Trying something new
Have you ever saved a new recipe or fitness class, promising yourself that you'll get to it one day? As a wild card in the calendar year, there is no better day than Leap Day to step out of your comfort zone and finally try that thing you've been putting off.
Who knows, trying out that honey cake recipe might end up with you falling in love with baking and creating a side hustle. That's what happened to former U.S. national volleyball player, Tui Tuileta during the pandemic. Tuileta used his free time to bake cookies and post his creations on social media. It quickly picked up and led him to fulfill orders locally, baking 400 cookies weekly from his parents' oven. Attempting new things spices up your routine and can lead to unexpected opportunities — you never know if you don't try.
The joy of the moment: Celebrating the day
The rare occasion of having 366 days in the year calls for a celebration. Make this a special day by hosting a Leap Day-themed party. That way, you'll make special memories to last until the next Leap Year.
As part of the celebration, indulge in festive foods. Make it a potluck so your friends and families can share foods they love, filling your dinner table with a variety of options like party favorite samosas — a flaky Indian pastry with potato filling.
Connecting the dots: Building relationships
Leap Day offers 24 extra hours to spend with your loved ones. Take the time to write heartfelt letters expressing your appreciation for people in your life or plan a family cooking activity. Tanghulu, a traditional Chinese candied fruit street food, is an easy, delicious and fun snack to make with kids.
It's important to prioritize relationships as they are critical to personal development. They are a source of support during difficult times and help improve self-esteem and general well-being. Plus, a little appreciation goes a long way. Expressing gratitude releases oxytocin, the love hormone that strengthens the bond between two people.
Paying it forward: Kindness and community
Extend the spirit of Leap Day into the community by performing acts of kindness. Volunteer at a local food bank or spend the day decluttering your closet to donate items you've outgrown. Volunteering helps out the community and benefits your mental health by encouraging you to meet new people, increasing your social skills and boosting your self-confidence. Research, including a study by Western Connecticut State University, has shown that the more people volunteer, the happier they are.
A day for creativity: Unleashing your inner artist
Engaging in artistic pursuits comes with several therapeutic benefits that you may be unaware of. According to PhD psychologist Dr. Brenner, tapping into your creativity can reduce stress and anxiety and even boost your immune system. Dr. Brenner also explains that once you're in a creative flow, the brain releases large amounts of happy chemicals like dopamine, endorphins and serotonin.
Whether it's painting, writing or knitting, dedicate some time on Leap Day for these artistic pursuits you usually don't have time for. There's no pressure to create a masterpiece, just get started and let your creativity flow for your mental well-being.
Leap Day resolutions: Setting goals with a twist
You may have already set New Year's resolutions, but Leap Day resolutions are different. Given the rarity of a Leap year, it's an opportunity to create goals that are a bit more farfetched than your typical New Year's resolutions. Want to conquer your fears and go skydiving? Or, for a less extreme idea, why not challenge yourself to perform random acts of kindness every day? Setting these out-of-the-box goals will help you get out of a mundane routine and fully experience the joys of life.
It's one thing to set goals and another to execute them. Decide on a timeline for when you want to achieve each resolution and set actionable steps to make it happen. The best motivator is setting meaningful goals that will bring self-fulfillment.
The culmination: Making Leap Day last
End Leap Day on a high note by reflecting on how you spent this rare bonus day with intention and purpose. It's a unique opportunity to make a significant change in your routine or simply enjoy an extra day of life's pleasures, indulging in hobbies or activities you normally don't have time for. Keep the positive momentum going and use Leap Day as a springboard to leap forward into the year with renewed energy and purpose.
Robin Donovan is the author of more than 40 cookbooks, including the bestselling Campfire Cuisine, Ramen Obsession, and Ramen for Beginners. A food writer, recipe developer, and food photographer, she is the creator of the food blog All Ways Delicious, where she shares easy recipes for the best dishes from around the world. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on personal well‑being, mental health, and lifestyle changes, which aligns best with the Health topic, though it appears in the Entertainment section and mentions creative activities.

title: Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.
author: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 558
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Senators have rebuked CEOs of three major U.S.-based pharmaceutical companies for the high cost of prescription drugs in America."There is a lot of discussion in our nation about how divided our people are on many issues. That is absolutely true," said the panel's chairman, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont), "but on one of the most important issues facing our country, the American people… could not be more united, and that is the need to substantially lower the outrageous price of prescription drugs in this country."
Merck and Johnson & Johnson initially declined to testify at Thursday's hearing of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, prompting Sanders to announce a committee vote to subpoena the companies' CEOs. Both companies responded with letters accusing Sanders of targeting them for their lawsuits against the federal government over the price negotiation provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act.
Before the subpoena vote, the companies announced that they would agree to voluntarily testify. The witnesses included Joaquin Duato of Johnson & Johnson, Robert Davis of Merck, and Chris Boerner of Bristol Myers Squibb.
In his introduction, Sanders cited a recent poll published by the Kaiser Family Foundation showing that 82 percent of American adults say the cost of prescription drugs is unreasonable, while 73 percent believe that there is not enough government regulation limiting that cost.
According to a report published by the committee's majority staff before the hearing, several key treatments offered by Johnson & Johnson, Merck and BMS require U.S. patients to pay much more for drugs on an annual basis than those in other countries pay for the same drugs.
"Are the prices that you receive from countries like Canada or France — which look to me to be about one quarter of the price you get from the United States — … covering your costs?" Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Connecticut) asked.
Duato said that Johnson & Johnson is making a profit on selling treatments in those countries, and that the real difference between U.S. patients and those in other countries is that American patients get access to pharmaceutical therapies years before international patients.
He added that price caps on drugs are "not the way innovation is going to be fostered," echoing the stated reasoning in Janssen Pharmaceuticals' lawsuit against the Department of Health and Human Services and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
The lawsuit filed by Janssen, a Johnson & Johnson company, argues that "the U.S. innovation ecosystem to which Janssen contributes has two vital components" that are threatened by the Inflation Reduction Act's drug price negotiation program.
Janssen's lawyers said these components are the agreement between the federal government and drugmakers when the FDA approves new treatments, and "the operation of free-market forces to establish prices for medicines during and after their patent terms."
But senators questioned the companies' commitment to innovation, citing the findings of a recent study revealing that manufacturers of drugs chosen for Medicare negotiation spent more overall on stock buybacks and dividends than on research and development in 2022.
Sens. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) and Mitt Romney (R-Utah) reinforced the points made in the suit, suggesting that senators asking the CEOs what their companies are doing to lower the gap between costs and profits are out of step with the free-enterprise system.
"The last time I checked, when a buyer and seller negotiate for a price, that's capitalism," retorted Sen. Maggie Hassan, D-New Hampshire. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Senate hearings about high prescription drug costs and pharmaceutical company practices, which is primarily a health policy issue, though it also touches on business aspects of the pharma industry.

title: Rotary packages 30,000 meals to fight hunger
author: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com
content:
Rotary packages 30,000 meals to fight hunger

 February 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP dbishop@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 375
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Taking a swing in the fight to end world hunger, the Centreville Rotary sponsored a packaging of 30,000 dehydrated meals to feed people who are experiencing a hunger crisis. Sixty volunteers gathered Feb. 3 at the Centreville United Methodist Church to support the mission.Centreville Rotary President Matt Schiwy had participated previously with other Rotary clubs working with Rise Against Hunger and wanted the Centreville Rotary to sponsor an event.
A global organization, the mission of Rise Against Hunger is to end world hunger by the year 2030, and the organization believes that achieving the goal is possible.
Started in 1998 under the name Stop Hunger Now, its headquarters are in Raleigh, North Carolina. From there, the international hunger relief non-profit organization coordinates the packaging and distribution of food and other aid to people in developing nations.
The food and processing materials are not free for the sponsoring organization. Schiwy said, "We had to pay $4,000 for everything to be delivered here, and hauled away to be shipped to whatever area of the world the food is going to."
The set up began before 9 a.m. on Saturday. However, the actual packing process, using an assembly line of volunteers to package the food, didn't begin until 11 a.m. The total time packaging the 30,000 meals took just about two hours.
The foods are simple essentials — rice, soy, dehydrated vegetables with seasoning, all measured out by hand, and placed in a small plastic bag which was sealed. The bag has directions on it for using boiling water for cooking the contents, which makes enough for six meals per bag.
Each assembly line person had a specific role. It worked very efficiently. After sealing each bag, the bag was placed inside a box, along with at least 40 other bags, and then the box was sealed to be placed in the cargo truck and shipped to a large warehouse.
All Rotary International Clubs are service oriented. Each performs different services and activities that bring communities together, using people of all-ages. The volunteers who helped Saturday, ranged in ages from 16 to 80. Students from Gunston School, Queen Anne's County High School and Chesapeake College participated. Gunston School Headmaster John Lewis, and Chesapeake College President Cliff Coppersmith, were both among the volunteers. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community effort to package meals for hunger relief, addressing a public health issue (hunger). While schools and costs are mentioned, the primary focus is on combating hunger, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.
author: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service
content:
Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOS over the high cost of drugs in the U.S.

 February 10, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MATHEW J. SCHUMER Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 558
 Words 

 Read News Document

 WASHINGTON — Senators have rebuked CEOs of three major U.S.-based pharmaceutical companies for the high cost of prescription drugs in America."There is a lot of discussion in our nation about how divided our people are on many issues. That is absolutely true," said the panel's chairman, Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vermont), "but on one of the most important issues facing our country, the American people… could not be more united, and that is the need to substantially lower the outrageous price of prescription drugs in this country."
Merck and Johnson & Johnson initially declined to testify at Thursday's hearing of the Senate Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee, prompting Sanders to announce a committee vote to subpoena the companies' CEOs. Both companies responded with letters accusing Sanders of targeting them for their lawsuits against the federal government over the price negotiation provisions in the Inflation Reduction Act.
Before the subpoena vote, the companies announced that they would agree to voluntarily testify. The witnesses included Joaquin Duato of Johnson & Johnson, Robert Davis of Merck, and Chris Boerner of Bristol Myers Squibb.
In his introduction, Sanders cited a recent poll published by the Kaiser Family Foundation showing that 82 percent of American adults say the cost of prescription drugs is unreasonable, while 73 percent believe that there is not enough government regulation limiting that cost.
According to a report published by the committee's majority staff before the hearing, several key treatments offered by Johnson & Johnson, Merck and BMS require U.S. patients to pay much more for drugs on an annual basis than those in other countries pay for the same drugs.
"Are the prices that you receive from countries like Canada or France — which look to me to be about one quarter of the price you get from the United States — … covering your costs?" Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Connecticut) asked.
Duato said that Johnson & Johnson is making a profit on selling treatments in those countries, and that the real difference between U.S. patients and those in other countries is that American patients get access to pharmaceutical therapies years before international patients.
He added that price caps on drugs are "not the way innovation is going to be fostered," echoing the stated reasoning in Janssen Pharmaceuticals' lawsuit against the Department of Health and Human Services and Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
The lawsuit filed by Janssen, a Johnson & Johnson company, argues that "the U.S. innovation ecosystem to which Janssen contributes has two vital components" that are threatened by the Inflation Reduction Act's drug price negotiation program.
Janssen's lawyers said these components are the agreement between the federal government and drugmakers when the FDA approves new treatments, and "the operation of free-market forces to establish prices for medicines during and after their patent terms."
But senators questioned the companies' commitment to innovation, citing the findings of a recent study revealing that manufacturers of drugs chosen for Medicare negotiation spent more overall on stock buybacks and dividends than on research and development in 2022.
Sens. Rand Paul (R-Kentucky) and Mitt Romney (R-Utah) reinforced the points made in the suit, suggesting that senators asking the CEOs what their companies are doing to lower the gap between costs and profits are out of step with the free-enterprise system.
"The last time I checked, when a buyer and seller negotiate for a price, that's capitalism," retorted Sen. Maggie Hassan, D-New Hampshire. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Senate hearings about high prescription drug costs and pharmaceutical company practices, which is primarily a health policy issue, though it also touches on business aspects of the pharma industry.

title: Embracing the calm: New yoga studio coming to Shore
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Kent County News / Star Democrat
content:
Embracing the calm: New yoga studio coming to Shore

 February 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Kent County News / Star Democrat | Section: Entertainment 
 
 798
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Big things are happening at 932 Washington Avenue, Suite G in Chestertown. The soon-to-be new yoga studio, Slack Tide Yoga, is starting to take shape. Owner, Adriane Watson, excitedly shared construction on the interior began in February.With only minor modifications required — updating signage, flooring, paint, bathroom finishes, lighting and in-studio heat — Watson is using Second Wind Contracting to furnish the interior improvements. While that happens, she said, "I get to source the fun parts — scents, art, furniture and decor, all thoughtfully curated to create a serene environment that nods to the nearby waterways and landscapes. As you pass by in the coming weeks, you'll notice a bright green banner hanging in front of the location."
Slack Tide Yoga studio aims at helping each person, no matter their fitness level or needs.
Watson explains, "My highest priority is to create an environment where my members feel comfortable, above all else. Prospective students can expect a welcoming, judgment and stigma-free atmosphere. I believe in cultivating spaces that make practicing yoga approachable, attainable and welcoming for everyone — regardless of experience, body type, age, etc. My goal is to help students create embodied experiences that create opportunities for them to feel present and connected to themselves in a world that so frequently pressures us to disassociate, perform and hustle."
Watson, is well-known locally for teaching at TwoTen (Chestertown), Kent County YMCA and Fit Flock (Chestertown), and Soul Society Yoga (Kent Island). She is a 200-hour registered yoga teacher with 15 years of personal yoga practice. Watson explained, "I moved to Church Hill from Centreville in 2020, and quickly realized that commuting to Kent Island or Middletown for personal practice is not convenient, given the distance.
Chestertown's existing boutique wellness industry combined with robust attendance in my Chestertown classes and feedback from my students reinforced my intuition that people here would respond positively to a dedicated yoga studio that offered a consistent schedule of offerings. Aside from affording an excellent opportunity to develop physical wellness, a yoga studio can also foster a sense of community and serve as a safe haven wherein students can find respite from the rigorous demands of daily life — something I believe we all need. Sometimes, the difference between feeling well versus feeling unwell is simply having somewhere to go."
The name 'Slack Tide' has a special meaning that sets the tone for the yoga studio. Her website explains. "There's a moment sailors call slack tide, when the tide is neither coming in nor going out, but perfectly still. It's a moment frozen in time. When all is calm and peaceful. Much like the serene interval between tidal movements, yoga offers a space for stillness, where the ceaseless waves of daily challenges momentarily recede. Embracing the calm within, practitioners find themselves in a state of mental and physical equilibrium. Just as the slack tide is a pause before the next surge, yoga provides a pause in the rhythm of life, inviting practitioners to discover inner peace, balance, and strength before navigating the dynamic waters beyond the mat."
What can the public look forward to? Watson said, "While the class schedule is not yet finalized, I will offer a well-rounded schedule of classes, including vinyasa (otherwise known as flow — dynamic sequences with movement linked to breath), yin (a passive, mostly floor-based practice with principles of Traditional Chinese Medicine. Postures are held for 5-7 minutes with the goal of targeting deep connective tissues), gentle/slow flow (gradual progression between postures, incorporating more time for breathwork and meditation) and classes designed specifically for beginners that teach the foundational movements. In the future, I plan to offer chair yoga and a strength and balance class, both of which would be appropriate for beginners or anyone with physical limitations. I am exploring options to offer heated classes as well.
As an instructor, Watson likes to emphasize functional movement, and offers sequences that explore mobility while building strength at the end range of motion. "My classes always have great playlists, a light mood and a long savasana," she said. Additionally, they'll offer special workshops on posture and alignment, along with events like sound baths and collaborations with other wellness providers (think yoga + acupuncture, essential oils, etc). Watson said she welcomes anyone who is curious, or even hesitant, about beginning a yoga practice to stop by and have a chat so they can find the right class for them. She'll also offer private instruction for students who may want more individualized attention.
Although the opening date is not set yet, Slack Tide Yoga studio is predicted to open in early spring 2024. Stay tuned for more information on opening day and an open house by following the studio on Facebook at Slack Tide Yoga Studio, Instagram at @slacktideyoga studio or sign up for email updates at www.slacktideyoga.com. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the opening of a yoga studio, emphasizing physical wellness, fitness classes, and mental well‑being, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Eastern Shore Delegation hears about health care access expansion

 February 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 581
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Expanding access to health care on the Shore was a recurring topic at the Eastern Shore Delegation meeting Friday morning.During the meeting, which was held on Zoom, Mark T. Gladwin from the University System of Maryland spoke about a new program that would bring medical students to the Eastern Shore, and Sara Rich talked about the growth of the Choptank Community Health System.
Gladwin, who is dean of the University of Maryland School of Medicine and vice president for medical affairs at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, talked about the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal elective program.
Once in place, he said the program will have students spend their first two years in Baltimore, coming to the Eastern Shore to do rotations. For students' last two years, they will spend four months of each year learning and training on the Eastern Shore.
This program will address a need for more health care on the Shore, Gladwin said. The five counties in the state with the fewest primary care physicians per capita are all on the Eastern Shore.
"As we all know, there is a pressing need to enhance physician and medical provider services and hospital services for the Eastern Shore," he said.
This new program is a partnership between the University of Maryland, Baltimore, the University of Maryland School of Medicine and the University of Maryland Eastern Shore. Between the three partners, Gladwin said $300,000 has been invested to start the program.
He said a director, assistant director and administrative support staff have been hired. The estimated cost to support and build the program is about $2.2 million per year, Gladwin said.
"We put in a federal grant for the program," he said. "And we think it would be very helpful to get state support for this."
Gladwin said they are mainly seeking scholarship support for the program. He said they would like to be able to give out full scholarships to students in the program who agree to staying on the Eastern Shore to work.
"We think there's a lot of interest (from) our students in rural health care, in health equity," Gladwin said. "And we think this could be a signature program to attract future doctors."
Eastern Shore Delegation Chair Del. Chris Adams (R-Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) said he was appreciative of the efforts to get this program going.
"It is surely needed," he said of the program.
Also during the meeting on Friday, Choptank Community Health System CEO Sarah Rich talked about Choptank Community Health's expansions on the Shore.
Currently, the health system has seven health centers and 18 school-based health centers across Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
Rich said progress on the construction of its new center in Federalsburg is moving along "very well." The health system broke ground on this project in the early summer of 2023.
This new center will have five wings for medical, dental and behavioral health services. It will house a rural residency program in partnership with the University of Maryland School of Medicine and University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, as well as a dental residency program.
Rich also talked about Choptank Community Health's expansion into Kent County, which includes a health center in Chestertown and a school-based health center in Rock Hall.
Behavioral health in schools is another way the health system has expanded.
"We know that is a huge need," she said. "So we do have therapists now in Caroline and Talbot counties."
Rich said they plan to offer these services to students in Kent County and Queen Anne's County schools next. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses expanding health care access, a new medical student program, and health system growth on the Eastern Shore, making health the primary focus.

title: Health coalition raises issue with state regulations
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Health coalition raises issue with state regulations

 February 25, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 472
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — During an Eastern Shore Delegation meeting held Friday on Zoom, the Eastern Shore Behavioral Health Coalition expressed concern about new state regulations moving to a fee-for-service model and a proposed bill regarding telehealth services in schools.The Eastern Shore Behavioral Health Coalition gave a presentation about behavioral health issues and initiatives on the Eastern Shore. Tina Brown, director of Eastern Shore Crisis Response, said they currently serve eight of the nine counties on the Shore, and as of now, all services provided are funded by grant money.
For Brown, moving toward a fee-for-service model will be "devastating to our clients on the Shore and our program on the Shore."
The issue arises with the population on the Eastern Shore needing to be more significant to support those services in a fee-for-service system. Brown said that for the program to be successful, her team would need to see 10,515 cases every year and be able to bill for at least one hour.
That is three times the number that her team saw last year and is 59% of the population in Kent County.
Under the new regulations, the crisis team must cut their time working with families and children.
Currently, the mobile response stabilization service would work with families for about eight weeks. Under this new model, the team would be able to work with families for only two weeks.
"If we don't have that support, then I think what we're going to see people back in the emergency rooms or interactions with the criminal justice system," Brown said.
TELEHEALTH SERVICESAnother concern brought to the delegation was a proposed bill regarding telehealth services in schools.
Jessica Tuel from Caroline County's Local Addictions Authority said there is no way to ensure background checks on providers or to check qualifications for the services they would provide, as well as an inability to connect or communicate between outside telehealth providers and school staff.
"If the student sees an outside provider and is in an active crisis after the session, there is going to be no one there to support that child," Tuel said.
OTHER INITIATIVESIn addition to these concerns, the coalition brought up other initiatives. About $4 million has been allocated to assess the status of the Upper Shore Community Mental Health Center, and plans are underway for a crisis stabilization center there.
Adrienne Breidenstine, vice president of policy and communications for the Behavioral Health System in Baltimore, helps lead the fund Maryland 988 campaign that supports establishing a 988 trust fund through a cell phone fee of 25 cents to help fund crisis services on the Eastern Shore.
This 988 campaign will generate $15 to 20 million annually and can be used to support Maryland's network of non-aid helplines and related crisis services.
"This is the year to do it," Breidenstine said. "We urge that you support this legislation when it does come for a vote." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on behavioral health services, telehealth regulations, and crisis response funding, which are core health issues, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Safe Chain Solutions to settle alleged counterfeit HIV drug claims
author: Natalie Jones
content:
Safe Chain Solutions to settle alleged counterfeit HIV drug claims

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Natalie Jones | Section: Local News 
 
 754
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Over two years of civil litigation against Cambridge-based pharmaceutical distributor Safe Chain Solutions relating to its alleged implication in a counterfeit HIV drug scheme has reached a settlement, according to federal court documents.A consent judgment and permanent injunction filed Feb. 20 in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York is awaiting a signature from a federal judge, which will formally settle Gilead Sciences Inc's complex lawsuit against the local pharmaceutical distributor and its founders, brothers Charlie and Patrick Boyd.
Gilead is a biopharmaceutical company that develops and markets a variety of medications, including drugs that treat or prevent HIV.
The complaint, originally filed in 2021 and amended in 2022, alleged Safe Chain's involvement in the distribution of authentic-looking bottles of two of Gilead's HIV medications, Biktarvy and Descovy, to pharmacies across the country.
Gilead's deeper investigation into the alleged scheme revealed that some of the bottles contained completely different drugs not used to treat HIV. Some of the bottles reportedly contained quetiapine, or Seroquel XR — an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder, according to the amended complaint.
The complaint alleged that some of the counterfeit bottles purchased from Safe Chain, which were received by pharmacies and later reported to the pharmacies by customers, came with falsified pedigrees, or documentation, that claimed to trace the drugs back to an authentic source.
The consent judgment and permanent injunction will prohibit Safe Chain from selling any Gilead product in the United States, including a number of Gilead's HIV medications.
Under the terms of the agreement, Gilead will have the right to have an independent firm audit Safe Chain's purchase and sales records for all products bought and sold after the consent judgment is entered, according to the document.
The firm will not provide information to Gilead unless it relates to Gilead-branded products or non-compliance with the order.
Additionally, Safe Chain will be required to relinquish its rights to over $2.7 million in frozen assets, which includes over $1.9 million of Safe Chain's funds in an equitable trust account and money in the brothers' personal investment and life insurance accounts.
If a court finds that Safe Chain violated any terms of the consent judgment and injunction, the company would be required to pay Gilead 100 times the wholesale acquisition cost of the Gilead product sold, according to the document.
The wholesale acquisition cost for Biktarvy is over $3,000. Descovy is over $2,000.
Despite the lawsuit's allegations, Safe Chain believes that the drugs "were actually legitimate Gilead products that had been diverted into the stream of commerce," said August Matteis, an attorney for the the company.
In counterclaims against Gilead, Safe Chain alleged that Gilead's accusations were "false and defamatory" and that Gilead was "motivated by trying to destroy the secondary market for its drugs," he said.
According to Matteis, Safe Chain believes Gilead sued the company in "an attempt to cover up the fact that thousands of bottles of Gilead HIV drugs entered the stream of commerce due to poor oversight of Gilead's free drug access program in Florida."
"There has been no judicial ruling on Gilead's claims against Safe Chain or on Safe Chain's counterclaims against Gilead," he said. "Safe Chain agreed to settle this case to end the legal costs associated with this litigation and to get back to running its business."
Gilead's lawsuit was not the only documentation explaining concerns with Safe Chain.
A June 2023 warning letter issued by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration detailed the company's violations of the Drug Supply Chain Security Act. It followed the FDA's monthlong inspection of Safe Chain's Cambridge facility from April to May 2022.
Specifically, it called the company out for not having adequate verification systems required under law that "may have resulted in suspect product entering the supply chain" rather than being quarantined, according to the letter.
The letter also confirmed that Safe Chain purchased products from other drug wholesalers that were not authorized, failed to maintain records of suspect product investigations and failed to respond to notifications of illegitimate products.
The Feb. 20 injunction prohibiting Safe Chain from selling Gilead products ensures that Safe Chain "will never again be a source of counterfeit versions of our medicines," according to a Gilead spokesperson.
"This is the latest result of years of work reflecting our longstanding commitment to protect patients and the public from bad actors selling counterfeit and illicit versions of Gilead's medicines," the spokesperson said in an email. "This includes working closely with the FDA, FBI and prosecutors to dismantle this counterfeiting network, deter bad actors, and thwart illegal pharmaceutical distribution." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on counterfeit HIV medications, FDA warnings, and patient protection, which are primarily health-related issues, though they also involve public safety and business/legal aspects.

Board of Education president undergoes liver transplant

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 CAMBRIDGE — Dorchester County Board of Education President Mike Diaz is recovering from a liver transplant.At a Board of Education meeting Thursday, Diaz called into the meeting to thank everyone who had reached out with well wishes and prayers.
"My absence from this evening's meeting is due to the fact I'm currently in the University of Maryland Medical Center after undergoing a liver transplant last weekend," he said over the phone.

title: Many rural hospitals losing money, hundreds could close nationally; Medicare Advantage adds to challenges
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
Many rural hospitals losing money, hundreds could close nationally; Medicare Advantage adds to challenges

 February 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: National 
 
 1190
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Rural hospitals across the U.S. are struggling – with half operating in the red and 418 "vulnerable to closure."That is according to a new analysis by the Chartis Center for Rural Health.
Chicago-based Chartis looked at the financials and operating conditions at 2,115 hospitals in rural areas and small towns nationally.
The landscape is a cause for concern as pre-pandemic challenges conspire with new ones created by Medicare Advantage reimbursements.
The health consulting and research firm found 55% of independent rural hospitals and 42% of ones affiliated are suffering financial losses. Some of those hospitals and health care providers are struggling to pay vendors on time, while others are struggling to make payroll, said Michael Topchik, national leader for Chartis' rural health programs.
Alan Morgan, CEO of the National Rural Health Association, said rural hospitals and medical centers were facing tough times before the pandemic. They benefited from the big spending outlays during COVID.
Now, realities are sinking back in, Morgan said.
"It's a real concern," he said.
'OLDER, POORER, SICKER'
Rural hospitals and rural health care overall face structural and demographic challenges. "In general, rural Americans tend to be older, poorer and sicker," Topchik said.
Topchik said the current marketplace and national landscape for health care access and viable medical business models centers on private insurance and higher wealth levels.
"Any hospital that has a higher percentage of its communities that is employed and has commercial insurance is in a far better place," Topchik said.
That puts rural and small towns at disadvantage because they tend to serve communities with more households on Medicaid and Medicare than private insurance. "Poverty drives health outcomes," Topchik said.
Poverty rates are higher in rural areas (15.4%) than their metropolitan counterparts (11.9%), according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Rural poverty cuts across racial and demographic lines.
Several states with Republican governors and legislatures have also declined to or pulled back from Medicaid expansion to cover more lower-income households. That hasn't helped hospitals and other providers in rural and urban areas.
The new Chartis report found 89% of rural hospitals in Kansas are operating at a loss, the most of any state. In Wyoming and New York, 83% of rural hospitals are in the red, along 75% in Vermont and 74% in Alabama.
Since 2010, 167 rural hospitals have closed nationally or ditched inpatient services. Last year, 23 rural hospitals closed, according to Chartis.
MEDICARE ADVANTAGE
Medicare Advantage plans – which are offered by private insurers with extra benefits and services offered to seniors – are proving to be a major challenge for rural hospitals and providers.
Topchik puts it more bluntly.
"Medicare Advantage – it's a nail in the coffin," he said. "Medicare Advantage is a really, really sticky wicket."
Rural and smaller hospitals are struggling with adequate reimbursements for services provided under Medicare Advantage plans.
Enrollments in Advantage plans grew by 48% in rural areas of the U.S. between 2019 and 2023, according to Chartis. Marketing campaigns for those plans have increased in outlying regions and small towns.
"Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement, on average, is less than the cost of care. A significant, ongoing challenge has been commercial and Medicare Advantage insurance administrative barriers, including delayed responses from insurers and denials of authorization requests," said Lisa Goodman, vice president of communications for the Oregon Hospitals Association. "It is not unusual for a hospital to wait three days or longer to receive a response from a Medicare Advantage plan, and in many cases, those requests are denied. While Medicare and Medicaid do provide coverage to the vast majority of Oregonians, inadequate reimbursement and administrative burdens and challenges contribute to the financial headwinds rural hospitals face."
Goodman said rural hospitals in the Pacific Northwest and throughout the country "disproportionately rely on the predictability and stability of Medicare and Medicaid payments."
She said in 2022, Oregon hospitals had their worst financial year in three decades, with inflation and staffing shortages. She said labor expenses rose 26% from pre-COVID levels.
Topchik said some of that stems from those medical centers having smaller billing departments and patchwork reimbursements for Medicare Advantage services compared to set and uniform rates.
"They're not being reimbursed," he said. "Traditional Medicare was very predictable."
The Better Medicare Alliance – which represents Medicare Advantage providers – did not respond to interview requests regarding the Chartis report. The group – whose members include large insurance groups and health care providers – said 32 million Americans utilize Medicare Advantage plans.
On Feb. 15, the group said it wants rate adjustments for Medicare Part D services that better reflect growing demand and the costs of services.
"There has been a notable increase in seniors using health care services from their doctors and providers, which makes sense, given an increasingly aging population and the pent-up demand after the COVID-19 pandemic. At the same time, the Medicare Advantage program continues to adjust to significant policy changes, including the implementation of major changes to Part D. To ensure program stability for the 32 million beneficiaries who rely upon Medicare Advantage, adjustments should be made to appropriately account for these trends," said Mary Beth Donahue, president and CEO of Better Medicare Alliance, in a statement.
Medicare Advantage plans — which launched in 2003 and are now a $13 billion industry — enjoy substantial support on Capitol Hill.
In late January, 61 U.S. senators wrote CMS voicing support for advantage plans, pointing out that many of its beneficiaries are disabled or seniors making $20,000 per year or less.
Signatories of the letter include U.S. Sens. Steve Daines, R-Mont.; Ron Johnson, D-Wis.; Marco Rubio, R-Fla.; Rick Scott, R-Fla.; Jon Tester, D-Mont.; Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn.; Tom Carper, D-Del., and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y.
'IT'S NOT ROCKET SCIENCE'
At the beginning of 2023, a new federal hospital designation aimed to help financially struggling rural hospitals avoid closure — but will further change what kinds of services are available.
The Rural Emergency Hospital (REH) designation offers hospitals a potential $3.2 million annual payment from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Service if they convert into an emergency room and outpatient medical services model and ditch inpatient services.
Chartis projects close to 400 rural hospitals will convert to the REH model.
Morgan said there are misconceptions that rural hospital operators are to blame for their predicaments. Instead, he says the main factors are labor shortages, tough finances driven by patient loads with higher levels of Medicaid, Medicare and uninsured patients, and Medicare Advantage reimbursement challenges.
"This isn't rocket science," Morgan said.
But the answers aren't so easy, and some federal and marketplace actions add to rural health challenges.
The Chartis study found substantial numbers of rural hospitals have cut inpatient services, such as chemotherapy treatments or obstetrics.
Morgan said Medicare Advantage plans work well in suburban and urban hospital settings, where more patients overall are on private insurance, and bigger hospital systems are better equipped to work with MCA providers on reimbursements.
"Medicare Advantage is a great urban program," Morgan said, stressing the juxtaposition to its impact in rural regions.
On a broader level, Morgan said the American health care system will have to come to the realization that while private health care can work in metropolitan areas, it is a challenge in small towns and the hinterlands.
"At some point, we just have to treat rural hospitals and rural health care as a utility," Morgan said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the financial struggles and closure risk of rural hospitals, Medicare Advantage reimbursement issues, and broader health policy impacts, which are central to the Health topic. Business/Economy is a secondary fit due to the financial analysis, while Public Safety is less directly relevant.

title: County Council declares March Endometriosis Awareness Month
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
County Council declares March Endometriosis Awareness Month

 February 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 306
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Tuesday evening, the Talbot County Council declared March 2024 Endometriosis Awareness Month for the fourth year.Shannon Hannawald, founder of the Endo Warriors of the Eastern Shore and ambassador for the Endometriosis Association, presented her lifelong struggle with endometriosis to the council.
Hannawald described the effect that endometriosis, a disorder in which similar tissue to that which lines the uterus grows outside the uterus in places where it doesn't belong, has had on her life. She shared an experience she had with a doctor who downplayed the pain she was experiencing because of endometriosis.
"All I could think about was my nieces or some other younger generation, laying in that bed and being spoken to that way and not knowing how to advocate for themselves. And that made me really angry. So it is kind of my theme this year is just, please advocate for yourself," Hannawald said.
She highlighted the need for doctors to listen to and understand patients' experiences and for women to advocate for themselves regarding their healthcare.
OTHER ACTIONS
The County Council unanimously approved several other items, including:
Reappointing Jennifer Williams to the Police Accountability Board.Appointing Tanisha Shields, case manager for Tabot Caroline County from the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services, to the Local Drug and Alcohol Abuse Council.The council received a request from Critchlow Adkins Children's Center for a letter of support for their effort to secure a state bond initiative of $500,000 to expand their space. The council unanimously approved this request to provide a letter of support for Critchlow Adkins Children's Center's state bond funding request.
An update was given by Dr. Maria Maguire from the Board of Health. This update included introducing Brendan Cane as the new director of environmental health, providing data on cancer rates and priorities like reducing melanoma diagnoses and announcing new and expanded health department programs and services.

title: ‘It’s certainly over’ for aid-in-dying bill this year
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
‘It’s certainly over’ for aid-in-dying bill this year

 March 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 577
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Lawmakers have tabled a fiercely debated bill that would have granted terminally ill Maryland residents the right to end their lives, a setback to supporters who hoped it would finally pass this year.Senate President Bill Ferguson (D-Baltimore City) said in a press conference Friday that the measure had not won enough support among the 11 members of the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee to move forward this term. Ferguson indicated he was unwilling to bring the bill for a vote if it was likely to fail.
"For this year, it's certainly over," said Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee Chair Will Smith (D-Montgomery), noting the bill would have fallen one or two votes shy of passing his committee.
Although Democratic leaders — from Gov. Wes Moore to Ferguson and Smith — all previously expressed support for the bill, they said there would be no last-ditch efforts to change lawmakers' minds on an issue that is deeply sensitive for both supporters and opponents.
"I told every member of this committee that on issues like this, it's a vote of conscience," Smith said. "It's so personal. It's such a tough issue … In order to come to me and say, 'Hey, look, I'm expressing unreadiness, I cannot vote for this bill,' I would honor that."
This bill, known as the End-of-Life Option Act, sought to make Maryland the 12th jurisdiction to legalize medical aid in dying, which provides patients with incurable illnesses the option to die by self-administering lethal medication. Patients would have been eligible if they had less than six months to live, were of sound mind and made a series of oral and written requests.
As the Senate and House considered companion bills over the past few weeks, the issue became the subject of contentious debate and hours of testimony. Proponents said aid in dying was a matter of dignity and bodily autonomy, while opponents expressed religious, ethical and moral concerns.
The bill's failure elicited strong emotions from its supporters on Friday, many of whom have experienced years of setbacks on the issue.
"It's gut wrenching," said Sen. Ariana Kelly (D-Montgomery), a member of the Judicial Proceedings Committee and a bill co-sponsor. "The proponents of this bill have come before the legislature, year after year, explaining why it's necessary. I have a broad community of constituents back at home and friends and colleagues who I see in Annapolis who are gutted … People feel this very personally."
Among those who testified in support of the bill was Diane Kraus, a 59-year-old Baltimore woman living with metastatic breast cancer. She said she wanted to have the option of medical aid in dying in the event her condition became terminal.
"I'm really disappointed," Kraus said in a phone interview. "I don't want to have to move out of state in order to be able to use this."
But one opponent said the bill's demise was the right outcome.
"I'm actually very pleased," said Sen. Mike McKay (R-Allegany, Garrett, Washington). "I know that it's a very, very personal piece of legislation that affects each of us much differently than (Republicans) to (Democrats) or rural to suburban … There's just people (who) weren't comfortable moving forward."
While the bill has met its end for this session, lawmakers said they anticipate reintroducing aid-in-dying legislation in upcoming terms.
"This is one that in time, maybe things will change with more education and more discussion," Ferguson said. "And so it's best to just know that it's just not happening this year."
Angelique Gingras contributed reporting for this story. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a legislative bill on medical aid in dying, focusing on health policy and patient rights, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Advocating for endometriosis awareness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Advocating for endometriosis awareness

 March 3, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Local News 
 
 598
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For years, Shannon Hannawald has been a vocal advocate for what is seen as a "private disorder."Endometriosis is a disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that lines the uterus grows outside the uterus in places where it doesn't belong. Hannawald has made it her mission to spread awareness and create a community of support for people diagnosed with endometriosis.
Endometriosis affects 1 in 10 women and often begins during teenage years. Hannawald was one of these girls. At 15, she was experiencing severe menstrual cramping, which caused her to be in and out of hospitals.
She went years without receiving a diagnosis. Hannawald said that she felt isolated and got to the point where she started to believe it was all in her head and that she was "crazy." After years of having her pain go unvalidated, she attempted to take her own life.
"I was tired of fighting. I was tired of nobody listening to me," Hannawald said. "I started to wonder if maybe I was crazy. Maybe it was in my head because nobody would listen to me. Thankfully, my mom found me before anything happened and called the ambulance."
At the age of 20, she found a new doctor, who immediately recognized her symptoms, and after receiving laparoscopic surgery, she was confirmed to have severe stage 4 endometriosis.
Currently, the only way to diagnose endometriosis is through laparoscopy, a minor, minimally invasive surgical procedure that is done under general anesthesia.
According to a study by Yale, on average, women in the United States will suffer from symptoms of endometriosis for ten years before receiving a proper diagnosis. Hannawald said her pain was often assumed to be related to her menstrual cycle or in her head entirely.
Doubts about women's pain has been shown to affect treatment for a wide range of health issues, including heart problems, reproductive health, chronic illnesses, adolescent pain and physical pain.
Over the years, Hannawald has had a total of 16 surgeries related to her endometriosis. She says that endometriosis has affected every aspect of her life, from her fertility to her relationships with her family.
Her goal now is to ensure that no one goes through the same struggle she has.
Hannawald started the Endo Warriors of the Eastern Shore Facebook group during the pandemic. She created the page so that other women with endometriosis would see it and know they aren't alone.
Her group has grown and provided a community for education, awareness and support regarding endometriosis.
Hannawald joined the Endometriosis Association and has been recognized for raising awareness and securing proclamations from multiple towns and 16 counties on the Eastern Shore. She speaks to nurses and doctors so they can understand a patient's perspective.
For the last three years, she has worked to get municipal buildings like courthouses, town halls and police stations lit up in yellow for March to show community support in spreading awareness.
March 15 is "Yellow Day," a day meant to raise awareness about endometriosis. She motivates people to wear yellow and encourages county leaders to do the same.
Hannawald says she still deals with doctors who downplay her pain. It makes her angry, but she continues to advocate for women, particularly, she says, for her nieces and young girls whose pain is not taken seriously by medical professionals.
She says she hopes to build a better future for them, but until then, she encourages young women to advocate for their bodies.
"Don't settle for an answer. Don't let a doctor define who you are," Hannawald said. "You know your body better than anyone. And if you feel like there's something wrong, then you need to keep fighting." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on endometriosis, a medical condition, and the author's advocacy for awareness, diagnosis, and support, which aligns directly with health topics.

title: Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content:
Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone

 March 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 1188
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Jackson Taylor remembers when a peer passed out from an overdose across from his high school. He knows friends who have struggled with addiction. One has been in and out of rehab.Those experiences help explain why the Rockville High School senior now trains his peers on how to administer naloxone, a lifesaving medication that reverses opioid overdoses. They're why he carries naloxone at school and why he wants all districts to let their students do the same.
"It's just like a student having a heart attack," said Taylor, who runs a student task force on drug and opioid issues in Montgomery County. "It might be rare, but on the off chance it happens, you want to be able to save them and help them."
Currently, a disparate and ambiguous set of district-level policies has created confusion on the role students may play in preventing opioid deaths among their peers. But a bill before the Maryland General Assembly aims to provide a clear and uniform set of standards.
The measure, HB 1268, would explicitly authorize students across the state to possess and administer naloxone — also known by its brand name, Narcan — as adolescent opioid deaths surge and teens lobby for urgent solutions.
While the practice is already permitted for students in Montgomery County, others have gotten punished for carrying naloxone in school, according to the bill's sponsor, Del. Joe Vogel (D-Montgomery).
"We know that our student populations are uniquely vulnerable when it comes to (the opioid) issue," Vogel said. "And this (bill) is, to me, a common-sense step to say, 'Hey, you should not be punished for carrying naloxone with you in a school hallway, and you should not be punished for saving a classmate's life if they're overdosing.'"
At a hearing before the House Ways and Means Committee on Wednesday, Taylor, 18, was among those who testified in support of the measure. So, too, did Maryland's Special Secretary of Opioid Response, Emily Keller, an indication that the bill has the backing of Gov. Wes Moore's administration.
"Empowering people and giving them the tools necessary to help is a vital strategy, especially with young people," Keller said in her testimony. "Making naloxone accessible with every Marylander is one of our priorities because we know it's the number one life-saving tool."
The bill responds to an alarming national trend: Between 2018 and 2022, adolescent deaths from opioids quadrupled, according to an analysis by KFF.
The rise in overdoses has coincided with two factors, said Patricia Kapunan, the medical director for Montgomery County Public Schools. One is the use of social media to market pills without a prescription. The other is the rise of fentanyl, a potent synthetic opioid that is being mixed with illegal drugs, often unbeknownst to the user and with deadly effects.
In 2021, fentanyl was involved in nearly four times as many fatal overdoses among young people in Maryland as the next deadliest drug, cocaine, according to the state's Vital Statistics Administration.
"Suddenly, (fentanyl) is showing up everywhere, and suddenly one pill can kill," Kapunan said.
Implementation questionsIn response to the opioid crisis, lawmakers have mandated that school districts take preventive actions. The Start Talking Maryland Act of 2017 required public schools to teach kids about the dangers of opioids and have naloxone available on campuses. It also authorized nurses and other health and school personnel to administer the medication in overdose emergencies.
Most districts have not extended the same permission to students. In Cecil County, students are not necessarily punished for possessing naloxone, according to director of student and school safety John Roush. But "they would be talked to by their school administration about it and informed that we don't have a policy for (them) to carry that in schools," he said.
Roush thinks the bill is a good idea and may help save lives, though he anticipates challenges with implementation and logistics.
"We have over 15,000 kids in our system here," he said. "How do you get Narcan out? How do you get information out? How do you make them educated on the use? How do you make them aware? It seems like there would be a lot of time and details to be worked out in that regard."
While the bill requires schools to educate students about the benefits of naloxone, it does not specifically address one major logistical consideration: training kids on how to dispense the medication.
Available over the counter as a nasal spray, Narcan must be administered by tilting the person's head back and firmly pressing the plunger. Because the medication's effects are temporary and overdose symptoms may return, it is critical that the individual providing Narcan also call 911 and seek medical aid.
To the American Medical Association, the benefits of expanding naloxone access in schools still outweigh the risks. Following a debate on the issue, the group approved a resolution last year encouraging "states, communities and educational settings to remove barriers to students carrying safe and effective overdose reversal medications."
"Narcan saves people quickly, and lack of Narcan kills people quickly," said Kenneth Certa, an AMA delegate from the American Psychiatric Association, which co-sponsored the policy. "When somebody is turning blue and cold, you don't have much time. And to wait until a dose gets from another part of the building can be too late."
'Hugely empowering'In Montgomery County, which saw a 78% spike in youth overdoses from 2021 to 2022, a policy permitting students to carry naloxone took effect on May 1, 2023.
Kapunan, who crafted the measure, said students were never punished for possessing overdose-reversing medications and were already protected under good samaritan laws if they acted in an emergency. But teen advocates nonetheless pressed for a policy change that eliminated ambiguity and codified their right to intervene.
"Those levels of permission were really important to students," Kapunan said. "For me, it was a very small part of the regulation. For them, it was hugely empowering."
Kapunan says the policy does not mean schools are depending on kids to save lives. During the 2022-23 school year, naloxone was dispensed on school grounds in Montgomery County 18 times, almost always by nurses. Since the policy change, there have been no known instances of a student administering naloxone to a peer at school.
But to supporters, the measure remains an important preventive step, permitting those in closest proximity to an overdose to act without fear of repercussion.
"Students know before the teachers do, is the truth," Taylor said. "I'm a lot more likely to know, 'Hey, my friend has a pill in his bag that he's thinking about taking, and it could have a repercussion' than a teacher would know."
Vogel, who is running for the open U.S. congressional seat in Maryland's 6th District, said expanding policies like the one in Montgomery County has become a necessity. Six months ago, he met with student leaders who spoke to the urgency of the opioid crisis and their desire to help address it.
"A lot of them have taken matters into their own hands," Vogel said. "A number of them have stepped up and said, 'We want to get trained on how to administer naloxone, and we want to be able to carry naloxone.' … That's what this bill is in response to." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on opioid overdose deaths and the medical response (naloxone), which are core health issues, even though it discusses school policy and legislation.

title: 'None of us can get paid': Hospitals' technology, billing, claims systems crippled by UnitedHealth ransomware hack
author: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor
content:
'None of us can get paid': Hospitals' technology, billing, claims systems crippled by UnitedHealth ransomware hack

 March 15, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Mike Sunnucks APG National Enterprise Editor | Section: Business 
 
 655
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Vince Sica has never seen anything like it before.Sica is CEO of DeSoto Memorial Hospital in Arcadia, Florida.
The 49-bed rural medical center in southwest Florida is one of scores of hospitals throughout the state and country impacted by a ransomware cyberattack against the one of the largest providers of health care technology systems infrastructure.
"This really has never happened before," said Sica of the situation which has seen his hospital's billing, reimbursement, insurance verification and other technology systems down since Feb. 21.
That's when Change Healthcare — owned by U.S. health insurance giant UnitedHealth Group — notified hospitals and other medical providers that its systems had been hacked.
"So we turned it off," Sica said, adding similar actions were taken by a number of hospitals across the state and country.
Almost a month later, DeSoto Memorial, Sarasota Memorial and other hospitals' backbone technology systems are still affected.
"It's still not working," Sica said in Arcadia.
The cyber assault and resulting ransomware situation has crippled many hospitals' technology backbones and cash flows across the U.S.
"None of us can file electronic claims to get paid," Sica said. "This is a national event."
'EXTRAORDINARY REDUCTIONS IN CASH FLOW'Change Healthcare processes 15 billion hospital and medical transactions annually touching as many as 1 in 3 U.S. patients records, according to the company as well as industry groups.
American Hospital Association President and CEO Richard Pollack said in a March 13 letter to federal lawmakers that providers were seeing delays in authorizations for medical care because of the hack and "health systems and other providers are experiencing extraordinary reductions in cash flow, threatening their ability to make payroll and to acquire the medical supplies needed to provide care."
AHA also has been pressing UnitedHealth — which is the parent of mega-insurer UnitedHealthcare and had $370 billion in revenue and $22 billion in profits — on why the disruption has taken so long.
The Florida Hospital Association noted more than 100 hospitals statewide are impacted by the ransomware hack and the prolonged systems disruption.
That includes Tampa General Hospital and Sarasota Memorial Hospital — which has locations in Sarasota and Venice as well as urgent care and other medical centers throughout southwest Florida.
"We do not anticipate any disruptions or delays in care for hospitalized patients. The connectivity issues have impacted mostly back-office systems, and SMH is using alternate systems and downtime procedures to continue normal business operations until it is independently deemed safe to reconnect to UnitedHealth Group services," the Sarasota hospital said in a statement.
Sica said DeSoto Memorial Hospital hasn't let the technology situation impact patient care. He said switching over to a new system takes time, especially for smaller hospitals, and he doesn't have the billing and claims personnel to go back to more paper-based financial frameworks.
"You just don't change overnight," he said. "There's quite a bit of man hours involved."
INDUSTRY CONSOLIDATIONThe weekslong disruption — which has continued despite a potential $22 million ransomware payment by UnitedHealth — has extended across the country.
UnitedHealth and Change said pharmacy networks impacted by the hack were returning to service Wednesday, some electronic payment platforms were up Friday and other hospital-related technology systems including medical claims could start being tested Monday.
"We are committed to providing relief for people affected by this malicious attack on the U.S. health system," UnitedHealth Group CEO Andrew Witty said. "All of us at UnitedHealth Group feel a deep sense of responsibility for recovery and are working tirelessly to ensure that providers can care for their patients and run their practices, and that patients can get their medications. We're determined to make this right as fast as possible."
Federal agencies are launching investigations into the cyber attack — which Sica and other hospital executives worry could encourage more hackers.
UnitedHealth acquired Change in a $13 billion merger in 2022 that has been part of a major consolidation of the medical technology space.
"All those little processes at one time were separate companies," Sica said. "And over time United acquired all of them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a ransomware attack that crippled hospital billing and claims systems, directly affecting patient care and the healthcare industry's operations, making Health the most relevant category.

title: QA's Department of Health continues to make strides in community wellness
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QA's Department of Health continues to make strides in community wellness

 March 22, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 572
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Community engagement and prevention has been the focus as the county has now entered into a "quiet zone" with more normal functions returning after years of Covid-19, Dr. Joseph Ciotola, the Queen Anne's County health officer, reported to county commissioners.Presenting updates of the health department from the last six months at the March 12 meeting, Ciotola noted the health-related resources available for all ages throughout the county.
The health department's community wellness outreach programs, implemented three years ago, are going strong and adjusting to serve the needs of the community, he said. This program utilizes community nurses, and since July 2023, it has provided over 800 screenings for blood pressure, glucose, cholesterol and lifestyle at venues including senior centers and community fairs.
Ciotola stressed the ability to adjust to the changing needs of the community; A1C1 pre-screenings in particular being invaluable to community health.
"The push from a medical standpoint in our community is not to try and treat all of the diabetics — it's to prevent diabetes, especially the adult onset diabetic," he said.
The health department's infants and toddler program works in conjunction with the Board of Education, and since July 2023, the program has seen 83 referrals, serving over 100 individual children, according to Ciotola.
Another crucial program of the health department is the nurse-practitioner-run family planning clinic, in which all clients are at or below the poverty level, with 77 percent of those clients non-English speaking, he said.
Colorectal cancer screenings are also available to members of the public who may be under insured, Ciotola said.
County preventive programs also include children's sun safety events that provide UV color changing bracelets that demonstrate what sunlight can do to the skin. And for years the health department has supplied mouth guards to Queen Anne's and Kent Island high schools and the Lions Youth Football League. While Queen Anne's County Health Department does not perform direct oral or dental care, they do collaborate with Choptank Community Health and the Kent County Health Department, Ciotola noted.
The health department's smoking cessation program is pushing toward asthma awareness and how the smoking habits of household family members can affect attacks. And the department is ramping up programs addressing marijuana use and how to keep youth away from vaping.
Ciotola reminded the commissioners his department has led the state through its Mobile Integrated Community Health to provide home care right to the doorstep. Working with neighboring health centers, MICH addresses patient needs and services following hospital discharge.
Working in conjunction with state agencies, he reported, the mobile program has been able to significantly reduce unnecessary 911 calls and 30-day post hospital readmissions.
Playing an integral role in Public Health Emergency Preparedness, Ciotola told the commissioners, the health department recently had a tabletop exercise with local hospitals, emergency services and law enforcement to detail and plan for active incident response and recovery.
And in the county's continued fight against the opioid epidemic, since January, the health department has distributed 140 doses of Narcan throughout the community, he reported. Queen Anne's County is one of the few jurisdictions offering overdose boxes to businesses and public facilities.
Queen Anne's County has had nine reported cases of opioid overdose and thus far no deaths in 2024, he said.
Expired Narcan can be exchanged at the Department of Health at 206 N. Commerce Street in Centreville. Their officials continue to regularly engage in active public outreach, addressing addiction and spreading the word of the importance of Narcan, Ciotola said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article details the county health department's wellness programs, screenings, preventive services, and opioid response, making health the primary focus, with secondary relevance to public safety and local government.
