title: Recovery in Motion lights candles for victims of addiction
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Recovery in Motion lights candles for victims of addiction

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Saturday evening, over 50 people gathered at Fountain Park for Recovery in Motion's annual candle lighting event to recognize International Overdose Awareness Day, Aug. 31.This now annual event ushers in Recovery Month, a month where Kent Goes Purple raises awareness through purple banners and signs spread around the county.
Speakers that night encouraged attendees who suffer from addiction to find their higher power.
Steve Hafferman told the audience he struggled with drugs and alcohol most of his life. Even after he overdosed, he didn't change his ways. He was homeless until he found that higher power. He said he attended a church once where most of those gathered were former addicts.
"For the first time, I realized I wasn't alone," Hafferman said.
That support helped him, going through the steps to recovery, experiencing something dramatically different from his family background.
His new faith was life-altering, but then he got into a motorcycle accident by no fault of his own.
While riding in Easton on March 26 last year, a vehicle ran a light, affording him no time to stop. It was a devastating collision, his bike in shambles, his body mangled. Nineteen hours of surgery resulted in his leg being taken.
After the accident, he was angry at God for allowing this to happen.
"I lost my gratitude," Hafferman said, remembering being in pain every day.
Feeling powerless, like he couldn't even play with his kids, after five years of sobriety, he wanted to end his life. Drugs seemed to be the most effective method, he thought. He took enough cocaine to stop his heart, yet, miraculously it didn't.
He realized then God was not done with him.
Hafferman said, "Failure's not when you fall, it's when you stay down."
The next speaker, Recovery in Motion peer support Bobbie Sutton, didn't stay down either.
Her loving, musically talented older brother William Sutton IV died of a heroin overdose. Narcan, an effective medication used to treat overdoses, was not ready available as it is now, Sutton shared.
"He was always a such a good brother and great friend. He never treated me like a bratty sister," she reflected.
In 2009, his disappearance had sparked a year-long investigation to the dumping of his body, which furthered her pain, hurt and confusion.
The great loss and nature of the case threw Sutton into addiction as well, and after 11 years in that cycle, she wound up in prison for four years in Buncombe County, North Carolina.
With support from her mother, Phyllis Harrington, a nurse at the A.F. Whitsitt Center, and others, Sutton found her higher power in Christ and went through the steps. Subsequently, she followed in her mother's footsteps as well, helping people as a peer recovery specialist.
She said she's in awe of the change.
"I thought I would never be someone to carry titles and make a decent living. It's amazing that women come in and want to speak to me now for help," Sutton said.
"I've been able to come back home," she said, grateful of the people in her life, now three years clean.
While others lit candles, Sutton joined her mother beside a photograph of her brother, holding the flame close, remembering his personality, his talent and his band, The Big Hurt Band.
Director of Community Addiction Services Jennifer McCready and Peer Supervisor Brett Forrest thanked all those in attendance. McCready mentioned for anybody who needs help for opioids or stimulants, the center has crisis beds available.
She gestured to the table, where cards contain the phone number of dedicated peers committed 24/7 to answering questions.
And during this month, besides the purple shirts and signs, McCready noted, if you see laundry baskets placed in various sections throughout town, it's a part of the program "2 Sheets for Recovery," collecting twin-sized bedding for people going into recovery housing.
These are all events that correspond with the theme, Kent Goes Purple, an initiative of the Kent County Sheriff's Office and the Chestertown Rotary Club.
Sheriff Dennis Hickman was also in attendance, inviting the public to join them for their 5K Color Fun Run/Walk Sunday, Sept. 8.
He provided a message as well during this month of reflecting and commemorating those lost to addiction as well as enforcing prevention methods. "Law enforcement are partners in this journey to combat addiction. We're here to help in any way we can," he said.

title: Oxford event examine clean drinking water in Africa
author: Staff Writer

Oxford event examine clean drinking water in Africa

 September 5, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Entertainment

 Lifetime Wells International President and co-founder David Powell will speak at the Oxford Community Center on Thursday, Sept. 19 to highlight the group's efforts to help supply clean drinking water in Africa.The free Oxford speaker series event starts at 5:30 p.m.
Powell will talk about his Pennsylvania-based nonprofit group's work in Ghana and Tanzania.
"The mission of Lifetime Wells International is to improve the quality of life in the developing world by engaging with and empowering local partners to design, install and maintain safe and reliable drinking water systems," according to an announcement promoting event.
Approximately 1 in 10 people worldwide (or 703 million people) do not have direct access to clean drinking water. The result is women and girls walking an estimated 3.7 miles each day to fetch clean water for household and daily use, according to World Vision.

title: Talbot Goes Purple strives for prevention
author: Tom McCall
content:
Talbot Goes Purple strives for prevention

 September 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 624
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — September is Talbot Goes Purple month. You can see the front porches lit in purple to highlight concern about substance abuse disorder glowing through the night. This drug prevention program's main focus is prescription drugs laced with fentanyl.Knock-off prescription drugs like Adderall or Xanax that are purchased on the internet or other places can be laced with fentanyl, which makes them lethal.
"What people need to really understand is the Talbot Goes Purple is a prevention initiative. So we focus on kids 11 to 17. The goal is to delay or prevent onset of use," said Kelley Callaghan of Talbot Goes Purple. "Kids need to know that they are putting fentanyl in these pills. The DEA has a campaign 'one pill can kill.' Seven out of 10 pills that they seize have fentanyl in them," she said.
Kids can order these pills online, but they are not the same as what a doctor prescribes.
"If it is not coming from your doctor, there is a good chance that it is fake," she said.
Organizers of the effort hold events in September to increase awareness of the cause.
"We had our event this past weekend for Overdose Awareness Day and also for our kickoff on Saturday, fourth annual Festival of Hope. This is our eighth year. It was at Anchor Church. The food vendors sold out. So we provided 300 meals and 500 snow cones," Callaghan said.
There was a dunking booth with the sheriff and free face painting. There was a bounce house.
"We have all the fun stuff, but at 7:30 we have a memorial piece. Aug. 31 is International Overdose Awareness Day, so places across the globe come together to remember those we have lost. We put out luminaria bags and pictures," Callaghan said.
Linda Webb, director of Talbot County Department of Social Services, said, "Talbot County DSS is a supporter of the 'Talbot Goes Purple' substance use awareness and prevention initiative. Talbot Goes Purple promotes the safety and well-being in our community, and we're proud to partner in their mission."
Naloxone, or Narcan, is a nasal mist that counteracts opioids. Businesses, churches and civic organizations can have the medicine mounted to their wall. Around 60% of overdoses occur in the home, so Callaghan recommends getting the lighter sized antidote on your key chain.
"Many of our staff have been trained on the administration of Naloxone, an opioid overdose response medication. We are a Talbot Goes Purple Operation Save a Life partner and have overdose response kits installed in both our DSS office and the Children's Advocacy Center," Webb said.
Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble was focused on this epidemic early.
"2016 was when he started talking to me about Talbot Goes Purple. He was an early adopter of all things having to do with Narcan. He was getting it out to his deputies and going and giving talks about it," Callaghan said.
Law enforcement is trying to increase the face-to-face contact with people who want help.
"The good Samaritan law is really important. If someone overdoses, and this includes alcohol and minors, call 911 and don't leave. The law protects people from six misdemeanors including possession of alcohol or drugs," Callaghan said.
People up and down Talbot County are going purple.
Executive Director of the Oxford Community Center Liza Ledford lights up their boat.
"As a tradition we turn the lights on purple on that Yankee Peddler boat that we have out front. That is how we acknowledge our partnership and show the world that we care about the epidemic that is a crisis. We have a great return your unused medicine program at the police station down here," Ledford said.
Callaghan said that Talbot County is a leader for other states and counties that are starting their own Purple programs.
For more more information email talbotgoespurple@gmail.com 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on drug abuse prevention, fentanyl risks, naloxone distribution, and community health initiatives, which align most closely with the Health topic, though it also involves law enforcement and local agencies.

title: QAC Goes Purple kicks off Sept. against substance abuse
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Goes Purple kicks off Sept. against substance abuse

 September 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 468
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Encouraging the community to stand up against substance abuse in September, the annual "QAC Goes Purple" campaign kicked-off events during the Queen Anne's Soccer Club opening weekend Friday, September 6 at Church Hill Park and Saturday Sept. 7 at Route 18 Park.Both days brought in the community for Celebrating QA Soccer Club opening weekend, official QAC Goes Purple events kicked-off Sept. 6 at Church Hill Park and Sept. 7 at Route 18 Park inviting the community to stand up to substance abuse with giveaways, county resources and soccer fun.
Marking the beginning of a month-long opioid awareness initiative aimed at educating and mobilizing the community against substance abuse, Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition partnered with the QA Soccer Club for the first year.
Around a thousand kids from multiple youth soccer groups participated in the kick-off, according to Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition Chair Warren Wright.
As youth soccer groups registered for the season, participants received t-shirts and hot dogs from the Coalition and families partook in informational activities highlighting drug free living.
A shining light in the county coalition's efforts against substance abuse has been the Drug Free Student Ambassadors, Wright said.
A small but mighty group, the youth ambassadors work hard coming up with creative ideas for events and posters spreading awareness about living a drug free life to be rotated around the county, he said.
While the Coalition focuses on parents, the ambassadors take on leadership roles as they connect with peers and give younger students role models.
"Kids do so well talking to kids," he said.
Participating organizations welcoming a drug free September also included the Queen Anne's County Sheriff's Office, the Queen Anne's County Department of Health, Veteran and Military Support Alliance and Mid-Shore Behavioral Health.
As part of its Celebrate Recovery program, Kent Island Methodist Church presented a mobile trailer demonstrating a mock teen's bedroom, showcasing the creative means in which teens are able to hide drugs and paraphernalia.
Presenting its mobile trailer designed as a mock teen bedroom, the Celebrate Recovery program of the Kent Island Methodist Church highlighted red flags to be aware of and the deceptive avenues kids can try to hide drugs and paraphernalia right under parents' noses, including hallowed out seemingly everyday items.
Member Cathy Timms encouraged parents not to be afraid of violating their children's privacy by going into their room if there is suspected substance abuse, "It could save their life," she said.
"Knowledge and awareness is everything when it comes to addiction," Timms said.
"QAC Goes Purple" signifies a collaborative effort that transcends organizational boundaries and unites the community against substance abuse. By participating in this initiative, individuals can make a meaningful impact and contribute to a safer, more informed community
Business marques are encouraged to announce the drug free month as everyone puts in purple light bulbs and proclaims QAC drug-free this September. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community campaign to raise awareness about substance abuse, involving health departments and educational outreach, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Peer support specialists are on the front lines of the overdose crisis
author: Tom McCall
content:
Peer support specialists are on the front lines of the overdose crisis

 September 11, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 580
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GREENSBORO — Kristie Thompson, a peer support specialist, is on the front lines of the substance abuse disorder crisis in Caroline County. When someone calls for help, she is there with viable options.Thompson works for the Sante Group, a behavioral health service that focuses on crisis services and treatment. She is based out of the Caroline County Sheriff's Department and rotates through the county's municipalities, offering a certain number of hours a week in each when individuals struggling with drug addiction can come in seeking her services.
Thompson helps them navigate available recovery options.
"I get to reach people and show them the other side of recovery. It is possible to get through the storm. I can help them walk through it, if they are willing to do the work. People with addictions can be functioning again and can be put back in society. They can have something to offer the community," she said.
Thompson said the need for these services is growing in Caroline County.
"Last month I had five new people, and I had six follow-ups from the previous months," Thompson said.
There are lots of possible routes to recovery based on what the individual thinks they can do. There is outpatient, intensive outpatient and support groups. Mental health services can go hand-in-hand with recovery.
"I do an assessment of their experience level with substances. From there I figure out what the plan is for recovery. I want to rebuild them. Usually it is inpatient- that is what the safe station is for," Thompson said.
Caroline County Sheriff's Office Lt. Richard Baker said that there is a private room designated for this work.
"We would love to have more people to use it. They want to receive treatment. They want to receive help, and we are in partnership with the Sante Group. I use Narcan once or twice a month. We get a chance to save a life. If you feel you need help, come to this office. You are getting help and not getting arrested," said Baker.
There is still a stigma that needs to be broken around seeking help for addiction, the lieutenant said. There is a law called the good samaritan law, and it makes it safe to bring someone into a hospital or a police station who has overdosed. Under this law, neither the person experiencing the overdose nor the person who is bringing them in for help will be charged, Thompson said, but often people in the community do not know this.
"It saves lives. Before a lot of people were leaving their friends to die out of fear and stigma," she said. "Fentanyl is laced into a lot of drugs, and it is lethal."
There is another new drug stirring concern in the county, Tompson said.
Injectable intoxicant is xylazine, which veterinarians use to tranquilize horses, is often called "tranq" and causes open flesh sores.
"Their arms are decaying, and still they are injecting these drugs," Thompson said. "Right now they have been more opioid-related. Or stimulant and opioid. We have been encountering Xylazine mixed with fentanyl, and it has been dangerous."
"... The drugs are cheaper and more easily accessed than they were five years ago. The problem is getting worse and no one is talking about it," she said. "When people have money problems or are coping with the recession, the using behavior increases."
Thompson thinks there need to be more peers like herself to meet the needs of the county.
"Even if just one person is helped, that is good for me," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on peer support specialists addressing substance abuse and overdose crises, describing treatment options, mental health services, and community health initiatives, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Medical services chief arrested for stealing from ambulance boxes
author: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com
content:
Medical services chief arrested for stealing from ambulance boxes

 September 18, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jesse Yeatman jyeatman@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 705
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nearly two months after emergency medical personnel discovered medication boxes on multiple ambulances had been tampered with, a suspect was arrested.Thomas Patrick Raley, 39, who was the chief of Emergency Medical Services for St. Mary's County, was publicly identified as the suspect about a week after the county's emergency services department contacted the sheriff's office on July 16 and reported suspected tampering with a narcotics box in a local medic unit.
The sheriff's office announced last week that Raley was arrested on a warrant issued Sept. 11.
According to court documents, he was charged on Aug. 5 with 34 criminal counts, including two felonies — theft scheme of $1,500 to under $25,000 and second-degree burglary.
Misdemeanor charges included theft scheme of $100 to under $1,500; three counts of theft of $100 to less than $1,500; four counts of theft less than $100; two counts rogue and vagabond; 21 counts of CDS possession, not cannabis; and one count CDS possession of controlled paraphernalia for purposes of illegally administering a controlled dangerous substance.
St. Mary's sheriff's office detectives investigated and found the seal on a medic box containing vials of fentanyl had been broken and security packaging on fentanyl vials within the box had also been compromised, "leading to further investigation uncovering additional tampering incidents in multiple county medic units and EMS facilities," according the sheriff's office.
After his arrest last week, Raley was transported to the Detention and Rehabilitation Center in Leonardtown to await a bond hearing.
This is not the first time the Leonardtown man was accused of stealing medicine from ambulances.
Raley was charged with misdemeanor theft and property destruction offenses in court papers alleging he stole a vial of morphine and a vial of Midazolam on Dec. 17, 2018, at the Leonardtown Volunteer Rescue Squad.
A paramedic at the time, Raley was accused in charging papers of entering a secured medical storage unit and its locked medical container, and breaking the lock seal on the container, at the volunteer rescue squad's building on Lawrence Avenue in Leonardtown.
A sheriff's corporal stated at the time that the lock box's seal had been broken "and appeared to be glued back together," and that the officer was told a surveillance video showed Raley enter the building and the secured storage area, according to charging documents at the time.
After initial police questioning about the matter, the court papers state, Raley "called a few days later advising he took the medications and had a substance abuse issue."
Despite those 2018 charges, Raley had been appointed chief of Emergency Medical Services by the St. Mary's County commissioners late last year after serving as acting chief since the beginning of 2023.
The county commissioners entered an emergency meeting after the newest allegations of Raley came to light in July and unanimously moved "to appoint a new EMS captain position for the department of emergency services utilizing existing funding sources."
"It's very disappointing," Commissioner Mike Hewitt (R) said earlier this summer about the situation, including the commissioners hiring Raley to lead the department after the incident from a few years prior. "I was told that if you need [emergency services] to come to your house, this is the guy you want. Everybody has skeletons in their closet."
Raley's contract with St. Mary's County government was terminated on July 23.
"Ensuring the safety and well-being of our patients is our top priority," Jennifer Utz, emergency services department director, said. "We are evaluating and updating our internal processes and will continue working closely with the state medical director, jurisdictional medical director and local health officer to address this issue and protect our community."
In mid-August, she said in an interview with Southern Maryland News that emergency services were using the non-narcotic ketamine for pain management.
"Right now we still have the ability to treat pain, we just don't have the option for both right now," Utz said. "We will be restricted on how much [fentanyl] we can order."
A total of 18 patients received fentanyl around that time and emergency services staff is trying to contact each of them, and is reimbursing them for the emergency calls.
Questions regarding public health concerns about the case should be directed to the Department of Emergency Services. Representatives from the department contacted any individual whose care may have been impacted by this incident. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the theft of controlled medical substances by an EMS chief, the impact on patient care, and public health concerns, making Health the most relevant category, with Public Safety and Local Government as secondary matches.

title: Caroline Goes Purple 5K draws a colorful crowd
author: Tom McCall
content:
Caroline Goes Purple 5K draws a colorful crowd

 September 23, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 443
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PRESTON — A kaleidoscope of chalk was thrown into the air at the start of a 5K event to support the Caroline Goes Purple Saturday. Around 40 people started at the James Wright Memorial Park and either ran or walked the course.Catherine Bowrey is the chair of the Caroline Goes Purple Color Run.
"I am glad to see everyone out here having a good time. We have to get aware of the drug epidemic, which is a big thing. The stigma is terrible. So this way they can come out and get aware of what is going on in their communities," Bowrey said.
Caroline Goes Purple is organized by the Denton nonprofit Drug Free Caroline, a substance abuse disorder prevention and awareness program. Caroline Goes Purple is a community effort during the month of September to prevent drug use, heighten awareness and reduce the stigma around substance abuse disorder.
Jessica Tuel is the director of behavioral health for the Caroline County Health Department as well as the local addiction authority for Caroline County. She stood in front of a public health table filled with information, stress balls and pens.
"We do a lot of services in the schools both for substance use and mental health. We have full time clinicians in the north county schools and we have the Mobile Treatment Unit," Tuel said.
Her work is data-led.
"The statistics say that the earlier people start using, the longer and higher risk their use is later. Today we are bringing awareness to substance abuse in our county. We have a lot of vendors that are going to give education and services for those who need them. It is important to all these peers here, who are in a state of recovery. That is what all of the Caroline Goes Purple events are for," she said.
As a public health expert she wants both education and anti stigma to get across.
"Stigma is multifaceted. So it is stigma of the community against those who use. It is stigma of those that don't want treatment because they fear they will be judged. It is 'We don't have this problem in Caroline County,'" Tuel said.
The remedy to stigma is education and bringing statistics to the community, she said.
Angel Perez, the former Caroline Goes Purple Chair, was at this year's event as a volunteer.
"This event is important because we can raise awareness about substance abuse prevention and what is going on in our communities. We created this event last year to raise awareness in a fun way. Everybody can enjoy, but also get the information. We want to make them aware of what is going on in our community with substance abuse," Perez said. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: QAC announces Suicide Prevention Month
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC announces Suicide Prevention Month

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 350
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — Taking a stand against preventable loss of life and promoting available help in the community, the Queen Anne's County Commissioners, alongside For All Seasons, announced September as Suicide Prevention Month.At a Sept. 24 meeting, Susan Ahlstrom, a human trafficking regional navigator, and Carly Palmer, outreach coordinator of For All Seasons, presented information about the community behavioral health and crisis center's services, which include therapy, psychiatry, victim services, crisis support and education regardless of anyone's ability to pay.
With the proclamation, For All Seasons welcomed the community to learn more about outreach and education services, and how the impacts of suicide effect everyone.
Suicide prevention can be as simple as listening without judgement, checking in on people in your lives, and encouraging them to seek help when needed, according to Ahlstrom.
"Be open to having those uncomfortable conversations with people because it could save a life ultimately," Palmer said.
According to the proclamation, as reported by the Centers for Disease Control, 49,476 people in the United States, including 608 people in Maryland, died by suicide in 2022.
The proclamation also announced that "according to a 2021 Youth Risk Behavior Survey, conducted by local school systems with the CDC, in the 12 months prior to the 2021 survey, 15.4% of Queen Anne's County teens attempted suicide."
The economic toll of suicide on society is also immense, with suicides and suicide attempts costing the nation almost $7 billion per year in lifetime medical and work-loss costs, the proclamation stated.
For All Seasons is always looking to be more involved in schools and impact the lives of youth.
"I don't think there's any school, probably in the nation, that has enough social services or other support for the pressures and what our children are experiencing these days in terms of stress and social media effects," Ahlstrom said.
For All Seasons recently welcomed an office in Stevensville and rolled out an open-access program with no wait time, she said.
The community is encouraged to learn more about For All Seasons services, outreach and education programs including about suicide prevention and mental health.
More information about For All Seasons can be found at: forallseasonsinc.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Hearing loss requires patience
author: Staff Writer
content:
Hearing loss requires patience

 September 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 186
 Words 

 Read News Document

 For those of us who patiently suffer hearing loss, I share some confounding demons of our plight.Certainly not as constrictive as loss of sight, the condition carries baggage imperceptible to those who shout, repeat and sigh while shaking heads.
Alas, we are indeed a frustrating lot, and believe me when I say how much we own this knowledge, chronically offering undeserved apologetics for our affliction.
Often, oh ye shouters, the solution lies in enunciation, not volume, a remedy difficult to understand and implement I concede. Bless you who get it.
For some, this sensory loss includes disorientation, which often translates as some form of idiocy, especially in public, quotidian transactions.
Consider the poor checkout clerk who struggles for a pitying smile, always received, by the way, with grateful appreciation. Bless you who know good manners.
Parking lots, with their random fly by cellphone conversations and harmonics emanating from passing cars, will find us jerking our heads in mistaken response. Bless you who, in polite recognition, just chill.
Aware of the trouble and patience hearing loss requires, I bid your forbearance and am ever grateful. Bless you who good naturedly endure.
ELINOR CECIL
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses personal experiences and challenges related to hearing loss, which is a medical condition, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Dorchester County Health Department teams with artists to transform bathrooms
author: Staff Writer
content:
Dorchester County Health Department teams with artists to transform bathrooms

 September 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Local News 
 
 452
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — The Dorchester County Health Department successfully completed a transformative Bathroom Beautification Project in Dorchester County Public Schools.This initiative, spearheaded this summer by students from the Youth Action Council in partnership with local volunteer artists, aimed to create vibrant, inspiring and positive environments within school restrooms.
The health department and the youth council worked with the Dorchester Center for the Arts to connect with local artists who agreed to volunteer with the students to work on the project.
The Youth Action Council worked alongside talented volunteer artists to design and paint uplifting images, words and murals on the walls of school bathrooms. These artworks are not only aesthetically pleasing but also carry messages of hope, resilience and empowerment.
"We believe that a positive and welcoming school environment can significantly affect students' mental and emotional well-being," said Kirsten Hurley, a Youth Action Council adviser. "This project is a testament to the power of community collaboration and the importance of providing our youth with opportunities to contribute meaningfully to their surroundings."
"Having the opportunity to prepare and collaborate with the Youth Action Council group in partnership with Dorchester County Health Department and DCA was such a wonderful way to continue the artistic support of our community's ongoing beautification needs," artist Miriam Moran said. "Being proactive in the mission of investing in and understanding the importance of encouraging our youth in these educational environments spaces is very critical to helping our youth unite, help and develop their confidence, their compassion, their mental wellbeing care with positive affirmations but most of all taking the time to show them by action example.
"I'm grateful to be one of the artists that was able to participate in the bathroom beautification collaboration not just because of the creativity purpose but because the very school that I chose to help bring this bathroom beautification project to life has played a big positive impact of my very own children's educational journey," she said. "I'm truly proud to be a part of this amazing project and very proud to have collaborated with our amazing youth council members and mentors who are taking action and making a difference daily."
Other participating artists were Robert Gladney and Cheryl Daringer of Wednesday Morning Artists and Griselda Jiménez.
The murals feature a variety of themes focused on bright and cheerful colors and images and positive affirmations for the age group. By integrating art into these everyday spaces, the Dorchester County Health Department and its partners hope to inspire students, boost their self-esteem and create a sense of belonging within the school community.
Artwork was completed this summer in one boys and one girls bathroom in several elementary schools. The Youth Action Council hopes to tackle the middle and high schools next summer. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a project led by the Dorchester County Health Department to improve student mental and emotional well‑being through bathroom beautification, making health the primary focus, with secondary relevance to arts and education.

title: Queen Anne's welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Queen Anne's welcomes Secretary of Overdose Response

 October 2, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 474
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Queen Anne's County welcomed Maryland's Special Secretary of Overdose Response Emily Keller for a tour of county programs and departments dedicated to erasing stigma and taking a stand against substance abuse September 25.Beginning at the Queen Anne's County Department of Health in Centreville, the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Services presented its focus on outreach, education and prevention programs.
Showcasing each journey to recovery was unique, but there were local travelers along the way, department Peer Support services offer one-on-one counseling, referral programs, outreach, and lending an empathic ear, Peer Supervisor Brook Todd said.
Providing resources for the community is a crucial aspect of preventing overdose deaths and just over the summer the department of health distributed 600 kits of Narcan to be available throughout the community, she said.
Over 100 One Boxes were also donated to businesses around the community, these kits contain CPR supplies, Narcan, gloves and everything needed in the event of an overdose.
A central focus of the Department of Health Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services is erasing the stigma connotated with overdose.
"No place is hidden, it can happen anywhere," Angulo Potts, peer recovery specialist said.
Housing and career opportunities are essential aspects of recovering from the disease of addiction and preventing relapse and the Department of Health requested assistance in streamlining the process to bring a recovery house to the county where there currently is none.
Keller noted the Maryland Office of Overdose Response is currently making it a priority to establish safe quality recovery houses and recommended collaboration with the county government.
More information about the Queen Anne's County Health Department's Alcohol and Drug Abuse Prevention Services can be found at https://www.dontlabelus.org.
At the Queen Anne's County Board of Education building, Keller heard about the activities and programs initiated by the QAC Drug Free Student Ambassadors, leading the way in youth advocacy.
Led by Julie Kille, opioid education and prevention coordinator, the Ambassador program puts students in role model positions to educate their peers on taking a stand against substance abuse and living naturally high.
With QAC Goes Purple, the Ambassadors work diligently with leadership opportunities and creative activities to spread awareness throughout the county with poster contests, collaborative community events and team-building exercises.
The Ambassadors recently won first place in the national Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration competition for their escape room sharing the dangers of pills with peers.
More information about QAC Goes Purple can be found at www.qacgoespurple.org.
Other stops on Keller's visit included the County Chamber of Commerce in Chester and the Opioid Awareness Park in Stevensville.
Throughout her visit Keller reiterated that recovery was possible and Queen Anne's County represented a prominent dedication to addressing overdose awareness for all ages in the community.
"It is great to hear what is going on. It is a hopeful time in Maryland," she said.
More information about Maryland's response to overdose and opioid awareness can be found at: https://stopoverdose.maryland.gov. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on overdose response, drug abuse prevention, and health department initiatives, which are primarily health‑related topics, with secondary relevance to public safety, education programs, and county government involvement.

title: New rural health initiative by University of Maryland seeks to fill medical gap on Eastern Shore
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
New rural health initiative by University of Maryland seeks to fill medical gap on Eastern Shore

 October 17, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 526
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Medical student Tahreem Riaz said her interest in rural healthcare was established due to the rural community she grew up in Punjab, Pakistan.Riaz is one of six students who has been chosen for the University of Maryland School of Medicine's new rural health initiative to address the physician shortage on the Eastern Shore.
Rural areas in Maryland have notoriously been medically underserved, according to the federal Health Resource and Services Administration. Students like Riaz are taking initiative to address these disparities and help close the medical disparity through the Rural Health Equity and Access Longitudinal Elective.
The students will be provided didactic and mentoring sessions as well as research and clinical experiences on the Eastern Shore.
Leah Millstein, the program director and associate professor of medicine, said there's a real challenge for the population of the Eastern Shore in finding and accessing exemplary healthcare.
"There's a shortage in primary care doctors as well as specialties, and we often have students who are interested in rural medical care in their futures, but their exposure to it during medical school is limited," Millstein said. "So this program seeks to fill those gaps, to really give the students an in depth exposure to rural health care, and give them the building blocks that allow them to feel like they'll be successful serving as physicians in those communities when they're done with their training."
Riaz said her initial circumstances in Punjab made her realize the importance of one-to-one connection with patients and their medical providers.
"I personally faced the challenges of not discussing quality healthcare due (to a) shortage of physicians," Riaz said. "Individuals of my village have to go to far off places to get necessary healthcare."
The program is designed to train and place incoming medical students in Eastern Shore healthcare practices. About $1.4 million has been secured in state funding and from the University of Maryland, Baltimore; University of Maryland Eastern Shore; the Rural Maryland Council and many donors.
Millstein said three of the six students accepted into the program were awarded full-tuition scholarships with a commitment to working on the Eastern Shore for four years after completing residency training. The long-term goal is to support 10 students interested in rural health in this elective program each year.
Ken Kozel, president and CEO of University of Maryland Shore Regional Health, said this program will help draw new providers to the Eastern Shore.
"Strengthening our provider workforce is a top priority at UM SRH, and programs like R-HEALE will help us attract providers who want to practice in rural communities," Kozel said. "We greatly appreciate our partnership with the School of Medicine toward enhancing access across the Shore."
For Riaz, she is happy for the opportunity to focus on improving rural areas and assisting caring for the people in rural areas.
"With this program, I'll be able to be involved in research projects that are deeply focused on improving population and community health, and also to deeply understand the social, economic or cultural factors that are rooted in the disparities of such communities," she said. "I think this comprehensive training through our field will allow me to deliver more compassionate and patient centered care in the future." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a university‑run rural health initiative aimed at addressing physician shortages and improving community health, making the primary focus health rather than education or economic aspects.

title: ‘Long-held promise’: Shore Regional Health breaks ground on hospital project in Easton
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
‘Long-held promise’: Shore Regional Health breaks ground on hospital project in Easton

 October 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 605
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Local officials and stakeholders joined together at the Talbot County Community Center on Monday afternoon to celebrate the groundbreaking of a long-awaited regional medical center, complete with a visit from Gov. Wes Moore (D).The University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's project is estimated to cost around $550 million. Moore said on Monday that since he was inaugurated, the state has committed $100 million toward the hospital.
Before breaking out the shovels, Moore spoke to hundreds of attendees on what the hospital will achieve for rural Marylanders in need of improved healthcare access.
"At a time when most things are leaning away from rural health, in Maryland, we're leaning in," Moore said. "We're showing that you cannot have a growing and a thriving state if every part of the state is not seen and heard and recognized in that growth."
Moore, Rep. Andy Harris (R-Md.) and other politicians emphasized the importance of bringing high quality healthcare to the Mid-Shore. The medical center is expected to attract doctors and other healthcare professionals to Easton's workforce, a point Moore hammered home Monday afternoon.
Mohan Suntha, president and CEO of the University of Maryland Medical System, thanked many partners for their commitments to the often-stalled project that has been discussed for more than a decade.
"We are delivering on a long-held promise," Suntha said. "And the future is so bright for the Mid-Shore, for the medical system and the state of Maryland."
Shore Regional Health first applied for a certificate of need to relocate its Easton hospital on Sept. 7, 2012. Industry changes, fiscal concerns and shifting project plans delayed the timeline.
This January, the Maryland Health Care Commission finally approved the certificate of need application.
Following Monday's welcome celebration, Moore told reporters he noticed the project was stalling when he began his term. He said it became a "priority" for his administration to remove "the barriers and the regulatory red tape."
"It's too long that we've had people on the Eastern Shore who have been left behind," he said.
The hospital will be built on around 230 acres just north of the Easton Airport and across from the Talbot County Community Center. It is replacing the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center that is located downtown at 219 S Washington St.
Site preparation construction is currently underway, with the bulk of construction beginning in the spring of 2025. The medical center is expected to be completed in the summer of 2028.
The campus will include a 325,000-square-foot, six-level main tower, complete with 122 licensed beds, seven operating rooms and a helipad. An adjacent building for offices and outpatient services will be 60,000 square feet.
The new hospital will serve as the primary inpatient hospital for Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. Sen. Johnny Mautz (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) called it a "transformative" addition for the Eastern Shore.
"I plan to spend the rest of my life here. I think my children plan to spend the rest of their life here," Mautz said. "And one critical factor is are we going to be able to get healthcare. I think with this new hospital, we're going to get it."
Moore echoed Mautz's sentiments after Monday's celebration, adding that he is confident the medical center will attract quality doctors to the Eastern Shore and benefit residents for the foreseeable future.
"It's fundamentally unfair that if a person needs to see a specialist, that they somehow have to cross the bridge in order to do it," Moore said. "It's not fair.
"And if you want to be able to recruit the top talent, you have to make sure that you have a world-class facility. And that's exactly what this investment is going to bring." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the groundbreaking of a new regional hospital, discussing healthcare access, funding, and medical services, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: 'Breaking Bread' discussion focus on suicide prevention
author: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com
content:
'Breaking Bread' discussion focus on suicide prevention

 October 29, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Michael Reid mreid@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 752
 Words 

 Read News Document

 A well-respected lieutenant colonel who was part of the U.S. Navy's Seal team, a local military veteran, emergency responders, law enforcement personnel and many others put their lives on the line every day to help others.But sometimes, they themselves are the ones who need help as suicide has gripped members of the military and first responders.
The Robert Irvine Foundation on Oct. 17 at Three Oaks in Lexington Park hosted "Breaking Bread with Heroes" to discuss various ways of helping those in need.
"If you've been in combat, if you've been in law enforcement and you come across a live shooter situation, if you're a first responder and you're running into a burning building, you're vulnerable," Robert Irvine Foundation Development & Impact Vice President Robert Yarnall said. "It takes courage, but you're very vulnerable because you don't know what you're going to experience. It takes courage to admit we need help."
Yarnall said the key is opening lines of communication.
"How often do you say to someone, 'Hey, how are you doing?' then [they answer] 'Pretty good,' then you move on?" he asked. "[A colleague told me] just ask the [expletive] question. A lot of times you might be surprised at the answer you get."
A news release said the event "is an important and meaningful moment to honor the experiences of veterans and their families by joining together, talking, listening and understanding."
"It's always going to be something that we just have to confront and make sure we're invested in," said Del. Brian Crosby (D-St. Mary's), who served 10 years in the U.S. Army, five of them active, and was deployed three times. "We just need to make a little bit of a difference every day and try to get somebody to the next day."
According to www.wefacethefight.org, more than 120,000 veterans have taken their own lives since 2001, and more than half of those did not have a known mental illness. Also, suicide is the second-leading cause of death among post 9/11 veterans, and the suicide rate for male veterans between the ages of 18-34 has nearly doubled since 2006.
Yarnall said one of the reasons for the high numbers — he added since 2001, more veterans have died by suicide than were killed in combat during the Iraq and Afghanistan wars — is accessibility to weapons.
"Weapons are 90% lethal ... so you don't get another chance," he said. "We all talk about how we know how to operate a weapon safely. Yes, we do but when we go into crisis mode are we thinking about the safe operation of a weapon? No, you're not thinking rational in that 5- to 10-minute time period."
Another is the stigma associated with asking for help.
"If you are suffering from some sort of depression or mental health issue or suicidal thoughts, to come forward there's a stigma associated with that and I think people fear that, 'I might lose my clearance, I won't be able to do the job I want to do,' or other reprisals," U.S. Navy Capt. Matt Farr said. "[They think] it's going to somehow negatively impact their career because a military career is everything; it's how you support your family and it's serving your country, so you don't want to put that on the line."
Farr, who lives in Leonardtown, experienced a recent loss when his Leonardtown neighbor, a military veteran, took his own life earlier this month.
The issue also exists with first responders.
"I've seen tragedy just about any way, shape or form you can imagine," said Kim Davidson, who was an EMS in St. Mary's for 48 years and one of the county's original 10 medics who started the Advanced Life Support system. "I've seen terrible things and I've seen how people react to them. It's not just, 'Oh, well put a Band-Aid on it.' It's a lot more than a Band-Aid and it goes a lot deeper than a Band-Aid can."
Davidson said there is a fine line when offering assistance.
"There is that wonder of how far can I go and how far can I push myself onto somebody else before they really turn?" he said. "I know when it's time for me to shut up and just sit there and just be company for you, and if you want me to speak I'll speak."
"We need to make sure people understand they have a support network out there," Crosby said, "and if they don't have one to help them find one because organizations like this provide them."
For more information, go to wefacethefight.org or robertirvinefoundation.org or www.militaryonesource.mil.
Twitter: @MichaelSoMdNews 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on suicide prevention, mental health challenges, and support resources for veterans and first responders, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Channel Marker adds 6 transitional living beds in Caroline County
author: Tom McCall
content:
Channel Marker adds 6 transitional living beds in Caroline County

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 447
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Channel Marker had an open house at 2451 Willow Pond Road to show off its new six-bedroom house designed to safely accommodate people who suffer from mental illness.This is the organization's eighth such house across Dorchester, Caroline and Talbot counties. They named it Willow Pond House.
Cathy Cassell, CEO of Channel Marker, said, "Today we are opening up our eighth residential group home. It will occupy six clients and one staff. It is a part of an expansion project that the state put into play, 40 residential rehabilitation beds across the state. We applied for six and got six."
The plan is to bring clients in around December.
"All the people referred to us have to have a serious and persistent mental health diagnosis. Referrals go through Mid-Shore Behavioral Health," Cassell said.
She described this as an affordable solution for some of her clients who are on fixed incomes. It offers an economical way for these people to have independent living. One of the Willow Pond's goals is to keep these clients out of higher level of care facilities like hospitals.
The house is very light, with oak floors, and there are a few dedicated hang-out spaces. One had big bean bags in it and a flat screen TV.
One innovation the house has is machines that distribute medications to the clients right in their bedrooms. This reduces mistakes and helps keep everyone in optimal health. It is like a vending machine.
The house has a van to help take clients get to their appointments.
"All their meals are communal. They live like a family. They take turns cooking dinner with staff," Cassell said.
The average stay is two to four years, and Cassell looks at this as transitional housing. Both men and women are welcome to be clients. The goal is teach clients skills to return to independent living.
Erin Hoxter is the adult services director of Channel Marker. She leads the Caroline County program. There are 12 other beds already in the county.
"We want them to learn how to cook and keep up with their ADLs (activities of daily living) like showering and toileting. The clients here are expected to do all of those things independently. When they do transition out they have learned these skills and can be successful in these areas," Hoxter said.
One big emphasis for Channel Marker is getting to know their neighbors and letting them know that this is safe.
"We try to do all the precautions we can. For example we have security systems all over this house," Cassell said.
Although the state helped provide funding, Channel Marker is in an active capital campaign to provide for the construction and maintenance of this house. Donations can go to channelmarker.org. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a new transitional living facility for individuals with serious mental health diagnoses, focusing on health services, medication management, and community-based care, making Health the most appropriate category.

title: Pumpkins — great for growing, decorating and eating
author: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking
content:
Pumpkins — great for growing, decorating and eating

 October 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARIE SAVAGE Country Cooking | Section: Food 
 
 1271
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Surprisingly, the pumpkin is very healthy for you. They are low in fat, calories and sodium. Pumpkins are high in fiber and an excellent source of vitamin A, vitamin B, potassium, protein and iron. When we begin to whip up those delicious recipes is when the sugars and calories creep into the picture.We never grew pumpkins on our farm, but many other local farms did, so we got them from those farms. Mom went through the entire process of cutting up the pumpkin, cleaning out the seeds, chopping it into chunks to boil in the large pot.
But she also had cans of pumpkin in the closet to be used. She only cooked one or two pumpkins just to have some fresh pumpkin for certain recipes.
I confess, I never cooked a pumpkin; Libby sells all the canned pumpkin I need.
However, I do buy pumpkins from the local farmers to decorate outside. They make the most beautiful classic farm displays with some mums.
Today we explore some pumpkin recipes. I include a few of my collection of recipes including my favorite pumpkin pie and a good homemade crust recipe to start.
FOOL PROOF PIE CRUST4 cup flour, 1 3/4 cup shortening, 2 tsp salt, 1 tbsp sugar, 1 egg, 1 tbsp vinegar, 1/2 cup water.
Mix flour with shortening, salt and sugar. Set aside. Beat together egg, vinegar and water. Beat well and then begin sprinkling the dry and wet ingredients together. Turn ingredients together with a fork. Chill 15 minutes or longer in the refrigerator before working into pie crust. Remove from the refrigerator and break into portions. Work the dough on a floured surface until smooth and proceed to roll out into the appropriate size crust you need.
PUMPKIN PIE2 cup pumpkin, 5 tbsp flour, 1/2 cup white sugar, 3/4 cup brown sugar, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp nutmeg, 1/2 tsp pumpkin pie spices, 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 3 cup milk, egg whites.
Mix pumpkin, flour, white sugar, brown sugar, salt, nutmeg, pumpkin pie spices and cinnamon. Add milk. Beat egg whites and fold into the mixture last. Pour into an unbaked pie shell and bake in a preheated 450-degree oven for the first 15 minutes, then 350 degrees until toothpick inserted comes out clean, maybe 20 to 25 minutes.
OLD FASHIONED PUMPKIN BREAD3 1/2 cup flour, 2 tsp baking powder, 1 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp salt, 1/2 tsp baking soda, 1/2 tsp allspice, 2 2/3 cup sugar, 1 cup oil, 4 eggs, 1/3 cup water, 2 cup cooked pumpkin.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Combine flour, baking powder, cinnamon, salt, baking soda and allspice in a large bowl. In a separate bowl, beat 2 2/3 cup sugar, 1 cup oil, 4 eggs, and 1/3 cup water. Beat in 2 cups of cooked pumpkin until smooth. Mix the dry and wet ingredients together, stirring until well blended. Pour into two greased loaf pans and bake in a 350-degree oven for 45 to 50 minutes. Cool ten minutes before serving.
PUMPKIN LOAF CAKE4 tsp baking soda, 1 tsp salt, 4 tsp ground cloves, 2 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp nutmeg, 5 cup flour, 4 cup sugar, 1 cup oil, 2 eggs, 3 1/2 cup pumpkin, 2 cup chopped walnuts, 2 cup raisins, 1 cup candied fruit.
Makes about four nice loaves that freeze well and make nice gifts. Preheat the oven to 350 degrees. Sift together baking soda, salt, cloves, cinnamon and nutmeg. Stir this into flour. In another bowl cream sugar, oil and eggs until smooth and add pumpkin. Add the flour mixture to the pumpkin mixture and then fold in chopped walnuts, raisins and candied fruit. Mix well, pour into four greased loaf pans and bake for 1 hour plus 10 or 15 minutes according to your oven. Insert pick or straw and it should come out clean.
PUMPKIN SOUP1 (4-pound) pumpkin (kabocha squash is best if you can find at a local farmers market), 2 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil plus more for drizzling, 1 medium yellow onion (chopped), 1 tsp sea salt plus more for sprinkling, 3 garlic cloves (chopped), 1 tsp grated fresh ginger, 1 tsp ground cumin, ½ tsp ground coriander, ½ tsp turmeric, ½ tsp ground cardamom, 1 (14-ounce) can coconut milk, 2½ cups vegetable broth, 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar, freshly ground black pepper.
Preheat the oven to 400 degrees and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Cut the pumpkin in half and scoop out the seeds. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with salt and pepper. Place cut side down on the baking sheet. Roast for 40 to 60 minutes, or until very soft. When cool to the touch, peel away the skin and measure 4½ packed cups of the flesh. Heat the 2 tablespoons of oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium heat. Add the onion, salt, and several grinds of pepper and sauté until soft, 5 to 8 minutes. Add the garlic, ginger, cumin, coriander, turmeric, and cardamom and stir for 30 seconds, or until the spices are aromatic. Add the cooked squash, coconut milk, and broth and stir to combine. Simmer for 20 minutes, then stir in the vinegar. Transfer to a blender, working in batches if necessary. Blend until smooth. Kabocha squash can vary in water content, so if your soup is too thick, add up to 1½ cups water (½ cup at a time) to reach your desired consistency. Season to taste. Pour into bowls and garnish with additional coconut milk, fresh black pepper, and microgreens, if desired.
BROWN SUGAR PUMPKIN SEEDS2 cup raw pumpkin seeds fresh or from a bag, 1/4 cup dark brown sugar, 2 tbsp unsalted butter (melted), 2 tsp pumpkin pie spice, pinch of kosher salt.
Preheat the oven to 300 degrees. Place the pumpkin seeds in a colander and rinse away all the pulp and stringy stuff. Spread the seeds out on a rimmed baking sheet and roast until dried out, 30 to 45 minutes. Toss the pumpkin seeds with the sugar, butter, pumpkin pie spice and salt in a medium bowl until evenly coated. Return the seeds to the baking sheet, spread them out and roast until dry, about 35 minutes. Let cool, then break up into pieces before serving.
PUMPKIN QUESO1 2-to-3-pound sugar pumpkin, 8 ounces dried chorizo (diced), 1 jalapeno pepper (chopped), 1 4-ounce can chopped green chiles, 1/2 tsp ground cumin, 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper, 3 tbsp all-purpose flour, 1 1/2 cup low-sodium chicken broth, 2 cup shredded mozzarella or Oaxaca cheese, 1 cup shredded monterey jack cheese, chopped fresh cilantro for topping.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees. Slice off the top 1 1/2 inches of the pumpkin and discard. Scoop out the seeds and stringy pulp. Heat the chorizo in a medium pot over medium-high heat until the fat begins to render, about 5 minutes. Add the jalapeno, green chiles, cumin and cayenne and cook, stirring, until the jalapeno softens, about 2 minutes. Stir in the flour and cook, stirring, until the flour is slightly toasted, about 2 minutes. Add the chicken broth and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium and stir in the cheeses. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the cheese melts and the mixture is creamy, about 3 more minutes. Place the pumpkin in a small baking dish and fill the pumpkin with the cheese mixture. Add 1 inch of boiling water to the baking dish. Cover loosely with foil and bake until the pumpkin is tender, about 1 hour, 20 minutes. Remove the foil and continue baking until the cheese is golden and bubbly, 20 to 25 more minutes. Let cool for 5 to 10 minutes. Sprinkle with cilantro and serve with tortilla chips. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on pumpkin nutrition, health benefits, and detailed cooking recipes, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: YMCA welcomes community to health expo
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
YMCA welcomes community to health expo

 October 31, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 370
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — On Oct. 17, health agencies, partners, businesses, nonprofits and community organizations attended the Kent County Family YMCA for the annual Health and Wellness Expo.Pickleball players and basketball hoopers were momentarily replaced with health vendors. Tables were set up in the gymnasium, where attendees could get information for health wellness; anything from house gutter protection to cochlear ear implant options.
"This expo is dedicated to fostering partnerships among local organizations that provide valuable services and education on essential health and wellness topics," said Gale Drenning president of HomePorts, a partner of the event.
This year, Acme Pharmacy provided flu and COVID vaccines.
At the next table over, the new Health Educator at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Chestertown, Sandy Wilson-Hypes demonstrated CPR practices on a mannequin, inviting guests to try it out.
Teenager, Nate Perogoy was up for the challenge, exercising chest compressions to the tune "Staying Alive," a perfect tempo at 100/120 compressions per minute.
In addition to the vendors, classes were provided.
In "Unlock the Secrets of Ancient Nutrition," Bill Schindler author, internationally-known chef and founder of Eastern Shore Food Lab, instructed how to get the most nutrients from food and sustain your health amid a worldview of unhealthy practices.
Lt. Sean Maloney of the Kent County Sheriff's Office gave his presentation: "Don't Be A Victim! The Latest Scams, Schemes, and Frauds." He said threats come from everywhere: computer hackers, romance scams, fake scanners at ATMs and stores, dumpster diving and mail.
He pointed out victims can be anybody, but especially retirees with disposable income.
Gloria Carter offered a dance-based cardio class, available Mondays and Wednesdays at the YMCA.
Throughout the afternoon, while people went from table to table, they were treated to the musical talents of River Voices from Chester River Chorale directed by Stephanie LaMotte.
Outside, under a blue sky and moderate weather, food was provided by Happy Chicken and Lockbriar Farms. Patrons enjoyed squash soup, pumpkin ice cream and fresh-pressed apple cider.
The expo was well-attended, with over 300 programs handed out, said a volunteer.
Throughout the years the expo had many homes, but for the past three years the YMCA has been proud to host it.
Executive Director of the YMCA Erica Osterhout and her staff expressed excitement welcoming the expo each year. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community health and wellness expo featuring health screenings, vaccines, CPR training, nutrition classes, and health education, making Health the most fitting primary topic.

title: One year in, Centreville Y nears 7,000 members
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat
content:
One year in, Centreville Y nears 7,000 members

 November 1, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 497
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — The Centreville YMCA opened in October 2023. A year later, according to the local Executive Director Brian Byrnes and Membership Director Laura Feller, it has grown to 6,692 members.According to Mid-Shore YMCA Director Robbie Gill, that doesn't count the 535 Active Aging Center members (who are 55 and older) or those "people engaged in our free chronic disease programs; Rock Steady Boxing for Parkinsons, LiveStrong Cancer Survivor Program, Enhanced Fitness, and the dozens of our partnerships that are using the Y for programs.
"The Centreville Y is serving over 10,000 people," he said.
Gill, who was part of the planning for the new, much larger Centreville location more than a decade ago, added, "It's exciting seeing the Queen Anne's County Family YMCA/Active Aging Center making a positive impact in the lives of over 10,000 community members."
Gill said he couldn't be more proud of the Y staff team, volunteers and the work of the Active Aging Center staff and volunteers.
One of the main goals of the Y is to make everyone feel like family.
Since the beginning in Centreville, there has been a partnership between the Y and the Queen Anne's County Department of Community Services, Department of Aging, sponsoring the Active Agency Center within the Y building. The Active Aging Center is for all people 55 and over. Registration and participation is free.
Within the Active Aging Center, there is a wide and growing variety of free services for seniors. Monday through Friday, lunch is served, with a donation of $6.30 asked for those ages 55-59. For those 60 and over, a donation of $3 is asked.
One regular participant in the daily luncheons is Arden Weiss, 85, of Queen Anne. Weiss said, "This is the healthiest food I've eaten in my entire life." Weiss comes to exercise each morning and enjoy the food with others each weekday.
The meals are catered by a contracted group. They provide the same service at the three county senior centers — Kent Island, Grasonville and Sudlersville each weekday.
Bethany Brennan is the Active Aging Center manager. She said, "While the manager organizes some of the activities, we encourage members to start their own groups or clubs too. It doesn't have to be overwhelming — it could be as simple as a card-playing group that meets on a specific day or a history club for those who share that interest. In the coming year, members can look forward to seeing some familiar events along with a variety of new ones."
Ed Kaczmarczyk, 65, was elected this past year as president of the Site Council at the Active Aging Center in Centreville. Kaczmarczyk said, "We meet monthly to discuss how the existing programs are going, and to make recommendations for changes and/or to organize different activities our seniors want to do." All Active Aging Center members are welcome to attend the Site Council meetings.
The Active Aging Center at the Y only exists at one other Y in the Mid-Shore area, located in St. Michaels in Talbot County. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the YMCA's community health and wellness programs, senior services, and chronic disease initiatives, making Health the most fitting category, with Sports and Local Government as secondary considerations.

title: Maryland enshrines abortion rights in its constitution
author: Marissa Yelenik Capital News Service
content:
Maryland enshrines abortion rights in its constitution

 November 6, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Marissa Yelenik Capital News Service | Section: Local News 
 
 632
 Words 

 Read News Document

 COLLEGE PARK — Maryland voted to approve a referendum affirming the right to reproductive freedom on Tuesday, making what was already state law a constitutional right.The referendum, which appeared as Question 1 on voters' ballots, states that all people have "the fundamental right to reproductive freedom, including but not limited to the ability to make and effectuate decisions to prevent, continue, or end one's own pregnancy."
The crowd at Angela Alsobrooks' election night watch party erupted in cheers when news arrived that Maryland's Question 1 passed with solid support.
"I think it's important for it to have been codified, and I'm here for women's rights," said A.C. Edwards, 34, of Baltimore, who was at the party.
However, critics fear the broad language will allow lawmakers to apply unrelated concepts to the amendment, including gender-affirming surgeries, and widen the access minors have to abortions without parental consent.
Existing state law requires parental notification of minors prior to an abortion, but does not require their consent. Parental notification can be subverted in cases of abuse, if the minor is believed to be mature enough to give informed consent, or if the notification would not be in their best interest.
The amendment follows a nationwide focus on reproductive rights after the overturning of Roe v. Wade. Nine other states placed abortion-related constitutional amendments on their 2024 ballots.
The 2022 decision caused many voters to feel unprotected and fearful for their bodily autonomy. While state law already protected reproductive rights, voters raised concerns that laws could be repealed with changing leadership.
The Maryland General Assembly is able to repeal state law through legislative action, but constitutional amendments may only be passed following three-fifths passage in the General Assembly and a majority approval of state voters.
Max Freeman, a high school senior from Bethesda, Md., has worked with the Angela Alsobrooks campaign since March and attended the Alsobrooks watch party.
"I do think it's important to codify [abortion rights], to enshrine it into the constitution, because it's such an important issue for so many people," said Freeman. "It's really affected a lot of women these past few years … so we just want everybody to feel safe."
On the way to cast their votes, both supporters and opponents told Capital News Service that Question 1 was at the forefront of their minds.
Lorie Morey, 54, of Middletown, Md., said she voted for former President Donald Trump and other Republicans on the ballot Tuesday.
However, Morey said she thinks the decision to get an abortion is up to the individual.
"I don't think anybody should tell a person what they can and can't do with their body," Morey said. "I don't think the government should have any say. I don't think the state should have any say."
Kathryn Harrington, a volunteer for the Montgomery County Republican Party, said she spent several hours outside the Summit Hall Elementary School polling station in Gaithersburg, Md., educating voters on Republican candidates and their platforms.
This election cycle, she said, she has been particularly worried about Maryland's abortion referendum.
"This ballot question is a little nefarious because it would allow a child to go get abortions without any parental involvement," Harrington said.
She worries that this referendum will allow sex traffickers to take advantage of young people.
"I stop and think about a 16-year-old who could be a victim of sex trafficking, get pregnant, get an abortion, get pregnant, get an abortion," Harrington said. "This amendment is pretty clear. [There is] no age, no limitation … I'm a mom with three kids and that scares me."
The Associated Press called the race not long after polls closed on Tuesday night. Other states showed a mix of results, with the Florida amendment to legalize abortion failing while the New York and Colorado amendments to enshrine abortion rights into their constitutions succeeded.
Sofia Appolonio, Katharine Wilson and Mennatalla Ibrahim contributed to this story.
