llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a state constitutional amendment protecting reproductive freedom, directly relating to abortion rights and women's health issues.

title: Blake Blackston Post 77 brings vets together
author: Tom McCall
content:
Blake Blackston Post 77 brings vets together

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: News 
 
 674
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Around a table in the Blake Blackston American Legion Post 77, five veterans of various histories talked about what brings them all together.The scars of war are sometimes obvious and sometimes hard to see, they said.
"We have been through situations where we have lost friends and lost part of ourselves. If you don't talk about your experience, you will never know someone else's. You never know what you have to say is going to help him out," said retired Chief Master Sergeant from the United States Air Force Victor Middleton. He served for 30 years in two combat wars.
Providing support to fellow veterans is about "family more than just camaraderie," Middleton said. It's been part of the VFW post's mission since its inception.
"The history of Blake Blackston Post 77 is named after two missing in action veterans that never came back. There names were Nelson Black from Unionville and John Blackston from Trappe. The original post was on The Hill. For 40 or 50 years this place has been packed," Staff Sergeant William E. Griffin said. Griffin is the commander of the post.
Since, post members said, the VFW has served as a place where not only history is honored, but so are the struggles and issues that affect veterans today.
Griffin said, "We can't forget about the thousands and thousands of veterans here who are homeless. They didn't get the help that I got, or maybe they just don't know where to go.
"The American Legion is here to help these veterans out — those that suffer from PTSD, those that don't know how to retrieve their benefits. This is our job to support them. There are too many homeless veterans and their families who don't have it as good as we do here."
Army Staff Sergeant Noreen Wilson did eight years of active duty in the Army. She is the adjutant at Post 77, and remembers how veterans were treated when she was younger.
"I remember Vietnam Veterans being pushed to the side, and that bothers me," she said. "People ignored them and didn't do much for them when they came home. If it wasn't for the American Legion, they wouldn't be taken care of as much as they are now."
Through tears, Middleton recounted losing friends, being wiped out by loss and having the resolve to keep going.
"Friends in Vietnam and Thailand. There are lot of things that happened in Thailand that had to do with the Vietnam War. When I do funeral services for our Legionaires, I can't help but cry. I have been the historian, chaplain, commander- first and vice. Of all of them, I have enjoyed the chaplain the most. My feeling is when we go, we deserve to go with dignity," Middleton said.
They are in this together.
But not all the bonding the happens at the VFW is over shared hardship, the five veterans said. Most look back fondly on their time of service.
"We got a chance to see the world and see people all over the world. I bet I know someone in every state. The military changed my life, made me a better person," said Michael Waller, who served three years in the Army and is the finance officer at Post 77.
Kirk Henson, who is on the board of American Legion Post 77, said being in the military put him ahead of his high school class who were looking for jobs.
"By the time I got out, I had seen a whole lot more that the people I would have graduated with. I had my high school diploma and boom, boom, boom, I got to see the world — Germany, Greece, and Fort Raleigh, Kansas," Henson said.
Wilson said, "It is a whole different thing versus being in the regular civilian world. You just have this camaraderie. You look out for each other."
This camaraderie is what drives and bonds members of Post 77 to serve the military community and the Easton community as a whole.
For those looking to get involved, the veterans said, there is always a seat at the table. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on veteran wellbeing, PTSD, homelessness and access to benefits, which are primarily health and social‑service issues rather than sports, education, or purely governmental matters.

title: Mid-Shore groups raise awareness for mental health needs of veterans
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore groups raise awareness for mental health needs of veterans

 November 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 686
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Douglas Willey and Chuck Engh come from different military backgrounds, but they hold similar advice for how society should look at veterans struggling with mental health: "Don't judge."Willey, a 22-year Marine Corps veteran and past commander of American Legion Post 70 in Easton, says the Legion's national branch is working to provide veterans with the care they need — whether they're suffering from PTSD, depression, battle fatigue or other struggles that stem from their time serving the country.
Along with the American Legion's growing initiatives, Willey and Engh believe younger generations of veterans and military members are more adept at accessing the help they need.
"Society's put a different face on it," Willey said. "It's not a stigma anymore. It's just who you are, and it's part of you."
Engh, Post 70's current commander who spent six years in the Navy as an aviation ordnanceman, said the American Legion encourages veterans in need to call the national 988 crisis line, attend Post 70 meetings with professional counselors or connect with fellow veterans.
"Go to somebody one-on-one who's been through it themselves, and they get in a conversation with one another," Engh said. "They walk away, and they're like, 'I feel better. I got to talk to somebody that knows what I'm going through.'"
Nationwide and in Maryland, veterans experience alarming rates of suicide. Lisa Short, adult population supervisor for Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, says around 17.5 veterans die by suicide each day and more than 71,000 died by suicide from 2011 to 2021.
Short agrees that the stigma around mental health has lessened over time, but emphasizes the work to provide support is nowhere near complete, especially to the Eastern Shore's large veteran population.
"We do still see a barrier … in military and emergency response personnel," Short said. "There's a stigma for them regarding their position. They're in roles that are seen to be the protector, the tough one."
J Howard, the organization's behavioral health coordinator for DEI and specialty programs, noted many behaviors that may be exhibited by veterans in need of help: nightmares, flashbacks, survivor's guilt, substance use, mood shifts and "diminishing interest" in activities previously enjoyed.
"Veterans are not as likely to share their trauma experiences," Howard said. "Though they may not speak about it, it does not mean there are not persistent symptoms. … It's important to validate and be consistent when support is being given to the veteran population."
Willey echoed the same, encouraging spouses, family members and friends to listen instead of judge. The need for outreach and someone to talk to only increases this time of year, he says.
"The national department and Post (70) are very proactive on buddy checks," Willey said, "calling a veteran, especially during the holidays."
Since July, Short noted that crisis response groups have seen upticks in calls from veterans. The Santé Group reported serving 10 veterans in this fiscal year's first quarter, compared to 25 the entire fiscal year 2024, Short said. The Eastern Shore Operation Center had 54 Mid-Shore veterans call the 988 hotline in fiscal year 2024, with 35 calling the hotline in just the first quarter of fiscal year 2025.
Short and Howard highlighted the importance of hope for veterans and that resources are readily available, whether it's calling a crisis line or reaching local organizations like the Cambridge VA or Veteran & Military Support Alliance. Short recommended something as simple as putting the 988 crisis line on the refrigerator.
"We don't want them to give up," Howard said.
In October, Post 70, American Legion Post 77 and Mid-Shore Behavioral Health spoke to the Talbot County Council regarding Operation Green Light, an initiative to raise awareness about resources for veterans and their families.
The council passed an Operation Green Light proclamation unanimously, which encourages residents and businesses to display green lights in honor and recognition of veterans from Nov. 4 to Nov. 11.
Willey hopes Post 70 and other organizations can continue to enhance that awareness around the importance of mental health for all veterans.
"The main thing is not to judge each other," Willey said. "I'm not going to judge you, you're not going to judge me, if we want to get any progress." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health challenges faced by veterans, suicide rates, counseling services, and crisis hotlines, which are core health issues. While public safety (suicide prevention) and education (awareness) are relevant, the primary emphasis is on health.

title: Here's a good question: How's your mental health?
author: CHRIS HOUSTON
content:
Here's a good question: How's your mental health?

 November 9, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: CHRIS HOUSTON | Section: Columns 
 
 591
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nobody would hesitate to explain that they missed hockey practice due to a broken leg. In some circles, scars are badges of honor. When I was a kid, students would gleefully sign their names in Sharpies on their friend's orthopedic cast.If you see a friend with a physical injury, you'll probably ask them about it, and likely they will tell you. "How are you?" is a ubiquitous greeting, and mostly people glibly give happy one-word answers like "fine" or "great." I like to surprise friends who ask by giving them sincere answers. My better half cringes when I give brief but honest answers to strangers who enquire.
I keep doing it though, because I think it's important to discuss how we are really doing. My sincere answers to "how are you?" sometimes catch people off guard. A question that I sometimes ask, however, has proven to be a real eye-opener. "How's your mental health?" never gets a glib answer. People don't expect that one. But often the question provokes really meaningful conversations.
Still, I don't commonly ask people about their mental health. To some, it remains a deeply private topic. But maybe it shouldn't be. I wonder how things might be different if we were just as quick to comment on our anxiety or depression as we were our headaches. Normalizing these chats erodes the stigma.
Stigma inhibits conversation about mental health and I think we might have more comprehensive healthcare if we were all more comfortable talking about it.
I've spoken in public and written about my mental health. I find that after I do so, people share their stories. Such stories are widespread. Years ago, I never thought much about mental health. During my recent short stint of local newspaper reporting, housing, poverty, substance use, and mental health were the most commonly discussed topics. They sometimes don't, but often do, overlap.
I used to think that when people spoke about problems, they were looking for solutions. I'm older and wiser now and I know that sometimes people just need to talk. Talking about mental health is therapeutic for folks. And yet, starting conversations about mental health can be difficult. We're not used to it. Many avoid even learning about it.
I like the BeThere.org website, which offers free lessons on how to support someone struggling with their mental health. The website offers golden rules on how to kick-start conversations: say what you see, show you care, and hear them out, know your role, and connect to help.
If you have a mental health issue, you are likely much less alone than you think. Regarding PTSD, a 2019 paper published in the Red Cross's academic journal notes that an "estimated 50 percent of men and 60 percent of women experience at least one trauma during their lifetime. Around 8 percent of these men and 20 percent of these women develop PTSD. In a given year, 8 percent of the general population has a current diagnosis of PTSD." The paper extrapolates that around 26 million people in the United States live with PTSD. The fact that women experience trauma at a rate double digits higher than men, should not go unnoticed.
According to data published by the National Institute of Mental Health 23.1 percent of U.S. adults lived with a mental illness in 2022. So, likely, you know people living with mental disorders. The sooner we all talk about it, the better it is. Practice it: "How is your mental health?" October 10 was World Mental Health Day.
Mental Health America operates a text/phone crisis line accessible via 988. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental health awareness, stigma, statistics, and resources, which aligns directly with the Health topic.

title: Nonprofit asks Caroline County commissioners for veteran support
author: Tom McCall
content:
Nonprofit asks Caroline County commissioners for veteran support

 November 13, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 383
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — Eric Johnson, executive director of the Center for the Military and Verteran Families, came before the Caroline County Commissioners on Tuesday in an effort to get more support for veterans and their families.His presentation focused on veterans from the Afghanistan and Iraq conflicts who have come home with PTSD. These veterans need better access to behavioral health services to prevent suicide, Johnson said.
Johnson said that more than financial support, he wants to restore the dignity for these men and women who have served but are not getting the help they need.
Also at the table were lobbyist Bruce Bereano the deputy director of Veteran and Military Support Alliance Lee Ellington.
VAMSA is located in Queen Anne's County but wants to expand its efforts into Caroline County and across the Eastern Shore.
Johnson said fighting with the bureaucracy to get disability services is really tough when a veteran is already sick. VAMSA, which was founded three years ago, is trying to make the system easier to navigate.
He also mentioned that a mentally challenged veteran creates a stress on their family, and he wants these collateral family members to get some help as well.
"If someone comes back from three tours in Afghanistan and has major PTSD issues, maybe some rage issues, and that is affecting their family, somebody has to take care of that family," Johnson said.
He is a veteran from the War in Afghanistan and has lost two siblings who served in the Air Force to suicide. Johnson says VAMSA has helped 20 different individuals avoid suicide 23 times.
"The number one thing that veterans can do is get involved with service to others. If we can get them to that point, those are the folks that seem to have the most resiliency and prevention of suicidal ideation in that population," Johnson said.
Johnson said veterans on the western shore get better care than veterans on the Eastern Shore. He wants to change that.
One of the ideas that VAMSA has put across is providing computer access to their program on monitors in the Denton American Legion. Virtual accessibility could help with transportation issues, and several VAMSA services can be offered via Zoom.
Travis Breeding, president of the Caroline County Commissioners, said, "We have now lost more Iraq and Afghanistan veterans to suicide than we've lost in combat." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on veterans' PTSD, suicide prevention, and access to behavioral health services, which are core health issues, while also involving local government officials.

title: Local behavioral health experts talk election stress
author: Tom McCall
content:
Local behavioral health experts talk election stress

 November 16, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Tom McCall | Section: Local News 
 
 642
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The election results have stressed some people out.The uncertainty, the disappointment and the queasy sense that there is trouble on the horizon have caused some to have depression and anxiety. Even the people whose candidate won the election are worried there will be another assassination attempt or civil unrest.
The American Psychological Association did a poll and found seven in 10 Americans have significant election stress. Add the holiday season on top of this, and it becomes a lot to handle.
Several local behavioral health leaders had some ideas of how to handle the stress.
"Give ourselves a little space and, I would underscore, give ourselves a little grace. Also you don't know where people stand, so it is also just being respectful. Conversations about it don't need to be top of the list at the Thanksgiving table," said Kathryn Dilley, LCSW-C, the CEO of Mid-Shore Behavioral Health.
Another local behavioral health expert is Beth Anne Dorman, president and CEO of For All Seasons.
With Thanksgiving coming up with all kinds of political viewpoints, she offered a way to stay cool.
"Choose your election dialogue partners carefully — don't engage with friends and family who upset you," Dorman said.
"We may feel we are on opposite sides of the election issues with our family members, colleagues and neighbors. This creates stress and can compromise our mental health. The presidential election, in particular, affects so many aspects of our lives that it's no wonder we are all stressed about the outcome," she said.
Change is tough, and there are big political transitions happening. Stress can affect personal relationships, weight changes and sleep patterns. Getting enough rest, eating healthy and investing in healthy relationships can all help.
Dilley oversees a five-county network of behavioral health support.
"988 the crisis and suicide prevention hotline — that nationally there have been last week an uptick overall. Calls coming in to that number are from a national perspective. Locally at our Eastern Shore Operations Center, we haven't seen a huge variance yet," Dilley said.
She emphasized having hopeful conversations and minimizing oversaturation of news feeds.
Dorman had a list of tips to help alleviate election stress.
"Watch your media diet and find the least stressful ways to stay informed without getting upset, ie: maybe switch to reading news and not watching TV," Dorman said.
Dorman also said to turn election stress into action — people should consider volunteering for a campaign or even running for office. The other mood enhancers she recommended were eating healthy, exercising, getting a good night's sleep and being out in nature. Those whose daily routines are being affected by this stress can seek an appointment at For All Seasons, which has a same-day mental health access policy.
Michelle Boulden-Hammond, Ph.D., is an author and holistic practitioner and has concrete techniques to reduce stress.
"I am seeing a lot of increased anxiety and a lot of depressive states. Worrying about what is going to happen? How am I going to survive with the new administration?" she said.
"I tell them to do journaling as an exercise. I give them some guided meditation. I always tell them to express their feelings. Don't hold it in. The holistic approach will reduce the symptoms. Connect with your higher power, it will never turn us wrong," she said.
Dilley said if stress is becoming unmanagable, there are places to get help.
"That is the message above all. If this situation post election has put anyone in a position where they don't feel they can manage how they are responding to it, I would strongly encourage them to seek help," Dilley said. "There is the Eastern Shore Operations Center, which is our regional hotline to connect. It is 24/7 and can connect you to quick access to get into urgent care appointments in the region. That number is 888-407-8018."
This report has been updated from an earlier version to correct the spelling of a name. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on election‑related stress, anxiety, and depression, and features behavioral health experts offering mental‑health advice and resources, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Holidays pose risk for rape, abuse survivors, local experts say
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Holidays pose risk for rape, abuse survivors, local experts say

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 720
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The holiday season is here, and though it often brings family cheer and joyful events, it also comes with additional stressors for survivors of rape and domestic violence.It is during the holidays that experts in the field see an array of survivors seeking help throughout the Eastern Shore.
The stress is elevated by a variety of factors including family proximity, financial concerns and a lack of free time for survivors to prioritize their mental health and seek services.
Jeanne Yeager, executive director of Mid-Shore Council on Family Violence, said the holidays require that families are together more. Due to a variety of factors including kid's holiday vacation from school and partners' vacation from work, which often "lends itself to more abusive behaviors."
"Domestic violence goes up because of the proximity of the abuser and victim in the home due to being off work during the holidays, but the victims are waiting until after the holidays to seek services, and that's what our data shows, and has shown for many years," Yeager said.
According to Yeager, calls to the Mid-Shore Hotline show a dip in services during the holiday season and picks up immediately following the holidays. Yeager said it's important to understand that victims often stay longer in abusive relationships due to factors prioritized over their own well-being, mainly children and financial stability.
Yeager said leaving an abusive relationship is difficult and dangerous, which is why Mid-Shore provides crisis housing, legal assistance including help with protective orders, divorce and child custody, financial support and assistance in finding employment, child care and other long-term self-sufficiency resources.
But sometimes the most difficult factors have to do with putting others' feelings over their own.
"Christmas is a lot about the kids, and (survivors) don't want to disrupt the Christmas routine for the kids," Yeager said. "I think from a victim perspective, that's where they're coming from, not thinking of self. I think they're thinking of their kids and saying, 'Every year we do this, and I'm just going to put up with it so the kids can get through the holidays and then I'll leave.'"
Although the holidays are a time of potential harm for survivors of domestic abuse, they also bring risk of new harm to vulnerable communities regardless of age.
Holiday gatherings with family, friends, and coworkers can elevate the risk of harassment or sexual assault. According to a study by the Rape, Abuse & Incest National Network, 93% of children who suffer sexual abuse are familiar with their perpetrator and 34% are abused by a family member.
Kirsty Mirando, director of the Rape Crisis Center at For All Seasons, said not only can abuse survivors be triggered by past trauma but the likelihood of new abuse increases.
"During the holiday season, incidents of sexual assault and child sexual abuse may occur more frequently," Mirando said. "The increased time spent with immediate and extended family, heightened emotions and potential alcohol consumption can create vulnerable situations for those at risk of abuse."
Lesa Mulcahy, chief clinical officer for For All Seasons, said she encourages survivors of abuse and parents to create a plan for the holidays that includes identifying potential triggers or stressful situations and having coping mechanisms ready, such as taking breaks, setting boundaries or having a "mental health first aid kit" with comforting items.
Additionally, Mulcahy said it's important to collaborate with supportive family members and friends to work together to make the holidays more manageable and create a positive experience for everyone.
Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communication at For All Seasons, said that while abuse is not a topic that is easy to talk about, it's something that everyone can work on preventing. If people identify as part of a support network for survivors it is important for them to step up and provide care for the people in need.
"I think the most important thing we can do as we approach the holidays and regard to survivors of sexual assault and abuse is just to be supportive, to be a good listener, and to always approach every conversation without judgment," Theeke said. "And we don't always have to have the perfect words to help them through what they're going through if they share something with us, but that we just have to make sure they know that we believe them and that we're there to support them." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the mental and physical well‑being of rape and domestic‑violence survivors, discussing trauma, counseling, and support services, which aligns most closely with the Health category. It also touches on safety concerns, placing Public Safety as a secondary match.

title: Talisman Horseshoe Heroes awards banquet shines spotlight on local heroes
author: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Talisman Horseshoe Heroes awards banquet shines spotlight on local heroes

 November 28, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: DOUG BISHOP Special to the Star Democrat | Section: News 
 
 335
 Words 

 Read News Document

 GRASONVILLE — Saturday evening, Nov. 16, Talisman Therapeutic Riding hosted its second annual Horseshoe Heroes Awards Banquet at the Hyatt Place hotel, located at Kent Narrows.Event Chair and emcee Audrey Scott welcomed those in attendance, explaining the purpose of the banquet was to recognize those in the community who have supported the mission of Talisman Therapeutic Riding, an organization providing horse therapy to disabled military veterans, children, and other individuals.
Following dinner, guest speaker U.S. Coast Guard Captain Carrie Wolfe spoke briefly, talking about related services the Coast Guard provides to members of the military, particularly those struggling with mental health issues. She stated, "We not only use horses for therapy treatments, but other animals such as dogs and others, to help members of the military improve their quality of life."
Scott was joined by TTR Chair Diana Saquella and Queen Anne's County Commissioner Jim Moran during the presentations. Moran read a biography of each honoree.
Talisman Therapeutic Riding has been in existence for more that a decade. Executive Director Noelle Douglas said, "This banquet is held to recognize our volunteers and members of the community who go above and beyond to help Talisman."
The Talisman farm and facility is located at 172 Blue Ribbon Lane in Grasonville. For more information, visit talismantherapeuticriding.org or call 443-239-9400.
The Honorees
Business of the Year — The McMahon Consulting Group, which fulfilled the terms of an $80,000 AmeriCorps planning grant.Volunteer of the Year — Beth Cole has been a part of the Talisman family since 2014 as a PATH certified instructor, committed to two days a week helping countless students become more independent.Neighbor of the Year — Sara and Rami Essaid, described as "lifelong champions of animal welfare," they share the (Talisman) Blue Ribbon address with a magnificent group of horses, goats, cows, dogs, cats and a pig.Philanthropist of the Year — Cal Gray Jr. reduced Talisman's mortgage by 70% in the past year. His efforts brought about three different donations of $100,000 each towards the mortgage, along with numerous other valuable donations.

title: That which brings us together at the library
author: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library
content:
That which brings us together at the library

 November 30, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: BILL PEAK Talbot County Free Library | Section: Life 
 
 889
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Back in September, I attended a lecture at the library given by Meg Daley Olmert, entitled "Sit, Stay, Heal." Olmert is a writer who has worked on documentaries for Smithsonian World, National Geographic Explorer, and PBS, among others. In 1992 she was asked to join a research team studying the neurobiology of social bonding.Listening to Olmert speak, it became obvious that her work on that study changed her view of history; and I began to think it might change mine as well. So I picked up a copy of Olmert's book on the subject, "Made for Each Other," rushed home and devoured it.
I have referred to Jared Diamond's "Guns, Germs, and Steel" before in this column. That book's thesis, that geography rather than racial superiority gave Western Civilization a leg-up on the rest of the world, is now the lens through which I view and understand the past.
But if Diamond's book posits geography as history's fulcrum, Olmert's work places an even less obvious entity at that pivot point: a simple molecule, oxytocin.
Oxytocin is often referred to as the "love hormone." All mammals produce it, and in all mammals it produces the same effects.
When it's time to give birth, oxytocin brings on labor. When it's time to suckle our young, oxytocin brings on lactation. When animals groom one another — whether it's a ewe licking her lamb or a man helping his wife with a zipper — oxytocin is released and all concerned feel a rush of goodwill.
Oxytocin boosts trust, empathy, fidelity and nonverbal communication; it encourages and solidifies social bonding.
All of this is well known, but what Olmert's book makes clear is that these benefits are interspecific, that is: the effects are the same whether a woman is straightening her husband's tie or removing a thorn from her cat's paw. In both cases, their health improves and their bond is strengthened.
For years it has been received wisdom among archaeologists that humans created their first permanent settlements around 10,000 years ago, with the advent of agriculture. But recent discoveries have pushed that date back to a point 15,000 years before people began cultivating crops. Why then?
Well, it turns out that the earlier date dovetails nicely with humanity's first successful domestication of a wild animal; the wolf became a dog, oxytocin was released, and the bond between man and man's best friend was created. People could now go to sleep in the same place night after night secure in the knowledge that their dogs would alert them if a saber-toothed cat or an enemy band approached their settlement.
If permanent settlement is the necessary first-step toward civilization, then we can thank Fido for Chartres Cathedral and the great pyramids. But before those piles could be erected, oxytocin still had more tasks to perform.
When Homo sapiens first entered Europe, among the megafauna they encountered was a monster that stood six feet tall at the shoulder and sported eight-foot horns: the aurochs. When Caesar saw his first aurochs in Germany, he declared them too vicious to ever be tamed. The general would have been surprised to learn that the cattle marching placidly along in his army's wake were, in fact, descendants of the first domesticated aurochs.
But let's think for a moment about how that animal's vastly significant domestication first took place.
Imagine the courage it took for some Neolithic man or woman to approach a wild aurochs, corral it and slip a rope over its neck. Olmert makes the case that this person, whoever they were, was the test pilot of their day, that their one small step toward an aurochs represented a greater leap in world history than Neil Armstrong's. And it was successful, almost certainly, thanks to the oxytocin released in both man and beast.
If oxytocin helped create the bonds between people and animals that made civilization possible (think horses, camels, sheep, dogs, cattle, pigs, etc.), then Olmert's book closes with a cautionary note about what a deficit of oxytocin might mean for our modern world.
Since the Industrial Revolution, people have been moving in ever greater numbers away from the animals that fueled civilization's development. Today, so few Americans still live on the land that the Census Bureau no longer lists farming as a career category to be checked off.
As we moved away from our farms and our farm animals, two particularly devastating mental disconnects blossomed among our children: autism and ADHD. Both conditions are characterized by low levels of oxytocin in the bloodstream. The severity of both has been found to be reduced by giving affected children the opportunity to care for a non-human animal.
In a study performed in 1995, oxytocin was found to protect adults against the modern world's leading cause of death. Among 369 victims of heart attack, dog ownership was found to be a better predictor of survival than regularity of heartbeat, absence of diabetes, or strength of the patient's heart. One year after their coronary, 20 of the 369 patients studied had died — only one of the 20 owned a dog.
Whether or not you think the world would be a better place if we all spent more time stroking Fido or milking Clarabelle, Meg Daley Olmert's "Made for Each Other" will convince you there's more to both than meets the eye. You can find "Made for Each Other" at that hallmark of civilization: our local library. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on the role of oxytocin in human health, mental conditions (autism, ADHD), and cardiovascular outcomes, making health the most relevant category despite mentioning a library lecture.

title: Health should not be politicized
author: Staff Writer
content:
Health should not be politicized

 December 7, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 200
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I remember polio summers.My vigilant mother, a nurse, imposed a quarantine on all the pleasures of warm weather (water and crowds were two known transmission sources), so no swimming and no amusement parks
If we complained, all Mother had to do was show us the scary picture of a roomful of children in iron lungs.
When she learned that Dorchester County got a supply of the polio vaccine before Talbot County, she got us in that first wave of vaccinations, and I could finally take swimming lessons at age 12.
Medical topics were freely discussed in our house as well as the history of loss due to childhood diseases that were not preventable at the time. I had a case of measles at age 6 months, which the family did not expect me to survive.
When it was time for my own children, I was grateful for the scientific advances that enabled me to protect them against measles, mumps and rubella.
I have great concern that the health of our children will be managed by individuals who lack scientific or medical backgrounds.
The health of children should not be weaponized or politicized. All other political opinions aside on this matter we should stand together.
SHARON HARRINGTON
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses vaccination, disease prevention, and the politicization of children's health, which directly aligns with the Health topic.

title: Wellness takes a creative twist with music and art at the core
author: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat
content:
Wellness takes a creative twist with music and art at the core

 December 8, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: NIAMBI DAVIS Special to the Star Democrat | Section: Local News 
 
 751
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Twelve days after his 1984 graduation from Queen Anne's County High School, Darrin Pruitt joined the Navy."I still had my Ocean City sunburn," he recalled. After serving for six years, Pruitt lived in Washington State, working on quality control for nuclear fuel production.
When his mother developed melanoma, along with other life changes, "it seemed like a good time to come home."
Pruitt, a self-described serial entrepreneur, works for the Department of Labor Workforce Development Veterans Services during the day. His brainchild and "sometimes beautiful disaster" is Chesapeake Creative Wellness, a nonprofit organization operating under Chesapeake Charities.
The inspiration for Chesapeake Creative Wellness came from two very different directions. As a Navy vet who works with veterans, Pruitt sees PTSD and anxiety every day. Seven years ago, as a marketer for an Australian custom guitar company, he met Alice Cooper's Solid Rock Center members in Arizona. This group uses music and art to help at-risk teens. "When I told them I wanted to bring that model back here to the East Coast they kind of patted me on the head with a patronizing 'yeah, keep us in the loop.'"
He did. In 2023, Pruitt advised them of Chesapeake Creative Wellness' projected launch date for the second quarter of 2024. In August the organization held its first music session. In September they acquired a studio on Creamery Lane in Easton. "I told our landlord I didn't want the walls or floors redone. I want people to paint on them. We're painting murals inside the studio. It has worked out well for us." Kristi Egnar, an Easton artist, is the Creative Wellness art director. Mike Elzey of Mike Elzey Studios and musician Quinn Parsley provide musical direction.
Pruitt describes the Chesapeake Wellness model as peer counseling with no set structure. Some participate regularly; others attend infrequently, while others come only to hang out and talk. "And I didn't know it at first, but that approach turned out to be the best part; it's what we do really well. We want people to know that even if they don't want to ask for help they're not alone; there are people here who can help. It's a niche that needs filling in our community. We found the right time and the right way to fill it."
Relationships with Veterans of Foreign Wars, the American Legions, and Patriot Point in Dorchester County support the work of Chesapeake Creative Wellness. The Queen Anne's County Centre for the Arts is a friend of the organization. "At a veterans' job fair at Maryland Live Casino, I met the General Manager who is also a Marine," Pruitt recalled. "I came asking for assistance but also looking for a way that we could help. The GM told me I was the first person who ever asked for assistance and followed up with an offer to help."
Today Chesapeake Creative Wellness stocks the Maryland Live employees' break room with colored pens, pencils, and adult-level coloring books. In January the organization will host a monthly music program and comedy show at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center. "We're looking for other ways such as outreach to nursing homes and rehab centers with long-term patients," Pruitt announced.
Locally, Chesapeake Creative Wellness hosts paint parties at local restaurants in Easton, Cambridge, and Centreville. Dates and times can be found on their Facebook page. Plans are in the works for a blog written by professional artists and musicians, including posts from contributors who have experienced similar challenges.
Ideas fuel the engine of Chesapeake Creative Wellness. "It's the busy people who get things done and our minds are always working," Pruitt says. "If an idea pops up, we hold on to it. As soon as we're done with one, we start working on another." Their idea for Christmas 2024 is a 16-foot Christmas tree to stand outside the VFW in Easton. Chesapeake Creative Wellness will sell ornaments for purchase and decoration, similar to the concept of the Crab Basket Trees at Fisherman's in Grasonville. Each ornament is two-feet in diameter and sells for $50. Proceeds from the sale will be used to purchase supplies for the organization's operation.
Chesapeake Creative Wellness welcomes volunteers — from those with artistic talent to anyone with time to sit in the office and keep the doors open for the day. Above all, Pruitt extends this invitation to anyone in any walk of life, "If you're having difficulty with PTSD or anxiety issues, we're here for you."
Visit Chesapeake Creative Wellness at 31A Creamery Lane in Easton or call 410-340-6257. 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a nonprofit that uses music and art to address PTSD and anxiety, focusing on mental wellness, which aligns most closely with the Health topic, while also involving artistic activities.

title: Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Music as medicine: holiday concert provides cheer to residents living with memory loss

 December 21, 2024 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: Holiday 
 
 418
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On Monday afternoon, the HeartFields Assisted Living in Easton was filled with hums and songs.The annual holiday concert led by TiShawna Jordan, a local musician, was an effort to provide holiday cheer and acted as an intervention to benefit those living with loss of memory.
Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton partnered with the Chesapeake Center in order to provide support for elderly individuals through volunteer-led events such as the holiday concert.
Erin Lewis, director of career services at Chesapeake Center, said TiShawna Jordan's concerts have provided holiday cheer and positive memory recollection to those in the Bridge to Rediscovery program.
"Watching her perform throughout the year with the people in the memory clinic. She brings them back to life," Lewis said. "They start singing, they start dancing, they remember all the words to each one of the songs. It's wonderful to see how she can interact. It's almost like a different way of communicating."
According to Northwestern University, musical intervention has therapeutic benefits for people with dementia or Alzheimer's disease and has been proven to decrease a patient's agitation and improve communication.
Megan Pinder, director of sales and marketing for HeartFields Assisting Living, said HeartFields had begun partnering with the Chesapeake Center about two years ago. The volunteer-led programs began with a bird club where volunteers come to the Heartfields and fill up the 41 bird feeders every week for the residents to enjoy.
Then TiShawna, an active volunteer at the Chesapeake Center, began to come and play music for residents at HeartFields.
According to Pinder, the first holiday concert was a resounding success, and TiShawna Jordan was presented with roses by the HeartFields Resident Ambassador because her playing had moved many attendees to tears.
Elsie Jordan, mother of TiShawna Jordan, said her daughter was always musically inclined. As a child she would play the keyboard, and Elsie Jordan said she would help her daughter learn new music through humming songs.
During the concert, Elsie Jordan sat next to her daughter humming and singing along to classic Christmas songs such as "White Christmas" and "Jingle Bell Rock." At some points they would both sing, encouraging the crowd of attendees to raise their voices and fully enjoy the memory of the holidays.
"God gave her that gift, and I want her to share her gift with other people," Elsie Jordan said. "Because if it wasn't for God, she wouldn't have the gift she has. I feel like it's a gift and you shouldn't have to be paid for something you love doing. And she loves playing." 

 © Copyright © 2024 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a music concert used as a therapeutic intervention for residents with memory loss, highlighting medical benefits of music for dementia patients, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Resolve to eat better in new year
author: Staff Writer
content:
Resolve to eat better in new year

 January 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 153
 Words 

 Read News Document

 New Year's resolution anyone? How about one with multiple benefits for our health, our planet and the animals? Eating more veggies, fruits, legumes, grains and nuts helps us stay healthier, reduce global warming and stop animal suffering. It requires no exertion or deprivation. And it saves money too.The abundant nutrients and vitamins in plant foods keep us in top health, while their fiber keeps us regular. Plant foods don't do drugs, antibiotics, hormones, cholesterol or saturated fats. Concerned about ultra-processed foods? Then you certainly don't want your food processed through an animal's digestive tract.
Best of all, plant-based eating is supported by your local supermarket, which offers a rich variety of plant meats, cheeses and ice creams in their frozen food section, as well as a wide selection of nut and grain milks. Same goes for your favorite family restaurant and nearly every fast-food franchise.
There is more food for thought at:
nytimes.com/2023/11/15/well/eat/plant-based-diet-nuts-beans-grains.html.forksoverknives.com.bitesizevegan.org
Bon appetit.
DALEB STOKER
Cambridge

title: Mental Health experts offer tips for managing New Year's resolutions
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mental Health experts offer tips for managing New Year's resolutions

 January 5, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 585
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The new year is here, and what comes with it, for many people, is a fresh start.New Year's resolutions are infamously tied to failure of goals, but mental health experts share that if people are seeking positive change in their lives, understanding mental health will allow people to not only accomplish their goals but to be kinder to themselves if they are unable to achieve their goals within an expected time frame.
Katie Theeke, vice president of marketing and communications at For All Seasons, said the connection between mental health and New Year's resolutions are heavily tied together.
"Mental health is foundational to how we think, feel and act," Theeke said. "When we care for our mental health we feel better, and people will often see their quality of life and relationships improve. Without awareness and care for our mental health, it's very difficult to have the motivation and commitment to fulfill our hopes and goals for the new year."
According to Centerstone, a national nonprofit specializing in mental health and substance use disorder, there is an unspoken rule that resolutions should be all or nothing extremities. This mindset it often leads to difficult-to-accomplish resolutions and then ideas of self-sabotage and punishment if resolutions are not accomplished, Centerstone said.
Theeke said it is great to think of goals, but what is more important is the little steps and systems that are put into place to steer people in the direction they want to go. Instead of focusing on a big goal like losing a significant amount of weight, she encourages people to try to set up a simple system to start getting healthy, such as walking with a friend each week.
Theeke said it's the small attainable steps that start to build up. If one system doesn't work it's important to evaluate and change the system to something that works better for the individual.
For those who want to make resolutions around mental health, Theeke suggests considering activities that bring positive emotions, whether it be music, walking, exercising, feeding and watching birds, or spending time with friends and family. Prioritizing simple acts of joy, even if it requires carving time out to do so, can have big gains in mental health growth, she said.
For those who find themselves continuing to feel low for more than two weeks at a time, Theeke suggests considering reaching out to a mental health professional. Individuals need to take the time to invest in themselves and investing in mental health can have lasting gains.
But most importantly, Theeke encourages everyone to be kind to themselves regardless of success on their resolutions. If people are able to approach themselves with more kindness and understanding, it can help build the confidence needed to accomplish whatever goals that are made. But most importantly, kindness for self can make moving forward with everyday life easier and improve personal relationships.
"One of the nicest things you can do for yourself in the new year is change your internal dialogue," Theeke said. "So many of us are criticizing ourselves throughout the day. Catch yourself if you are thinking something negative and try out some simple phrases like, 'I am focusing on progress, not perfection.' Or, 'I am getting a little stronger and healthier every day.' There are so many positive affirmations out there. Find a few that feel right for you and try them. Reach out to a trusted friend or a mental health professional if you continue to struggle. There are good people out there who are ready to help." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on mental‑health advice and strategies for managing New Year's resolutions, which directly relates to personal health and well‑being.

title: Region tops flu and Norovirus charts
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub,com
content:
Region tops flu and Norovirus charts

 January 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub,com | Section: News 
 
 214
 Words 

 Read News Document

 During the holiday season, Region IV, encompassing Kthe Eastern Shore, experienced a significant increase in influenza cases, surpassing other regions and the state in prevalence.Kent County Health Officer Bill Webb said, "The influenza for Region IV shows a significant uptick. Since we are in the heart of the Flu Season this is somewhat expected. In fact, we are outpacing other regions and the state as a whole on this metric."
Viruses like this one are known to spread in settings such as households, health care settings, schools and child care centers, and during food preparation if hands have not been thoroughly washed with soap and water.
Symptoms can be nausea and vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, low fever, headache, muscle aches, chills and tiredness, usually lasting 24 to 48 hours and go away without treatment.
Webb highlighted the significant uptick in flu season but also noted a rise in gastrointestinal illnesses linked to the Norovirus in the area.
The Norovirus, commonly spread through fecal matter or vomit contact, contaminated food, or water, can cause symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and fever.
The rates for Norovirus in Region IV have spiked, reaching a high of 160 per 100,000 residents, according to Maryland Department of Health data sourced from diverse surveillance methods including emergency visits, thermometer sales and the ESSENCE system. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Trust your doctors on vaccines
author: Staff Writer
content:
Trust your doctors on vaccines

 January 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 380
 Words 

 Read News Document

 We are two retired pediatricians who practiced in Easton for a number of years and who have a great concern about the risk to children posed by vaccine hesitancy. That is, the reluctance of parents to have their children receive approved vaccines according to the recommended dose and schedule.When we were both young and in our training, diseases such as measles, mumps and chicken pox were common. Cases of smallpox were not unheard of, and some survivors of this disease were left with severe facial scarring. Polio epidemics, particularly in the 1950s, closed swimming pools in the summer and both of us had schoolmates who were affected. Fear of catching polio and being confined to an iron lung caused nightmares. For this disease, the picture rapidly changed with the advent of the Salk, and then Sabin, polio vaccines. Due to those vaccines, the scourge of polio has essentially disappeared from the United States.
In 1963 in the United States prior to the introduction of the measles vaccine, according to the CDC, 400 people died annually, 48,000 were hospitalized and 1,000 developed brain swelling from measles. Now for vaccinated children, the number is essentially zero.
Vaccines to protect against common childhood diseases have been one of the greatest advances in medical science, at least as important as the discovery of antibiotics. At the current time, vaccines protecting against over ten serious diseases including diphtheria, whooping cough, tetanus, polio, hepatitis A and B, pneumococcal pneumonia, rotavirus, chickenpox and influenza are available. There are also vaccines for COVID, respiratory syncytial virus, meningitis and human papilloma virus.
Unfortunately, the dramatic decrease in incidence of those serious diseases secondary to the introduction of vaccines has been threatened by vaccine hesitancy. This hesitancy has been fueled in large part by dissemination of misinformation on social media.
The vaccines your medical care giver recommends for your child have been exhaustively tested for their efficacy, safety and scheduling. We beg for you to talk with your caregiver if you have questions about vaccines and not to rely on possible misinformation found on social media. Your caregivers have years of scientific education and experience behind them, so please trust that they are recommending appropriate vaccines with the appropriate schedules. Your child's life may depend on it.
DR. BRIAN J. CORDON DR. JUDI GIESKI
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Mid-Shore Behavior Health to host count of unsheltered people
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content:
Mid-Shore Behavior Health to host count of unsheltered people

 January 25, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado | Section: News 
 
 313
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Across five counties on the Eastern Shore on Wednesday, Jan. 29, Mid-Shore Behavioral Health will be hosting a point-in-time count.According to Jimmy Morris, continuum of care housing outreach specialist at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health, it is a count of all experiencing unsheltered (living in cars, parks, streets, etc.) and sheltered (living in emergency shelters, transitional housing) homelessness on a single night.
The results of the data gathered will be submitted to the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development and can be used to secure grant funding.
The hosted locations for the count include Queen Anne's County libraries in Stevensville from 10 a.m. to noon and in Centreville from 2 to 5 p.m.; St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Caroline County; Talbot County Free Library in Easton; Delmarva Senior Center in Cambridge; and Kent County, where people will be commuting through the county to make the count.
Morris said this particular count of people is important due to the rise of unsheltered individuals on the Shore.
Morris shared that some people are coming to shelters with 14-day-old babies and even 7-day-old babies.
"There's people that lost their homes because of medical conditions or job layoff, drug, alcohol, addiction or mental health," Morris said. "We are overwhelmed in these five counties."
Getting the word out about the count has been essential for Morris and the team at Mid-Shore Behavioral Health. Morris said he has gone to tent camps around the Eastern Shore to share information about the point-in-time so those living there can have their voices heard.
"We have people in hotels that cost grant money, there's people that are living in their cars, living in the woods, and God, it's cold out," Morris said. "We don't have the funds anymore. The only way to get the funding is to let them know what the situation is down here."
For more information, Morris encourages people to call him at 443-786-0699. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Advocates say budget cuts would harm Marylanders with disabilities
author: EMMA TUFO Capital News Service
content:
Advocates say budget cuts would harm Marylanders with disabilities

 January 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: EMMA TUFO Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 444
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Advocates for disabled people in Maryland are concerned about proposed cuts to their state programs, warning that the reductions could hit quality of care for some of the state's most vulnerable residents.During a hearing Thursday, advocates described the far-reaching consequences these cuts could have on the state's Developmental Disabilities Administration.
Mat Rice, executive director of People on the Go Maryland, urged state lawmakers to "not turn back the clock on a marginalized community."
"Are we saying to my staff person that is here with two kids, that he might have to take a potential pay cut?" Rice said. "There is a human cost here."
But Helene Grady, secretary of the Department of Budget and Management, said the "cost containment" measures were intentionally designed to minimize disruption to essential services.
"There are many potential options within the DDA program that are not on the table, and very intentionally not on the table, because of the impact they would have to the services the state is providing," she said. "The package that is on the table for cost containment was structured in a very targeted fashion to impact the areas and the flexibilities within the program."
Gov. Wes Moore has proposed $2 billion in cuts in his fiscal 2026 budget, as part of an overall attempt to address the state's looming $3 billion deficit. The DDA's spending has grown in recent years, agency officials said.
Moore's proposed reductions to the current fiscal year budget would adjust wages for an overall savings to the state. One of those changes would eliminate geographic differential rates, which currently pay providers more if they work in areas with a higher cost of living.
Ande Kolp, executive director of The Arc Maryland, argued the potential harm of these reductions. It would be hard for providers in high-cost areas like Montgomery and Prince George's Counties to survive the cuts, advocates say.
"The geographic differential is foundational to our rates," Kolp said. "It amounts to kind of kicking the legs out from under these providers at this time."
"I'm not sure that they will survive," she said.
Another cut would target "low intensity" support services, designed to help people avoid more drastic intervention. They allow individuals and families to use funding for short-term in-home care, minor home modifications for accessibility, short-term respite care, adaptive equipment, summer camps and other needs.
Sen. Cory McCray told Grady that families benefiting from the program are already contacting him, expressing concern over its potential elimination. McCray, a Democrat from Baltimore City, asked why the program should be cut.
Grady said it was a part of the cost-containment plan to ensure a sustainable budget model for the DDA going forward.
"We still have work to do," Grady said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on proposed budget cuts to Maryland's Developmental Disabilities Administration and their impact on care for disabled residents, which aligns most closely with health and social services.

title: 'We are a big family here': Bringing joy and love to local seniors
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
'We are a big family here': Bringing joy and love to local seniors

 February 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Entertainment 
 
 955
 Words 

 Read News Document

 In the year and a half since Colleen Upp became Activity Coordinator of the Amy Lynn Ferris Center at 200 Schauber Road, Chestertown, she has been having a blast, conducting new dance classes, art activities, crafts, and crazy games. Before she was there, the center had one exercise class and bingo twice a week, she said.That's changed under her watch. The parking lot there is filled, depending on what day and what fun activity, said board member Cathy Quesenberry.
"We are a big family here," Upp said with the youthful energy she exudes to anyone who walks through those doors.
It is a fun occupation, but it also is a very important job, requiring possessing a level of care ranging beyond the center, since the senior members she works with can be widowers, often live alone, and some may not have immediate family close by.
Such was the case with one member, 90-year-old Dean Wood. His wife passed away two years ago and since then, he has been religiously attending lunches there, amusing staff with his quirky mannerisms.
But one day last fall, Wood was not there — unusual for him. Upp noted that he did not miss many, if any, meals, and would ask for double helpings when he could, followed by a kind of catch phrase he adopted, "Well, you know me!"
Additionally that day, receptionist Cathy Smith told Upp and Shift Coordinator Michaela Wilson that the Meals-on-Wheels volunteer Joy Grace went by his house but he did not answer the door.
Upp and Wilson decided to drive to Wood's home to check on him.
Upp hollered for Wood, and after a while, she heard him through the window in his usual tone, a booming voice, hearing impaired.
"What? Who is that?", he cried.
"Are you ok? Dean, it's Colleen," she responded.
The silences were too far in between and Upp knew something was wrong. She was ready to climb through the window, but Wilson was already on the phone with the police. When they arrived they had to break down the door where they found Wood laying in the hallway.
He had fallen, but maintaining that distinct personality, he looked at Upp while awaiting medical transport.
"Dean, I knew something was wrong when you didn't come to lunch," she said.
Not missing a beat, his smile turned to a frown and said, "You mean I missed baked potato day? You know me, I never miss a meal!"
Wood's humorous response highlights the care, respect and appreciation, Upp, Wilson and the entire staff show towards their seniors.
Knowing Wood's habits and routines enabled them to possibly save his life. If not for their concern, he may have been in that position all weekend since Meals on Wheels only delivers on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays.
Wood, according to medical personnel, was likely dehydrated and malnourished leading to his fall — it could have been fatal.
Instead, he spent five weeks recovering in the hospital, first in Christiana, then in Corsica Hills where he expressed discomfort of the beds there.
Wood is happy to be back home now.
On the day of this interview, it was lunch time on a Wednesday. They were serving up roasted pulled barbecue chicken, succotash, jasmine rice, fruit, milk and juice.
Wood showed up, back in his place, and sat down and wanted milk and juice with two straws, as is his usual custom.
His eyes shined when he saw Upp, and it was evident he looked forward to seeing some of his friends, chatting with them and other staff members.
All of the seniors who came in were greeted warmly showing that these gestures of kindness, and dignity, mean as much to seniors as the meals the center serves. Vanolia Brown, of food services, asked one member where they were at yesterday, playfully chiding them.
It was this kind of personal attention that protected Wood that day.
Upp said, "Every one of us know where the members are and we know when something is off. For instance, we know the day one of them might go to AquaFit, or have an appointment with the VA hospital, or are visiting their son every Wednesday. We see their routine."
It is a vital and often under appreciated responsibility that the whole staff share.
"We love them all. We see them everyday and interact and care for them. It is extremely rewarding work," Upp said. "It takes all of us to do it."
It is this personal attention that keeps senior's minds and bodies active as well. The chance to do all the activities that Upp has planned is something they can look forward to each week.
What love she gives, she gets back in full. On her wall, in her activity room, displaying exactly how much residents appreciate her — are memories from Colleen Appreciation Day on July 11, last year.
Hanging on a hook is a whip one of her residents made for her, to poke fun at her intensity leading her exercise routines. Dancing is a joy for her, tracing back to her mother, Arlene Blanke, a former Rockette in New York, who started a dance troupe called The Happy Hoofers," while in a senior center in Virginia. Upp's vibrance and energy come thorough when in conversation.
There are countless cards of appreciation on the wall but one card sums up the great impact she has made.
"Colleen's dedication, determination, imagination, ingenuity, and enthusiasm have all made the Amy Lynn Ferris Center more fun and has encouraged new people to participate."
Quesenberry said, "She has been wonderful. We're so lucky to have her."
And what of Wood?
He is back, saying blunt things very loudly for all the tables to hear, and never passing up on a great meal.
Well...you know Dean!
For information of the activities for the center call 410-778-2564. Their hours: Monday-Friday 8 a.m. to 3:00 p.m or go to: https://www.uppershoreaging.org/centers. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on senior well‑being, medical issues like dehydration and falls, and the role of a community center in supporting health, making Health the most fitting category.

title: Talbot County distributing micro grants to combat opioid epidemic
author: COUNTRIBUTED
content:
Talbot County distributing micro grants to combat opioid epidemic

 February 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: COUNTRIBUTED | Section: Life 
 
 175
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Talbot County has announced the fiscal year 2025 Opioid Restitution Fund Community Micro Grant Program.This initiative provides organizations with active 501©3 status the opportunity to apply for one-time funding allocations ranging from $1,000 to $20,000 to support programs and services addressing the opioid crisis in Talbot County. Grant funds must be used by June 30, 2026.
The Opioid Restitution Fund stems from settlements with pharmaceutical companies and distributors. Talbot County is leveraging these funds to invest in community-based solutions, focusing on prevention, treatment and recovery initiatives to address the ongoing impact.
Applications must be submitted to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office by Friday, Feb. 21, at 3 p.m. Late submissions will not be considered.
"The opioid epidemic continues to impact families and communities across Talbot County. This funding presents an opportunity to invest in programs and initiatives that save lives and provide critical support to those affected by opioid use disorder," said Sheriff Joe Gamble. "I encourage our local nonprofits to submit their ideas and partner with us to make a real difference."
For additional information, visit talbotcountymd.gov/orf.
