It also touches on safety and community outreach, making Public Safety a secondary fit, while its announcement nature suggests Public Notices as a lesser match.

title: What it was like ... to be a health care worker
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
What it was like ... to be a health care worker

 March 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 279
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — On her phone, Jess Caraker keeps a photo that, to her, sums up the COVID-19 pandemic.The photo is of her 18-month-old daughter in the first months of the pandemic. In the photo, her daughter is on the other side of a sliding glass door with a pacifier in her mouth, wearing a diaper.
"And I had drawn a heart on the window," Caraker remembered. "And she put her hand on it and put her hand (on her chest) and put her head down."
At the time, Caraker — who was a clinical coordinator in the intensive care unit at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Center at Easton — was living apart from her husband and three children due to her role on the front lines of the COVID-19 pandemic. Caraker and her husband had made the decision that she would move in with her sister, who is an emergency responder.
"Because this was the beginning of the pandemic," Caraker said about the decision, explaining there was little information about the virus. "We were still washing our groceries before we took them in the house."
Caraker lived away from her family for the first three months of the pandemic. She considers it one of the hardest things she's ever done.
"I did everything so that they didn't have to get exposed," she said about her family. "So I would go to the grocery store on my way home and drop stuff off on the porch."
Five years later, the photo of her daughter on the other side of the door still makes Caraker tear up.
"That picture, to me, is like how it felt to be gone for that three months," she said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a frontline health care worker’s personal experience during the COVID‑19 pandemic, making the primary relevance to health and health‑care topics.

title: Stacey Smith
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Stacey Smith

 March 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 265
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — When her son was diagnosed with long COVID in 2022, Stacey Smith went from being a full-time teacher to being a full-time caretaker with her husband Michael Smith."Researching had become my full-time job because I stopped teaching to take care of Dylan," she said about their now 15-year-old son Dylan Smith.
For Stacey Smith, one of the more difficult aspects of her son being sick was that it was a newer illness that hadn't been heavily researched.
"If it was a disease that we knew of, like diabetes or — I don't even want to say cancer — but just a disease that you knew of, there's research and there's proven medicine to help," she said. "The doctors did not know what to do."
The Smiths tried everything, from medication to a month-long rehabilitation program to natural supplements. Stacey Smith said none of it worked.
"We were finished with the doctors that were just trying to prescribe medicine," she said. "I was done. And I believe we all felt that way, basically, because of everything that it was doing to him. It was just making him worse. So we honestly were at a point where we felt stuck."
In March 2024, Stacey Smith received a text from the long term substitute filling in for her at work recommending a clinic in Arkansas. Of all the research and all the reaching out to people she had done, Stacey Smith said, it was this recommendation that led to Dylan Smith returning to good health.
"It's like his body woke up," Stacey Smith said about how the treatment affected her son.

title: Chester man to again bike across NY for cancer
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Chester man to again bike across NY for cancer

 March 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 528
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTER — On a personal mission to raise money for cancer research, Richard Catan, 67, of Chester is gearing up to participate in his second Empire State Ride to raise funds for cancer research this summer.Committed to cycling over 500 miles over seven days, from Staten Island New York, to Niagara Falls,"Whatever comes up during training or the ride, I know it is nothing compared to those who are given a diagnosis of cancer," Catan said.
Watching siblings and close family members go through cancer treatment, Catans's most constant thought was, "What more can I do?"
Finding his answer in the Empire State Ride, Catan said the tangible results from research through the money raised from the ride gives hope to those with cancer and their family and friends who support them.
With riders from 21 states and Canada, 291 cyclist completed the full seven day ride across New York state last year, with ages between 24 and 75.
This year's ride is expected to have close to 300 participants again, and as far as Catan knows, he is the only cyclist from the Eastern Shore.
This year's 11th annual Empire State Ride is the community's opportunity to help shape the future of cancer research and treatment while honoring everyone affected by cancer, he said.
Catan seeks the community's support in fueling cancer research funding. Every dollar raised is leveraged to make $26 dollars of research funding and every dollar makes a difference, he said.
Reflecting on his first attempt last year, Catan noted even an avid cyclist with some distance riding experience, the initial thought of cycling across New York State seemed like a near insurmountable challenge, he said.
But as new and innovative treatments and cutting-edge research are being discovered through the funding raised by the ride, he knew the ride was the perfect opportunity to "help shape the future of cancer research and treatment while honoring everyone affected by cancer, " he said.
To prepare for such a long distance, Catan employs "chunking" or breaking riding into manageable segments between rest stops, 16 to 24 miles, he said.
"By focusing on these smaller goals, the journey felt less daunting," Catan said.
"Experienced cyclists know that long-distance riding is as much about mental fortitude as physical strength. It's crucial to maintain the right mindset, remember to hydrate, take in nutrition, manage gear, stay aware of those around you, and adapt to the terrain," he said.
Now heading into his second trek, Catan feels more prepared in his training regiments and is more confident in his abilities as a cyclist.
For Catan, the Empire State Ride is as much about the journey as the destination, with new sites and challenges to experience as well as camaraderie to forge with fellow riders in addition to the end goal of fundraising.
As Catan prepares for his monumental week-long ride, he invites everyone to visit his fundraising page to learn more about his personal connection to cancer and join in supporting the noble cause.
"Together, we can pedal for a cause, advancing cancer research, and bringing hope to those who need it most, he said.
Catan's official fund raising page is available at https://bit.ly/4ieOmNq.
More information about the Empire State Ride can be found at https://empirestateride.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a personal fundraising effort to support cancer research, which is directly related to health issues. While it mentions fundraising (economy) and a long-distance bike ride (safety considerations), the primary focus is on cancer and health research.

title: Senior care leaders warn cuts could be ‘drastic’ for Talbot County seniors
author: Konner Metz
content:
Senior care leaders warn cuts could be ‘drastic’ for Talbot County seniors

 March 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 446
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Senior care experts warned the Talbot County Council Tuesday that state cuts could impact senior services not only in fiscal year 2026, but in the final quarter of the current fiscal year as well.Carrie Ottey, director of senior services for the Talbot County Health Department, said initial proposals from the state put $2.5 million in funding for senior care programs statewide at risk. After the Maryland Department of Aging calculated how those may be allocated to counties, Talbot faced the potential of losing $24,000 in funding this year, Ottey noted.
"Since we're already pretty much spent through quarter three, that would be really drastic cuts in quarter four of this year," Ottey said. " … We'd have to cut off almost all of our services to our seniors in the last quarter of this year if these cuts were to go through."
Ottey said that state legislators are pushing for a reduction in total cuts, potentially from the $2.5 million mark to around $900,000. The trimming comes as the state is faced with an over $3 billion deficit.
Council Vice President Pete Lesher said senior care is the "wrong place to find those savings."
Council member Lynn Mielke denounced the potential cuts and noted Talbot County's higher-than-average age makes such funding even more crucial.
According to census data, people 65-and-over accounts for 30% of Talbot County's total population. The county's average age was 50.9 in 2023 and has slightly increased each year since 2020. The national average is just under 39 years old.
"I think it's disgraceful what this state has done in this regard, and find it to be really ageist," Mielke said.
"Hopefully the state legislature will wake up and do the right thing by its senior citizens, who have supported them all these years," she later added.
Ottey said the county's senior care program has served 214 clients this year already, up from 207 last year. "People are needing us now more than ever," she said.
Jennifer Marchi, vice chair of Talbot County's commission on aging, said depending on how the cuts shake out, they may return to the council at a future date with a request for up to $24,000 in contingency funding.
Tuesday, the County Council voted 4-0 to write a letter of support for senior care program funding. Council members thanked Ottey and Marchi, along with senior care leaders and workers in attendance, for their work.
"You've done a fabulous job at providing services," Mielke said.
"And we also know that there are senior homeless issues that are going to have to be addressed," she continued. "And how are they going to be addressed if they cut back our funding for what we're already providing? It's a tragic situation." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on senior care services and funding cuts affecting health programs for older adults, making Health the most relevant category, with Local Government as a secondary theme due to the involvement of the county council.

title: Beyond the immediate crisis: COVID-19's lasting transformations
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
Beyond the immediate crisis: COVID-19's lasting transformations

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: STAFF REPORT | Section: News 
 
 235
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As the Eastern Shore emerged from the acute phase of the COVID-19 pandemic, the virus left an indelible mark that extended far beyond immediate health concerns.The pandemic became a catalyst for unprecedented change, reshaping communities in ways both unexpected and profound. While the virus disrupted lives, it also accelerated innovations and exposed critical gaps in infrastructure, healthcare and social support systems.
The digital divide, long a silent challenge for rural communities, suddenly became a lifeline during lockdowns. Broadband expansion, once a slow-moving initiative, gained momentum as remote work, telehealth and online education became necessities rather than conveniences.
Mental health emerged as another critical frontier. The isolation, uncertainty and collective trauma of the pandemic laid bare the state of community mental wellness.
The federal government's response came in the form of the American Rescue Plan Act, a massive injection of funds designed to support communities struggling in the pandemic's wake. These funds became a lifeline for local governments, schools and healthcare systems, offering a temporary reprieve and an opportunity for strategic reinvestment.
The pandemic forced communities to reimagine infrastructure, healthcare delivery, education and social connectivity. Each challenge became an opportunity for innovation, each obstacle a chance to rebuild more resiliently.
In this section, we'll explore these lasting impacts — how broadband expansion bridged critical access gaps, how mental health challenges surfaced and began to be addressed, and how ARPA funds were deployed to support communities during their most vulnerable moment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on COVID-19's impact on public health, mental health, and healthcare delivery, making Health the most fitting category, with secondary relevance to Education (online learning) and Local Government (ARPA funding).

title: COVID changed the way people view mental health
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
COVID changed the way people view mental health

 March 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 689
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Before COVID-19, mental health might have been the least of many peoples priorities for people living on the Eastern Shore. COVID helped bring more awareness to a topic that needed to be more focused on, experts say."So I think what COVID did was it brought to light that we all experience mental health symptoms," said For All Seasons President and CEO Beth Anne Dorman.
On March 13, 2020, the first Trump Administration declared a nationwide emergency. The world stopped for what many thought would only be two weeks. It turned out to be much longer.
At schools, some seniors didn't get the chance to walk the stage or have their senior prom, which caused mental health officials in schools to be proactive on making sure students were in good spirits.
"In that first early wave, we did not have behavioral health providers working for us at Choptank," said Chrissy Bartz, PA-C director of Community Based Programs at Choptank Community Health System.
"The therapists that were already working in the schools, they connected with those students at home as soon as they could. Fortunately with COVID came virtual and telehealth opportunities that we had never seen before in care."
Students experienced many different mental health problems. Some students were forced to be at home every day in situations that were unhealthy. Some lost the fresh meals they received at school.
Mental health officials were forced to be proactive in student care outside of school.
"We made really conscious efforts to reach out to students that we had been seeing in the schools because for a lot of them, we're the only resource that they have," Bartz said.
When students started to return to school, mental health officials discovered students were having a hard time getting reacquainted with daily routines and interacting with other students.
"I think one of the things that happened right away when we got back into schools, we started to identify some of the behaviors that came with them feeling socially isolated or not having normal routines," Bartz said. "We had a lot of kids come back really anxious because they hadn't been in a setting like this before. They had been out of it and now needed to reacclimatized themselves."
For adults, the shutdown meant multiple different things. According to Dorman, some patients experienced different trauma and needed more care than others. That's why staying open was a priority for For All Seasons, she said.
"We knew that mental health was not an option to shut down," Dorman said. "We are very much a part of the first responder healthcare line. Our major pieces were how do we keep things like the rape crisis center still moving? How do we make sure that we never closed fully? We had 25-30% of our staff in person all the time."
"... Loneliness, grief, anxiety, depression, were all up," Doorman said. "I think the impact was heavy on families when the time started ticking. Our brains are not programmed for unknowns. Our brains are programmed for beginnings and ends. COVID brought a lot of uncertainty."
According to Dorman, adults struggled adapting to regular daily routines as restrictions began to lift.
The numbers for adults seeking mental health services continued to rise because now people were aware of some mental health issues they had not been before, Dorman said.
"What we saw was that there were for the first time maybe folks were starting to recognize that they were struggling," she said. "That as they're starting to put one foot back in front of the other, maybe they were feeling more anxiety than they'd ever felt before because now they had to step out of their home which had been comfortable in this time."
According to Dorman, COVID showed that people all experience mental health in a different way.
"What I think COVID did was it helped us view connection differently," she said. "It helped us to be able to bring language to some of the things that we were all experiencing. I think in some terms it talks about like leveling the playing field for mental health. Leveling the playing field in a way that we had language to put to what people were feeling." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the impact of COVID-19 on mental health, services, and providers, which aligns primarily with the Health category, while also touching on school-related aspects (Education).

title: MidShore Meals til Monday celebrates growth
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
MidShore Meals til Monday celebrates growth

 March 31, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 497
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — MidShore Meals til Monday Executive Director Pam Allen understands times are difficult."Times are hard for everybody," she said at a ribbon-cutting event for the organization's new Race Street location March 27. "And it's doing our part to try to make things a little easier. To free up money in the household so that they don't have to spend all of their money on food."
MidShore Meals til Monday is a nonprofit that provides food for food-insecure children and families in Dorchester County. The organization provides students with bags of food to take home on the weekends and offers food giveaways to families. The program also provides emergency food to people in need via appointment.
Allen said providing food to families in the community allows those families to put $20 or $40 dollars toward other necessities, like paying bills or getting new clothes for their children.
"Whatever else they need," Allen said. "It's just freeing up some money in that household so that they can provide the other things that they need."
The ribbon-cutting with the Dorchester Chamber of Commerce celebrated Meals til Monday's new digs on Race Street, which the nonprofit moved into at the end of August, as well as its new refrigerated truck.
Meals til Monday Founder Leslie Bishop said the new truck will allow the nonprofit to expand it's mission to bring perishable food to children and families in need.
Last summer, Preston Automotive Group loaned the nonprofit a truck to provide summer meals to children in partnership with Dorchester County Public Schools and Caroline County Public Schools. Allen said with their very own truck this year — which was purchased using grants from a variety of organizations, including Preston Automotive Group — the organization will be able to continue that service this summer.
During the ribbon-cutting event, community members shared support and hopes for the continued growth of the nonprofit.
"I just think it's terrific and hope it will continue for many years," Dorchester County Register of Wills Terry Wheatley said.
In her speech, Bishop talked about the growth of Meals til Monday so far. She shared how she started Meals til Monday out of her kitchen eight years ago.
At that time, the nonprofit was packing bags for 25 Vienna Elementary School students. "Now it's 1,000 bags a week going home to hungry kids in Dorchester County Public Schools," she said.
Meals til Monday volunteer Merrill Schuetz remembers helping to pack about 150 meal bags per week at the Judy Center about seven years ago. When she started volunteering, the nonprofit wasn't yet offering the food giveaways to families.
"So that has expanded exponentially," she said.
Schuetz finds the organization's growth exciting. Unlike when she started volunteering, the program now has many organizations that come in to volunteer, she said.
"The word is out there now, and I think it's so refreshing to know that there are so many people that want to help, that are interested in donating their time and their energy for this type of program," she said. "It's exciting." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts
author: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com
content:
Community rallies to support food bank after federal cuts

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Josh Shannon jshannon@chespub.com | Section: State News 
 
 437
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since news broke last week that federal cuts would deprive the Food Bank of Delaware of 19 truckloads of urgently needed food, the organization has seen a surge of new donors and an increase in visitors to its website looking for ways to help."We have gotten so much groundswell of support from people that maybe didn't even know about the Food Bank, but are learning about the Food Bank now and not wanting to see people in the State of Delaware go hungry," CEO Cathy Kanefsky said.
That community support was on full display Tuesday evening during an emergency food drive sponsored by Newark-area legislators. A steady stream of cars pulled up at the Food Bank's Glasgow warehouse to drop off food donations that were then unloaded by legislators and other volunteers.
Inside, 25 volunteers helped sort and pack food.
"Tonight has been so heartwarming to just stand here and watch all the legislators that have come out to support, and all the people that are coming with food," Kanefsky said.
Food banks across the country were left reeling last week when the Trump administration abruptly paused $500 million in funding for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Emergency Food Assistance Program.
For the Food Bank of Delaware, from April to June alone, the canceled shipments equate to 750,000 pounds of food or 900,000 meals that would have directly benefited residents across the state.
State Rep. Eric Morrison, who has been a regular Food Bank volunteer for 20 years, organized Tuesday's food drive.
"When I learned that they are going to be losing about 50 percent of their food, everybody felt frustrated and I thought I have to do something. Somebody has to do something," Morrison said. "Tonight, we can bring in a lot of food, but we can also bring in awareness, which is really important."
One in seven Delawareans, including one in five children, are food insecure, he added.
"I think some people may have certain prejudices or misconceptions about who uses the Food Bank, but we're talking about your grandparents, your children, your next door neighbor with a disability. It's a lot of people," he said.
Morrison added that in Dover, there are ongoing discussions about how much the state will have to step in to make up for lost funding to the Food Bank and other programs affected by federal cuts.
"It's very hard right now, because with the federal administration, everything is just very day-by-day," he said. "Every day, we're waking up to something new."
Residents can visit fbd.org to learn how they can help the Food Bank.
"We're facing some interesting times, and we've all got to take care of each other," Morrison said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Willow's world: Mom pens 'hopeful, meaningful story' about daughter
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Willow's world: Mom pens 'hopeful, meaningful story' about daughter

 April 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 502
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Haley Queen's daughter Willow is just 5-years-old, but Queen is preparing for a future where Willow, who is autistic, will be all grown up.Queen just released her first book, a novel entitled "Beyond the Silence." The Elkton mom said it's written from the context of hope for all autistic children, but to also help the rest of the world understand the challenges for parents of these children and the children themselves.
"It's only 67 pages," Queen said. "It's not a long story but it's a meaningful one."
"Beyond the Silence" introduces the reader to Emma, a youngster who is non verbal. Willow was the inspiration for Emma. However, after a certain age, Queen creates a new life for Emma, which she hopes will be Willow's future.
Emma finds her own success in school and the world in spite of her struggles. Queen said Willow is starting down that same path.
"She's definitely learning," Queen said of her daughter who is now obsessed with a velcro-styled matching game that has taught her colors, letters and numbers. "She will be able to learn things as she gets older."
What Queen doesn't know yet --but hopes for — is how independent Willow could become. So she wrote out those hopes and dreams through Emma.
"My big worry for her is not being able to take care of herself," she said. It's the same for many parents of autistic children in Cecil County.
According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 1 in 36 children in the United States is diagnosed as autistic. Maryland's Department of Health reports some 47% of 8-year-old children in the state have been diagnosed.
April is Autism Awareness Month. It's a neurological disorder that affects how children learn and interact with the world. It manifests itself differently in each child. With recent changes in how autism is diagnosed it has led to some adults now learning they are autistic.
Many autistic children display repetitive movements. They expect the world to be the same around them every day and any change to that schedule causes them to be afraid or even angry.
Queen said those who read her book will perhaps get a better understanding and be less judgmental and more empathetic.
"Maybe people will be a little more open to the possibility that there's something different, not wrong with that child," she said, adding, "That it's not a typical temper tantrum."
Queen suggests people learn about the disorder especially if there is someone in your family or circle of friends that is affected.
"If you don't know how to interact ask, research, learn," she said.
Beyond the Silence is available on Amazon in paperback and ebook formats. Queen is looking forward to holding book signing events while, at the same time, working on her next book.
"I'm hosting a giveaway through Facebook," she said. "I'm giving away four copies."
Meanwhile, "Willow's Walk For Autism" is set for April 19 at Meadow Park in Elkton from 11 a.m. until 3 p.m. All proceeds will benefit Thomson Estates Elementary School.
She can be reached through email at: haleyqueen64@gmail.com 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on autism, a neurological health condition, and discusses awareness, diagnosis statistics, and support resources, making Health the most appropriate classification.

title: Kent Island resident seeks donations for Leukemia & Lymphoma Society
author: SUBMITTED NEWS
content:
Kent Island resident seeks donations for Leukemia & Lymphoma Society

 April 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SUBMITTED NEWS | Section: News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — A Kent Island resident has been nominated as a 2025 Visionary of the Year candidate for the nationally-recognized Leukemia & Lymphoma Society.The Visionaries of the Year campaign is an annual nationwide competition in which participants have 10 weeks to raise funds in support of the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society's mission to improve the quality of life for blood cancer patients and their families, and the ultimate goal, to cure blood cancer.
Kent Island resident Brittany Timms was recognized by a peer as a community leader in the area and was nominated to run as a candidate in this year's campaign — and is the only candidate representing the Eastern Shore community.
"To get local businesses involved, we have crafted the Neighbors for Tomorrow initiative, an opportunity for our small community to come together and show the world the strength and compassion we have as a small town when we unite for a cause," she said.
From March 20 to May 30, Timms and her campaign team, Cure Chasers, are aiming to reach their fundraising goal of $200,000.
"Why did I take on this rewarding challenge?" Timms said. "My grandmother, Janet Leichling, was diagnosed with blood cancer in early 2024. Thanks to the groundbreaking research and FDA-approved treatments funded by the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society, she is now in remission. Her story, though, is just one of many. My team and I are committed to raising funds that will not only advance research for better treatments but, ultimately, help us wipe out cancer altogether."
Visionaries of the Year has helped invest more than $1.8 billion in cutting-edge research worldwide, fueling nearly every critical advancement in blood cancer treatment that spans the most promising cancer research. For 75 years, LLS has been making measurable progress across each of its mission focus areas of research, patient support, and advocacy, according to Timms.
NEIGHBORS FOR TOMORROW
As the only candidate representing the Eastern Shore, Timms is asking for the community to band together and show the world how Kent Island shows up for those in need.
For any local businesses that contribute to one of the below levels, they will be recognized as follows for their generous support:
$5,000 — Logo recognition in the Kent Island Bay Times Record Observer and the Neighbors for Tomorrow website; sponsor recognition leading up to and at the Washington, D.C., Visionaries of the Year Grand Finale Gala; and six seats at the Grand Finale Gala in Washington, D.C., on May 30 (1,000 high net-worth attendees).
$2,500 — Logo recognition in the Kent Island Bay Times Record Observer and the Neighbors for Tomorrow website.
$1,000 — Name recognition in the Kent Island Bay Times Record Observer and the Neighbors for Tomorrow website.
$500 — Name recognition on the Neighbors for Tomorrow website.
Donations of any amount help move the needle closer to a world without cancer.
To learn more about Visionaries of the Year or the opportunity to support, reach out to brittanytimms.lls@outlook.com. You can also donate or learn more at https://pages.lls.org/voy/nca/dcmetro25/btimms 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Youth mental health initiatives see minimal cuts
author: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service
content:
Youth mental health initiatives see minimal cuts

 April 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: SASHA ALLEN Capital News Service | Section: State News 
 
 771
 Words 

 Read News Document

 ANNAPOLIS — Maryland mental health advocates and providers are relieved coming out of this year's legislative session, where state lawmakers decided against a drastic cut in funding to the state's year-old, big-money program aimed at improving the mental health of its young people.The Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports, created under the state's ambitious and expensive education reform plan called the Blueprint for Maryland's Future, will receive $70 million from the state's fiscal year 2026 budget to award mental health providers in its second round of grants. That's up from the $40 million Gov. Wes Moore originally suggested spending.
But with some money left over from funding this past fiscal year, the consortium plans to allocate closer to $98 million in grants. Legislators previously allocated $119.7 million over two years to set up the consortium and issued its first $111 million of grants in February 2024.
Partly as a result of those grants, more than 80% of Maryland public schools now have some sort of mental health service available for students. And mental health advocates said the additional funding means the state's effort will continue to reach a large percentage of the state's children.
"This is a critical investment that's ensuring students in every corner of our state have the resources and support necessary to learn and thrive," said Dan Martin, senior director of public policy at the Mental Health Association of Maryland. "We couldn't be happier."
The consortium provides mental health funding for dozens of services, including in-school counseling, substance abuse treatment and peer support groups for families and students.
But at the beginning of this year's difficult legislative session where the General Assembly would have to fill a $3 billion budget hole, Moore proposed a spending plan that allocated only $40 million to the youth mental health effort — even though he once proposed the program should receive $130 million for fiscal year 2026.
The General Assembly, however, passed a bill on the last day of the legislative session that added $30 million to the youth mental health budget on top of what Moore had proposed, leaving many relieved for the future of the program.
Sen. Katie Fry Hester, a Democrat representing Montgomery and Howard counties, said this decision was crucial for the future of the consortium and the youth mental health programs it funds.
"I think when you're trying to address the mental health needs of the entire state, you can't really do it piecemeal," Hester said.
If funding for the consortium had been limited to the amount suggested in Moore's budget, "you would have to redo the entire program," Hester added.
The consortium's grant allocations are designed around a "hub and spoke" model that aims to include community organizations in the program. The hubs, or organizations already established in Maryland's counties, including churches and community centers, help promote and run the services of the spokes, or mental health programs. Both are funded through consortium grants.
"The hub and spoke model would not have worked at $40 million," Hester said.
While the community organizations are in different stages of operation in each county, Mark Luckner, executive director of the Maryland Community Health Resources Commission, said the funding provided will allow for the program to move closer to full implementation this upcoming year.
Luckner said a good number of active service providers have applied for the second round of funding, which the consortium is expected to issue by June 30.
The initial 127 grants were projected to serve about 150,000 people, "and they're well on their way to do that globally," Luckner said at Thursday's consortium meeting.
Luckner said he believes within two years, as many as 22 of the state's 24 jurisdictions will either have a fully operational or almost fully operational youth mental health hub.
"We should just take a moment and celebrate that accomplishment that the consortium is achieving," Luckner said.
Service providers agree. Jan Guszynski is the project manager for Prosper, an app that, under Uneo Health, provides mental health check ins-for adolescents. The app received $1.4 million grants to provide services in Prince George's, Frederick and Calvert counties.
Before the legislation was passed confirming $70 million in consortium funding for fiscal year 2026, Guszynski said she was worried for the future of not only mental health services but for the students using them.
"I really, really hope that we do not see these resources shuttered or too heavily impacted as time goes on," Guszynski said. "Because it's hugely important."
Those resources won't likely get shuttered or too heavily impacted if the General Assembly sticks with the outline it set in the budget it just passed, which projects $100 million in youth mental health funding in fiscal year 2027 and $100 million annually after that. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on state funding for youth mental health services, describing grants, program implementation, and impact on students, which aligns most closely with the Health topic, though it also touches on education settings.

title: Fahmi aims to close gaps as Talbot County's new health officer
author: Konner Metz
content:
Fahmi aims to close gaps as Talbot County's new health officer

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 487
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Since becoming Talbot County's health officer, Fahmi Fahmi is focusing on listening first."I get to learn from different points of views, different intakes that can make my decision a little bit more refined," he said.
Fahmi assumed the leadership role at the Talbot County Health Department last month, succeeding Maria Maguire, who stepped down in October. But Fahmi isn't looking for a complete overhaul.
"If it's not broken, I'm not going to fix it," he said.
Fahmi, formerly the department's deputy medical health officer, will oversee public health initiatives and community programs in his new role. He says his early goals are to close gaps in areas such as senior services and children's vision offerings.
Talbot County's average age was 50.9 in 2023 and has slightly increased each year since 2020, per census data, a trend Fahmi recognizes. The department is already working to address senior needs, he said. For instance, staff members team up with emergency responders to bring a mobile integrated health program and in-home health care to seniors who have repeated ER visits.
Carrie Ottey, director of senior services, says Fahmi isn't just an intelligent and knowledgeable physician, but also a down to earth and invested member of the community.
"Dr. Fahmi's been really open to listening to some new ideas about how we can better serve the senior population, and especially those that are in the outlying rural areas," Ottey added.
Fahmi noted challenges Talbot County faces to provide quality health care, such as transportation and housing. "Being in a rural area is sweet and sour," he said.
A recent trip to Tilghman Island showed Fahmi that many areas are without reliable internet, which can serve as an additional barrier to health care for some.
"Even though it's challenging, it's exciting because it makes me think about solutions," Fahmi said.
The new health officer says the pandemic "exposed weaknesses in the whole system."
Josh Weber, the health department's public information officer, said health officials "tend to go back into the shadows" following periods such as the coronavirus pandemic, during which they were on the front lines. He and Fahmi hope the department can increase its community presence.
"Hopefully with Dr. Fahmi coming into play and creating more of a strategic plan going forward for the next three to 10 years, we want to be more visible consistently," Weber said. "We want to make sure that we are embedded in this community, that everyone knows we are here to serve. Not just in times of crisis, but all the time."
For Fahmi, his goals of closing senior service gaps and building rapport with residents begin with the health department's employees. In just a handful of weeks on the job, Fahmi says he's noticed their selflessness and dedication to serving the public.
"I am so lucky," Fahmi said. "Even if I imagine a group of people that I would handpick, I wouldn't come as close (to) the ones that I have currently in the health department." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the county health officer, public health initiatives, senior services, and community health programs, which aligns directly with the Health topic. It also touches on county administration, but health is the primary subject.

title: At Easton YMCA, community fights Parkinson's and builds a family
author: Konner Metz
content:
At Easton YMCA, community fights Parkinson's and builds a family

 April 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 738
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Two years ago, Roy Weedon was diagnosed with a severe form of Parkinson's, a progressive neurological disease that often causes tremors and slowed movement.Roy's wife, Zoulika, said the decline in his health was clear. But while there is no cure, the couple learned exercise is often recommended to prevent symptoms from accelerating.
So Roy, now 80, began taking exercise classes at the Easton YMCA dedicated for those with Parkinson's or related diseases. It's been a life-changer, his wife said, and not only for the health benefits.
"The fact that he's able to walk, to talk, to have a social life, to get dressed and all that kind of thing is important," Zoulika Weedon said.
The YMCA's exercise classes boost quality of life and level off physical and mental health declines for many seniors with Parkinson's. Zoulika Weedon said much of the credit goes to Wendy Palmer, whom she calls the "driving force" behind the classes and the community that's been built within them.
Palmer, director of chronic disease and prevention programs at the YMCA of the Chesapeake, leads a group of over 60 people at the Easton YMCA in a five-day-a-week program. There are two days of Rock Steady Boxing classes, two days of cycling courses and one day in the water swimming.
The classes are neuroprotective, Palmer said, and help improve flexibility, agility, range of motion, strength and balance.
And the group of people she trains with daily aren't patients, or simply participants. They're truly athletes, Palmer said.
"With a diagnosis that can be very scary and don't know your future, you need somebody that's going to say 'Let's do this together, you're not alone,' Palmer said. "And that's what the Y always hopes to provide."
LEVELING THE DECLINE
Mike Simpson has been in the Easton YMCA's Rock Steady Boxing program for three years. He has progressive supranuclear palsy, or PSP, a disease that shares some symptoms with Parkinson's.
PSP has unique effects, such as eye movement challenges and backward falls. Simpson said since he began the YMCA classes, "it's made a big difference" in leveling off his health declines.
While Simpson has a Parkinson's "offshoot" as he calls it, many of the Rock Steady boxers have direct Parkinson's diagnoses.
According to the Parkinson's Foundation, nearly one million Americans have the disease, more than all other neurodegenerative diseases aside from Alzheimer's. That number is only expected to rise in the coming years, the foundation states.
April is Parkinson's Awareness Month, as nationwide and local organizations aim to raise awareness about the disease. Palmer and Rock Steady athletes were honored earlier this month by the Town of Easton with a proclamation.
Palmer said when the YMCA of the Chesapeake picked up Rock Steady Boxing, local experts took notice.
"Neurologists were like, 'Wow this is really helping. We're going to refer more people to you,'" Palmer recalled.
Palmer describes the boxing movements as a dance, pushing participants to develop balance and pattern recognition. On a Thursday afternoon this month, Palmer pushed the group to give it their all, even during the workout's final minutes.
"What we tell our boxers is you can do anything," Palmer said. "You can do anything for three minutes. That's a round, right?"
The Parkinson's exercise program started in 2018 with just four athletes and the boxing classes but has quickly grown to include multiple activities and 175 participants across the YMCA of the Chesapeake.
In Easton, class athletes, coaches and volunteers are creating a family just as much as they're battling Parkinson's.
'ALWAYS CONNECTED'
Simpson said he often encourages others to join the Easton YMCA's Parkinson's group.
"It's fun, a good group of people to work with. Gives you something to do when you're retired," Simpson said.
Between group texts and monthly lunches at the Chili's in town, the Easton YMCA has cultivated a community of Parkinson's athletes and family members.
When volunteers or residents with Parkinson's inquire about joining, Palmer tells them they're "about to meet the best people." It's a welcoming and encouraging community, one Palmer said is "always connected."
"It's a joy for me to be a part of this program. It has changed my life," Palmer said.
And for the athletes, the classes are a rewarding but challenging venture. Palmer acknowledges that progressive decline is a part of Parkinson's disease, but she and the other coaches at the YMCA ensure pessimism doesn't take over.
"It's something that can be scary," Palmer said. "But again, we're not here to say you can't do anything. We're going to find a way for you to do it." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Parkinson's disease, its impact on seniors, and a YMCA exercise program designed to improve physical and mental health, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Diving into Maryland’s cannabis data
author: MIKAYLA ROBERTS Capital News Service
content:
Diving into Maryland’s cannabis data

 April 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKAYLA ROBERTS Capital News Service | Section: News 
 
 430
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Now that marijuana is legal in Maryland, some lesser-known effects of its use are coming to light. Since 2022, the Maryland Cannabis Administration has conducted an annual survey, the Maryland Medical Cannabis Patient Survey, to collect data on these adverse effects.According to the latest survey released last month, over 4,400 respondents met the criteria for cannabis use disorder, or CUD — with more than half being women.
"There's always a fine line between misuse and abuse. So when you get into the abuse, you run the risk of meeting criteria for cannabis use disorder," said Dr. Bernard Ravitz, an addiction medicine specialist.
The criteria for CUD, according to Ravitz, includes the inability to cut down or control use despite the effects of the drug causing interpersonal, physical or psychological problems. Another major criteria is a significant amount of time spent in getting, using or recovering from cannabis — which usually results in failing to fulfill personal obligations.
"The key is for everyone in the healthcare arena to really try to educate our communities. We do a lot of outreach. We have programs through our hospitals that refer people to treatment programs," Ravitz said.
In some cases, marijuana use can lead to cannabis hyperemesis syndrome, a condition marked by episodic vomiting and abdominal pain due to prolonged use of high doses. Although the majority of respondents said they had never experienced CHS, just over 200 Marylanders, about 2% of those surveyed, reported that they had experienced the condition.
"We have many frequent visitors that have been diagnosed with cannabis hyperemesis syndrome that present in our emergency department, and they are treated symptomatically, usually with IV fluids and, if needed, some antiemetics that reduce the nausea and vomiting," Ravitz described.
Other than the lesser known health effects, there's a more pressing matter regarding the drug, according to Ravitz.
"The problem right now is with kids and the manufacturing of the synthetics that look like candy, and we're seeing an increase of overdose poisoning in children because of children getting a hold of the gummy looking cannabis medications that are now legally sold in the state of Maryland," Ravitz said.
The MCA's Maryland Cannabis Use Biannual Study, also released last month, details the number of cannabis-related calls to poison control has decreased for the first time in seven years — with nearly 80 fewer calls last year than 2023. However, from 2023 to 2024, calls involving infants aged five and under increased by almost 35%. And while cannabis use among minors is down 0.6%, there is still concern of the drug's effect on the developing brain of this vulnerable group. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on medical cannabis use disorder, health conditions like cannabis hyperemesis syndrome, and impacts on children, which aligns most closely with the Health topic, though it also touches on safety concerns.

title: Drones may be flying over rural Maryland soon for a good reason
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content:
Drones may be flying over rural Maryland soon for a good reason

 April 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 492
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Drones could soon help improve life across Maryland.That was the message from officials at last month's meeting of the Tri-County Council, comprised of Charles, Calvert and St. Mary's counties in Southern Maryland.
"So we're looking at using drones for medical package deliveries that help improve health outcomes among the rural communities in Maryland where transportation challenges can really get in the way of people getting the medicine they need," John Slaughter, director of the UAS Research and Operations Center at the University of Maryland, said at the April 24 meeting.
The state recently called on the center to lead a pilot program aimed at using drones to deliver prescriptions and other medical supplies to isolated residents of remote communities, such as Smith Island, a recent article published by UAS Research and Operations Center said.
The University of Maryland center, based at St. Mary's County Regional Airport in the town of California, is working with the state to establish a Chesapeake Unmanned Aircraft Systems Route Network, which will start by enabling crewed and uncrewed aircraft to safely share an aviation corridor spanning the Chesapeake Bay, the article stated.
Slaughter said that those who work for the network are refining some of these ideas, trying to understand what this would look like in action.
"Rules are pretty restrictive around them. But that's going to change in the next couple of years, and the possibility here is going to explode," Slaughter said. "So we're trying to look at what those things can do for the state. Everything from public sector things, health initiatives, law enforcement, fire, emergency medical services, but then commercial opportunities as well, deliveries, infrastructure inspections, agriculture, a lot of different things have to be done."
The current project has drones flying over long distances within the state.
"Seems easy, sounds easy, isn't easy," Slaughter said. "Technically, it's challenging, but regulatory, really challenging. So, getting the right equipment is huge for this, but, you know, that is costly, and that's what it's up to."
Slaughter believes this will bring Southern Maryland "up on the national stage."
"It's going to be a unique capability to go out into the field, set up a laboratory in the open air, and do work that can't be really done very easily on the ground," Slaughter said.
"This is something that is coming sooner rather than later, and what we want to do is help the state of Maryland be prepared for when the regulations evolve to support these type of operations in the long term," Ben Griffith, Chesapeake UAS Route Network Project Manager, said.
Griffith said that his staff wants to take the work that's being done in other states and bring it here to leverage ideas.
A final test flight that will fly over the bay from Southern Maryland, go to Crisfield, go over to Smith Island and come back is planned for around mid-September. That would be roughly 60 miles of travel for the aircraft — the same ones planned to be used in Southern Maryland. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on using drones to deliver medical supplies to rural residents, directly addressing health outcomes, with secondary mentions of public safety and government initiatives.

title: Women and Girls Fund presents 2025 awards, grants
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Women and Girls Fund presents 2025 awards, grants

 April 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 394
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — During its annual luncheon at the Tidewater Inn Monday, the Women and Girls Fund of the Mid-Shore presented its 2025 awards and annual grants.Kathy Deoudes was presented with the Women and Girls Fund Award. The annual award honors members of the community who have made contributions toward understanding and addressing women and girls' needs.
Deoudes, who retired in 2010 after spending seven years as a legislative aide for former Sen. E.J. Pipkin, currently serves as chair of the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health Board of Directors.
In her speech, Deoudes thanked her friends, family and colleagues for their support.
"And then to everyone else in this room, your philanthropy, your volunteerism and your compassion is what provides a safety net for members of our community who need it all the time or some of the time," she said. "And for that, I am very grateful."
For All Seasons President and CEO Beth Anne Dorman was presented with the Sheryl V. Kerr Award. Given in memory of Kerr, the award recognizes individuals or programs that are significant to women, according to the Women and Girls Fund.
In her speech, Dorman said mental health matters and spoke about how important it is that women remember to prioritize self care.
"To know that it's OK if you need support, its OK to reach out and that sometimes the people that are leading and the people that are smiling and holding things need to be checked in on too," she said.
The Women and Girls Fund, which uses pooled resources to improve the lives of women and girls on the Mid-Shore, aims to support programs and initiatives geared toward women and girls and facilitate collaboration and partnership among organizations.
During the luncheon, a total of $64,970 in grants were distributed among 18 organizations.
Women and Girls Fund President Beth Spurry said the organizations recognized at the luncheon are ones that invest in young girls' ability and right to "soar."
"They will be the leaders of tomorrow," she said. "So a prom dress or a 5K race on its own doesn't save a life, but being told that you are valued, that you deserve the spotlight too and that you are strong and can do hard things, may just give these girls — who will be women — the raw material to move beyond the barriers imposed on them from the circumstances of their lives." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community fund that distributes grants and highlights mental health and self‑care for women and girls, making health the most relevant category, though it also touches on economic support and youth development.

title: Cambridge nursing facility faces complaints about care
author: Maggie Trovato
content:
Cambridge nursing facility faces complaints about care

 May 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Maggie Trovato | Section: Local News 
 
 1614
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — When Dorchester County native Danny Frazier lived at Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab in Cambridge, he loved having visitors.From high school buddies to family members, Frazier — who moved into Mallard Bay in his mid-60s after receiving an ALS diagnosis — treasured those visits, his sister Debbie Linthicum said.
Those visits were among the only reasons Frazier stayed at Mallard Bay from June 2023 until his death in May 2024.
"We talked a few times about moving him to another facility because we were so dissatisfied," Linthicum said. "And his biggest concern was, he said, 'I really love when people come to see me, and I'm afraid if I'm in Easton, it's a little bit of a further drive, they may not come.'"
Linthicum said when Frazier lived at Mallard Bay, he experienced inadequate care from staff, particularly when it came to food. She said when Frazier was no longer able to feed himself, there were instances when staff would bring his food but not feed it to him.
They are not alone in their experience with Mallard Bay.
From a lack of care for residents to staffing problems, residents, their family members and former staff members say they have tried to advocate for the residents of Mallard Bay but have not seen change. On top of that, it has been 2½ years since the last federal inspection of the facility, and the state agency responsible for overseeing nursing homes faces a lawsuit alleging it has failed to inspect nursing facilities and allowed complaints against facilities to pile up.
Former Mallard Bay geriatric nursing assistant Deanna States-Meninger said she spoke with Dorchester County State's Attorney Amanda Leonard about the facility and filed a complaint against the facility with the Maryland Office of Health Care Quality.
States-Meninger said that when she worked at Mallard Bay, management wouldn't do anything in response to her complaints.
"I would go down the chain, and it seemed like it just got pushed off," she said.
In an April interview with The Star Democrat, Del. Tom Hutchinson (R-Caroline, Dorchester, Talbot, Wicomico) confirmed Mallard Bay had been reported to the state. He said the Office of Health Care Quality, which is within the Maryland Department of Health, was looking into the complaint.
Key Health, which manages Mallard Bay, originally agreed to an interview and was sent a list of questions from The Star Democrat. However, the company later canceled the interview and sent a statement sharing its goals.
"Since Key Health began managing the facility in November 2022, we've worked hard to build a warm, supportive environment where residents feel valued and staff feel proud," the statement said. "... Like in any healthcare setting, we may occasionally hear concerns, but we always take them seriously. However, the voices of those with positive experiences — of recovery, comfort, and dignity are vast."
The statement said Key Health remains "fully transparent with regulators," accountable to its standards and committed to "every person who calls Mallard Bay home."
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, reviews for Mallard Bay are middling.
STEPHEN'S STORY
After a swimming accident this past summer left Stephen Nowlan, 54, paralyzed from the torso down, he spent three months in Mallard Bay's rehabilitation program.
Although he was excited to go there after hearing about "how incredible it was," he said it ended up being nothing like he expected.
Nowlan said there were not enough staff for the number of residents, and he would often wait a long time to receive help or care.
On his first day at the facility, Nowlan spent a long time waiting for his medication in pain. He said when he finally received his medication, the staff member who brought it didn't administer it.
"She put my pills on my table," he said. "But I can't move. … She put them on the table and left."
Nowlan said that when he shared his concerns with the higher-ups at Mallard Bay, they gave him "all kinds of excuses."
"I mean there's no excuse," Nowlan said.
Although Nowlan said he had good physical therapists and a few good aides, he often found himself waiting for care or simply not getting enough of it.
Nowlan said there were occasions when he spent physical therapy sessions getting a shower from the physical therapists because the care staff hadn't given him a shower.
He left Mallard Bay in December after three months because his insurance stopped covering his stay.
About eight months after his accident, Nowlan said he is able to move again but is considered quadriplegic because he has altered sensation in every part of his body. He attends physical therapy three times a week and expects to walk again one day.
BRITTANY'S STORY
Brittany Fletcher's father Michael Prager, 76, has lived at Mallard Bay since September.
Fletcher said her father had brain surgery for normal pressure hydrocephalus in early April and his doctors asked him to go on the Mediterranean diet for his brain health. According to the Cleveland Clinic, the Mediterranean diet "emphasizes plant-based foods and healthy fats."
That is not what Prager is being served at Mallard Bay, Fletcher said.
"They are giving him sugar drinks and cake, and the meals are very starchy," she said.
Fletcher said her father is learning to walk again. She said Mallard Bay left him alone in the shower, even though he is a fall risk.
And Fletcher said she has not had a great experience when it comes to communicating her concerns to Mallard Bay and its management.
Fletcher said she has thought about moving her father to a different nursing home, but funds are limited, which makes that harder to do.
"And I'm assuming anywhere is better than this at this point," she said. "But I don't know."
DEANNA'S STORY
Deanna States-Meninger said that after six weeks working as a geriatric nursing assistant at Mallard Bay early this year, she quit her job.
States-Meninger said she made the decision due to a culture of neglect and lack of care, consistent understaffing, overworking and unresponsive management.
According to the Code of Maryland Regulations, the ratio of nursing service personnel on duty providing care to residents of a nursing home may not be less than one to 15. States-Meninger said there was one night when she was left to care for an entire floor of 45 patients by herself for four hours.
"It made me feel like I was a failure," she said, "like I couldn't answer all the bells and help the people when they needed it."
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, the nursing staff turnover in a given year at Mallard Bay averages 71.2% compared to the 41.6% state average and the 47.5% national average.
States-Meninger called her job at Mallard Bay an "awful" one.
"I can't tell you how many nights I left in tears," she said.
DEFICIENCIES FOUND
According to the U.S. Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, Mallard Bay has an overall three-star rating, scoring "above average" (four stars) for health inspections, "much below average" (one star) for staffing and "below average" (two stars) for quality measures.
Concerns with the 160-bed facility pre-date Key Health taking over in November 2022.
In August 2022, seven deficiencies were found during a federal inspection, including failure to report incidents of alleged abuse to law enforcement, failure to serve meals as requested by residents and failure to provide treatment or services to prevent or heal pressure ulcers.
In an email April 30, Maryland Department of Health Director of Communications Chase Cook confirmed the 2022 federal inspection report is the most recent inspection report. This means there have not been any federal inspections since Key Health took over management.
In Maryland, the Office of Health Care Quality within the state's Department of Health is responsible for the oversight of nursing homes, which includes licensure, certification and investigation of complaints.
Last year, a lawsuit was filed against the Maryland Department of Health alleging the department has allowed more than 100 nursing facilities to go without an annual inspection for more than four years and allowed thousands of un-investigated complaints against nursing facilities to pile up.
According to the class action complaint, the plaintiffs argue that when the department fails to complete its oversight responsibilities, "dangerously poor-quality care within nursing facilities goes undetected and uncorrected."
The Department of Health has not responded to questions from The Star Democrat about Mallard Bay, the department's process for addressing complaints against nursing homes and how it ensures nursing homes in Maryland are safe for its residents.
In 2018, the Maryland General Assembly passed the Maryland Nursing Home Resident Protection Act to ensure complaints are addressed in a timely manner.
Specifically, the bill requires the Maryland Department of Health conduct a full inspection of each licensed nursing home in the state at least once a year and initiate investigations into complaints alleging actual harm within 10 business days of receiving the complaint.
The bill states the department shall receive 50 new full-time positions within the Office of Health Care Quality over a five-year period. These hirings were supposed to begin in fiscal year 2020, months before the COVID-19 pandemic shut down the country.
Sen. Stephen Hershey (R-Kent, Queen Anne's, Cecil, and Caroline), who was a sponsor of the 2018 bill, said in an email that this is an issue he still has concerns about. He mentioned a bill passed by the Maryland Senate this year — which he also sponsored — that requires the Department of Health to report inspection data to General Assembly committees.
"We've been extremely concerned with the lack of responsiveness from the Department of Health's efforts to ensure residents and families that nursing homes can provide safe, high-quality care," he said.
Hershey said consistent oversight is important when it comes to determining whether nursing facilities are providing high-quality care.
"Regulatory agencies must work collaboratively to ensure bad actors cannot operate unchecked and that residents receive safe, quality care," he said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on patient care, staffing, and regulatory oversight at a nursing home, which are core issues of the health sector.

title: Mid-Shore Behavioral Health answers questions from County Commissioners
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Mid-Shore Behavioral Health answers questions from County Commissioners

 May 14, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 626
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — At their Tuesday meeting, the Caroline County Commissioners talked about homelessness, housing, budget and community interaction with Katie Dilley, chief executive officer, and Ann Simpers, behavioral health coordinator at Mid Shore Behavioral Health.Dilley and Simpers presented organization accomplishments, partnerships and budgets for fiscal years 2025 and 2026 to the commissioners. The presentation was part of an effort by the organization to secure the renewal of its agreement to serve at the county's core service agency.
Commissioners noticed a $5 million increase in funding paid out by Mid-Shore Behavioral Health to partner organizations from fiscal year 2024 to fiscal year 2025.
For fiscal year 2026, federal and state funding to Mid Shore Behavioral Health jumps to $25 million from $21 million. But Dilley and Simpers warned that there could be modifications to the organization's budget with decreases coming from the federal government.
Commission Vice President Larry Porter questioned Dilley and Simpers on exactly how the funding is distributed among partner organizations.
"I'm just trying to wrap my head around all of these different organizations, and how it all comes together and how we make sure that we're not duplicating money that goes somewhere else," Porter said.
According to Commissioners President Travis Breeding, the commissioners wanted to ensure county funds were not allocated to efforts already funded by Mid Shore Behavioral Health.
Breeding said in an interview that state and federal agencies have better abilities to make sure the funds are being appropriately used by the organizations than the county does.
Dilley assured the commissioners of Mid Shore Behavioral Health's "stringent" funding process.
"Each program that we specifically monitor and procure dollars through, we have a very stringent contracting process, deliverable process statement of work that we agree to uphold to the state," Dilley said. "So, we monitor, report monthly, quarterly, we get financials, we get their financial auditing, we go out and do site visits. If there's a concern anywhere along the way of data showing that things are moving in the wrong direction, we're like, 'Hold up, we've got to regroup here.'"
The commissioners also asked specifically about the Point-In-Time count conducted by Mid Shore Behavioral Health in January.
The count is an annual survey that measures homelessness across the U.S. This year, Mid Shore Behavioral Health's Continuum of Care team contributed by gathering data from individuals in encampments, shelters and temporary housing in Talbot, Kent, Dorchester, Caroline and Queen Anne's counties.
According to the count, the total number of people experiencing homelessness on the Mid-Shore sits at 195, with 179 people in sheltered locations and 16 in unsheltered locations.
"Are the people that you come across in your data with the homeless population, like is there a percentage to say, 'Hey is this affordability process, or is it a mental health or social issues that that impacted my life.' That's the data that we would like to know, and we just don't seem to get that," Commissioner Frank Bartz said.
According to Dilley, the Department of Housing and Urban Development determines the funding that communities receive with an annual cost of living check.
"So, depending on where you fall in the region, they have a different allocation for what resources they'll give to our organization to make sure that we can appropriately house individuals that we have funding for. We have an ear-marked amount of funding and slots for individuals to be placed in housing.
"So, that dollar shifts based on what the trends in the market are showing, and obviously that's going up, but I think what one thing we're also seeing that the number one thing that our community members have identified as a concern is the cost of living. And that's for individuals that are housed, not housed."
Commissioners said the core service agency agreement will be added to next weeks action agenda for approval. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on Mid‑Shore Behavioral Health discussing funding, services, and homelessness data with county commissioners, focusing on behavioral health programs and budgets, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Ideas from loss bring care to veterans, families in need
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Ideas from loss bring care to veterans, families in need

 May 21, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 530
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Lucas Nagel was a young man who was loved by his community. Lucas was veteran of the U.S. Army, he deployed twice with the Army Reserves, both times at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba.He then went on to serve as a Corporal with the Caroline County Sheriff's Office and as a school resource officer at Colonel Richardson High School.
Nagel died of suicide in 2022, but his family continued his legacy through the Lucas Nagel Foundation.
The Lucas Nagel Foundation, established in 2023, was created to bring awareness to Post Traumatic Stress Disorder that first responders and veterans experience throughout their lives.
Nagel's father, Milton Nagel, said the idea of starting the foundation came from family and friends in the community.
"When you experience a loss like we did, you can have two different reactions," Milton Nagel said. "You can become an introvert and just go off and mourn on your own, or you can use it as a catalyst to take action and to try to do what you can.
"We needed to come up with a website and start to get the word out and bring help to increase awareness to the issue and try to raise money to provide resources for first responders, veterans and families that need it, and to break the stigma and be part of the ever increasing movement to create change on how they are treated and dealt with when they are exposed to traumatic events and when they need help."
While the foundation is still in the stages of raising money, it offers multiple resources that people can use if they experience PTSD.
"What we ultimately want to do is to be able to financially support peer support teams, critical incident response teams that that come in and it's peer to peer and they deep brief first responders after traumatic events."
The foundation does work for first responders, they recommended multiple partner organizations for veterans and their families to receive help at. One of these is Tragedy Assistance Program for Survivors.
TAPS is a national nonprofit that specializes in helping veterans and family member of military veterans.
Bonnie Carroll established TAPS in 1994. She was motivated by the death of her husband, Brigadier General Tom Carroll, in a 1992 Army plane crash.
Like Milton Nagel, Carroll transformed her loss into a mission.
According to Carroll, what matters to TAPS when supporting families is reminding theses families that it "doesn't matter how, or where or why the person died. What matters is that their life included service.
"We honor and care for all those who are grieving the loss. So, really is very broad support to honor lives lived in service. We come right alongside what the military provides in rendering final honors, providing a final resting place and administering benefits to those who are eligible and then we expect expand that as a private organization all at no cost to the family."
TAPS provides peer-based emotional support groups that helps families cope with their loss. The nonprofit also provides a 24/7 helpline for suicide loss survivors and hosts many in-person functions.
Carroll described the programs they provide as "wonderful." She said the programs give people a chance to meet others who have experienced similar losses. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on PTSD awareness, mental health resources, and support for veterans and first responders, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Thanks for support of veterans
author: Staff Writer
content:
Thanks for support of veterans

 May 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 June 2025 is National PTSD Awareness month. The campaign highlights recognition of the PTSD stress disorder, veteran suicide and the need for veterans' treatment courts which are the backstop for the first two issues as we try to "catch them before they fall."Thank you to Sens. Steve Hersey and Johnny Mautz, Dels. Chris Adams, Thomas Hutchinson and Steven Arentz and the District 3 Public Defender Attorney, Tamara Stofa, for participating in June 2025 National PTSD Awareness campaign.
Sens. Hersey and Mautz and Dels. Adams, Arentz and Hutchinson presented General Assembly citations promoting PTSD awareness to Ms. Stofa from the District Public Defenders Office for District 3. A huge thank you to administrative judge for District 3 courts, John E. Nunn, for allowing us to present our interest in exploring the possibility of prompting the creation of a Regional Veterans District 3 Court venue.
A Regional Veterans Treatment Court would have served the veterans living in Cecil, Caroline, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties. We also are grateful for the support for developing a Veterans Treatment Court over the last year from the following: state Sens. Gallion, Mautz, Hersey and Del. Christopher Adams, The Military Order of the Purple Heart Chapter of the Delmarva, The Veterans of Foreign Wars District 4, Queen Anne's County VAMSA Center, The American Red Cross of the Delmarva Peninsula, United Way of Kent and Caroline Counties; National Alliance on Mental Illness ("NAMI") of Columbia, Maryland, and Easter Seals of MD/DC/VA.
In addition, huge thanks to the county councils in Cecil, Caroline, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties; the states Attorney's Offices of Cecil and Caroline and Queen Anne's counties; the county sheriffs of Cecil, Caroline, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot, and the Maryland Sheriffs Association membership for supporting the proposals for expanding the Maryland Veterans Treatment Court program in Maryland.
Unfortunately, the current "financial landscape" in Maryland has hampered the grant funding needed to prompt the creation of new Regional Veterans Treatment Courts in District 3, District 4 (southern Maryland) and District 12 (western Maryland) that we had advocated for.
We can keep this in the limelight by supporting PTSD awareness and our afflicted veterans.
JOSHUA MARKS
Mount Airy

title: Impressed with quality of care
author: Staff Writer
content:
Impressed with quality of care

 May 24, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox

 Words
