title: Beating the heat: drive delivers fans, air conditioning to those in need
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Beating the heat: drive delivers fans, air conditioning to those in need

 July 28, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Dorchester 
 
 475
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — During a summer of extreme temperatures, the Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc., the Iota Chi Zeta Chapter, and the Dorchester County Health Department have joined forces to provide air conditioners and fans to residents who may otherwise go without.The FANtastic Fan and A/C Drive started in June when temperatures reached upwards of 90 degrees.
"Those temperatures were really, really extreme," said Tavonya Chester with the Dorchester County Department of Social Services. "And then, Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Incorporated was like, 'Man, just imagine if you didn't have an AC.' Just imagine, right?"
Drive organizers began collecting box fans and smaller air conditioning unites to donate to neighbors in need.
"If you're saying, 'Oh, it ain't that bad outside' cut your AC off. Cut it off. And then you know exactly how hot it is and how desperate people may be to have an air conditioner to cool their home off," Chester said.
So far, 12 air conditioners have been distributed, along with many more fans, thanks to overwhelming community support.
A grant from the City of Cambridge funded 10 air conditioners, which must be distributed within city limits.
"What I want to say is that the community has overwhelmingly stepped up and has done a very good job with donating fans and ACs. It makes me want to cry," Chester said.
While the drive is open to all residents, Chester wants to ensure those taking advantage of the program truly need it. Because of this, the elderly, critically ill individuals, and families with young children take priority when it comes to receiving an air conditioning unit.
However, they are not as strict when it comes to who receives fans because the fans are cheaper to purchase. An air conditioning unit can range from $139 to $150 and Chester said they are not picky about the brand, but the units have to be new.
"The air conditioners are so expensive that we can't afford to give them to everyone who needs it, so we're trying to give it to at least the people who needs it the most," she said.
New box fans and small air conditioners can be brought from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday to Friday to the Dorchester County Health Department at 627 Race St. in Cambridge, according to a press release from the Health Department.
According to Chester, the Cambridge Walmart no longer has A/C units, so people are ordering them online and having them delivered to the Health Department.
"Well, I always say, if you want to donate a fan, just go on Amazon and order it and have it delivered here. That way you don't have to leave the comfort of your home. You can stay home in your air conditioning," Chester said. "If you want to donate an air conditioner, same thing."
Monetary donations are also accepted and can be made out to Zeta Phi Beta Sorority Inc. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community health initiative distributing fans and air conditioners to protect vulnerable residents from extreme heat, involving the health department and emphasizing health and safety concerns.

title: From signs to survival: a family’s kidney campaign
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
From signs to survival: a family’s kidney campaign

 August 4, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 883
 Words 

 Read News Document

 POTOMAC, Md. — Melanie Flamenbaum and her family are on a life-saving mission to find kidney donors for her sister and brother-in-law, Dana and Andrew Goldstein of Lewes, Del.Her husband, Ed Goldstein, and their sons, Ranan and Brooks, have been posting signs linking to the National Kidney Registry website. They've placed the signs in storefront windows, near a soybean field at the Inn at Huntingfield Creek, and even at a Boston Red Sox–Washington Nationals game.
Last weekend, they brought the campaign to Kent County while picking up Brooks from camp at Echo Hill. The family stayed in Rock Hall, enjoying the peaceful surroundings while continuing to spread awareness.
Throughout High Street in Chestertown and surrounding areas, signs share information about Dana and Andrew's circumstances and promote awareness of organ donation.
Flamenbaum said she overcame any shyness to give her sister and brother-in-law a chance to live and witness future milestones — including those of their daughter, Jelena Goldstein, who recently earned a master's degree from the University of Delaware.
Dana and Andrew's story is deeply personal and heart-wrenching.
Both in their 50s, Dana and Andrew have lived with Type 1 diabetes most of their lives, Flamenbaum told Kent County News.
Andrew was diagnosed in infancy. He underwent radiation treatments that left him with one functioning kidney and a pancreas that never fully recovered.
Dana was diagnosed at age 8 and has been taking insulin ever since.
Originally from New York, the couple met while attending Case Western Reserve University in Ohio. Andrew studied biomedical engineering, and they bonded over their shared experiences managing diabetes. They fell in love, got married and later welcomed Jelena.
Despite their medical challenges, the couple thrived for years. Andrew built a career in the biomedical field, and Dana held various jobs before focusing on raising their daughter.
But toward the end of the COVID-19 pandemic, their lives changed dramatically.
Dana was rushed to the emergency room with breathing difficulties and tested positive for COVID-19. She spent two weeks on a ventilator in the ICU and faced a long recovery once discharged.
Even after the couple relocated to Lewes in 2022, Dana continued to struggle. Climbing stairs became difficult, and weakness persisted. At a routine checkup, her blood and kidney levels raised concern. Soon after, she began dialysis treatment.
Dana initially underwent hemodialysis three days a week, where blood is drained through a chest port, cleaned, and returned to the body. The process was exhausting and consumed much of her energy.
Eventually, she transitioned to peritoneal dialysis at home. Using a port in her abdomen, a cleansing solution flows into the body and is later drained through a hose into the shower. While more convenient than hospital visits, the daily process was just as draining. At first, she performed treatments four times a day. Now, she undergoes dialysis overnight for eight hours while sleeping.
Andrew was by her side through it all, specially trained to help administer treatment. But soon, his own health began to decline.
After attending a social event, Andrew contracted pneumonia and began experiencing kidney failure. Like his wife, he started with hemodialysis and now performs peritoneal dialysis at home.
Flamenbaum said that while he is still able to work from home, it is not sustainable long term.
"Diabetes and dialysis have taken over their life," she said.
Everyday tasks have become increasingly difficult. Boxes of dialysis solution are stacked in the living room — a constant reminder of their new reality.
"Activities we take for granted, like a routine trip for a cup of coffee, are a draining affair for them," Flamenbaum said. "It takes a force of will to just do something natural."
That's why the family is being proactive — raising awareness, reaching out to as many people as possible, and dispelling fears and misconceptions about kidney donation.
With her loved ones' lives on the line, Flamenbaum has become well-versed in the process.
She explained that through the National Kidney Registry's voucher program, finding a compatible donor is now easier and more efficient than ever. Donors undergo a comprehensive medical exam, speak with doctors and counselors, and can opt out at any time with no pressure.
While kidney donation is still a major procedure, Flamenbaum said it is one of the safest surgeries with a relatively short recovery time.
"Someone who receives an organ from a live donor can generally go back to work immediately," she said — something Dana and Andrew hope to be able to do again.
Receiving a kidney from a living donor also means a lower chance of rejection, fewer anti-rejection medications, and fewer long-term complications.
For donors, she said the risk is minimal.
"I've talked to people who have donated," she said. "One told me, 'If not for a small scar, I wouldn't even know I did this.'"
But the emotional and spiritual reward, she said, is immense.
"They feel really good, emotionally and spiritually, because they've given someone their quality of life back," Flamenbaum said.
That's the outcome Dana and Andrew are fighting for as they continue their campaign across Maryland and surrounding states. If successful, they plan to have their transplant surgeries at the MedStar Georgetown Transplant Institute, one of the country's highest-volume organ transplant programs.
For more information or to begin the donor screening process, visit: nkr.org/TDE863 for Dana or nkr.org/TKZ944 for Andrew.
"We want to spread our message as broadly as possible," Flamenbaum said. "We take our signs everywhere we go — and we're not stopping." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on kidney disease, dialysis, organ donation, and a family's campaign to find donors, which are core health‑related issues.

title: Camp Scrubs teaches about all aspects of hospital health care
author: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com
content:
Camp Scrubs teaches about all aspects of hospital health care

 August 13, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Jane Bellmyer jbellmyer@cecilwhig.com | Section: News 
 
 407
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Nearly two dozen high school students spent last week at ChristianaCare Union Hospital in Elkton attending Camp Scrubs, where they learned about every aspect of health care in a hospital setting."We tried to show them that a hospital is run by so many people; not just doctors and nurses," said Katie Hunter, project coordinator. Working with Cecil College, Union Hospital has been offering Camp Scrubs since 2014 (pandemic notwithstanding). Hunter said the program has gained popularity with a waiting list for next year. Middle school aged students attend Camp Scrubs in June, with the high school cohort in August.
"We had two camps last year and this year," Hunter said. "There will be three next year."
Tuition is $315 and eight scholarships are made available each year.
On Friday, Camp Scrubs was learning CPR and how to use a mechanized and an inflatable lift — a hover jack and a hover bed respectively — for easier and safer patient transfer. As one group took turns learning the different transfer methods, another was run through the paces of treating a patient in cardiac arrest.
For Brionna Iraca-Reeves and Simone Akehurst, Camp Scrubs is an introduction into what each hopes will be a career in medicine.
"I've wanted to be a trauma surgeon for as long as I can remember," Iraca-Reeves, 16, from Oxford, Pa. said. "I didn't have a Plan B."
Akehurst, 16, from Bear, Del. also plans to be a trauma surgeon.
"We learned a lot in the OR," Akehurst said of their visit to an operating room at the hospital on Bow Street in Elkton. "We saw a total hip replacement and a tonsillectomy.
"I also got to hold a gall bladder in the (pathology) lab," Akehurst said.
Along with getting introduced to the many aspects of a hospital the teens also got to talk with some of its professionals, which Akehurst called valuable.
"This morning I got to talk to a general surgeon," said the trauma surgeon hopeful. "He told me trauma surgeon is more medical than surgical. I want the opportunity to do more surgery. General surgery is a very broad skillset."
"A lot of it is mentoring in the field you want to pursue," Iraca-Reeves said.
Iraca-Reeves said any student with health care aspirations should consider attending Camp Scrubs. She credits Hunter with making the program valuable, informative but also engaging.
"She's all wrapped up in giving people the best experience," Iraca-Reeves said. "I think it's really important to recognize Katie and all she's done." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a hospital-run camp that educates high‑school students about medical procedures and careers, focusing on health‑care knowledge and experience.

title: Hole In the Wall Gang Camp on track to open May 2026 in Queenstown
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Hole In the Wall Gang Camp on track to open May 2026 in Queenstown

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 442
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEENSTOWN — Nestled in the scenic landscape of Queenstown, expansion of Paul Newman's vision for a camp for children with serious illnesses comes closer to fruition, with renovations well underway.Expansions to bring The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp to the Eastern Shore are more than halfway complete. The camp hopes to welcome the first session of campers in May 2026.
Founded in 1988 by Paul Newman, The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp provides a different kind of healing to thousands of children with serious illnesses and family members annually, free of charge.
Renovations are underway to transform the property's former Aspen Institute buildings into camp-friendly spaces.
Inclusion and accessibility and intention are key components of the camp as it seeks to provide the whole camp experience to all children regardless of illness, according to Hilary Axtmayer, chief program officer.
Features of the developing facility include complete ADA compliant ramps, temperature controlled swimming pool, and bringing vibrant fun colors to all corners of the campus.
As a medical camp, a state-of-the art infirmary will serve all camper care on-site.
Building off the success of its original Ashford, Connecticut location, the Hole in the Wall in Queenstown will provide transformative camp experience for Mid-Atlantic children with serious illnesses including rare diseases, and their families.
Like the original Connecticut location, the Queenstown camp will serve as a place of joy, connection, healing and respite, designed to support not only the child with serious illness but their entire family.
For many of these campers and their families, Hole in the Wall provides camp experiences they would not otherwise have opportunity for, Axtmayer said.
Years in the making, officials are more than excited to expand the camp's reach and bring the medical specialty camp to the area.
The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp is always adapting and improving to meet the unique and varied needs of campers and their families, Axtmayer said.
The Eastern Shore's centralized location close to Baltimore and Washington D.C is ideal for the camp's extensive hospital outreach program, she said.
Expanding The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp experience to the Eastern Shore, the future Queenstown campground will soon be a place where children with serious illnesses will have the chance to simply be kids, and, as Newman famously said, "raise a little hell."
The camp expects to welcome about 15 families per weekend during its first phase family program sessions opening in May 2026. A second phase to provide independent-camper opportunities is expected further down the line.
Officials have begun connecting with hospitals and organizations specializing in rare diseases to help recruit eligible campers.
"We can't wait to welcome families," Axtmayer said.
More information about Hole in the wall can be found at www.holeinthewallgang.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a medical camp for children with serious illnesses, highlighting health services, accessibility, and therapeutic benefits, making Health the most relevant category.

title: Our happiness and satisfaction can seem fleeting
author: GLENN MOLLETTE
content:
Our happiness and satisfaction can seem fleeting

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: GLENN MOLLETTE | Section: Columns 
 
 515
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Peace and happiness have many variables.We aren't happy when we feel we do not have enough and then burdened if we have too much. We fret over not enough money or worry about what we will do if we have too much money. Most of us don't have the latter problem.
We fret over not enough space or how we care for too much space. We accumulate and store up in our barns and build bigger barns to store up more stuff. We then don't know what we will do with all the stuff.
How much does it take to bring you peace and make you happy? Can you be happy in a one-room dwelling place? Does it take a 25-room house to make you feel good? How many cars do you need to make you feel satisfied? Or is satisfaction only a remotely impossible concept? Many years ago, one popular song lamented, "I can't get no satisfaction."
Satisfaction and happiness may be claimed for a season. Possibly you are satisfied with your vocation, athletic accomplishments, family life, parenting success, fulfillment of life goals and ambitions? Often, we are but then those seasons pass. Careers end, athletic contests become history, retirement comes with memories that fade farther and farther into the past.
Too often most of us can look back and wonder, "what if?" we may say. The problem with "what if?" is that it doesn't change anything. If it is in the past, you can't relive it or change it regardless of how great you were or how bad you were.
All we have for certain, is today. Even today is iffy. Since today is all we really have then it's best to not mess it up by constantly looking over our shoulders. You can't go forward always looking back.
In the Bible there was a man named Lot. He and his wife were told not to look back at Sodom and Gomera. She did and turned into a pillar of salt. Looking back has a way of doing that to all us as we become immobilized in time.
What does it take to make you happy? Someone to love and someone who loves you? A few family members to care for who also care for you? Enough money to pay the light bill and keep food on the table? Something to do during the day that you enjoy? The only person who can answer these questions is you because only you know what it really takes to make you happy.
Happiness is very much happenstance. Things change every day. Health, sickness, the stock market, families, jobs and hobbies. Friends and loved ones move away or die. Lie is always changing.
God never changes. Happiness may vary throughout the day or week, but your joy and peace that comes with faith in God and focusing on Him is something the world cannot give or take away.
Keep this verse in mind this day regardless of whether you feel happy or if you are down and blue.
"You will keep in perfect peace those whose minds are steadfast, because they trust in you." Isaiah 26:3. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses personal happiness, satisfaction, and mental well‑being, which aligns most closely with the Health category (specifically mental health), though it is a philosophical column rather than a medical piece.

title: My aging body: 'I feel like I'm being evicted'
author: ROBERT C. KOEHLER
content:
My aging body: 'I feel like I'm being evicted'

 August 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ROBERT C. KOEHLER | Section: Columns 
 
 768
 Words 

 Read News Document

 I thought I knew myself pretty well, but then this old-age thing hit ... hard. Both physically and psychologically.I'm still in Appleton, Wisconsin as I write, awaiting my second cataract surgery, right eye, tomorrow. The first one went well. I'm not concerned about No. 2, at least not in and of itself. But I've felt myself plunging into a sense of deeper stress, feeling, with increasing regularity – as I stay here with my loving family – like a shrug of nobody.
Only minimally am I a participant in the basics of life. Yeah, things are essentially taken care of for me, which is great – it's why I'm here – but nonetheless it leaves me feeling like a spectator of my own life. And it hurts to get up. Achy thighs, wobbly knees. Plus I don't hear well, don't see well (yet), and am good at pummeling myself into a state of uselessness: what I call I-don't-matterness.
As Leonard Cohen said shortly before he died, speaking of his body, "I feel like I'm being evicted."
And that state intensifies the aches and wobbles. Prior to standing up, for instance, I know the pain is coming and psychologically start cringing and grimacing, feeling the pain before it even starts. I'm just an old fart and this is what I get. This is what I deserve. Ouch!
But then something happened. This was just a few days ago, as I stood up from the kitchen table. A sense of awareness clicked – I'm not sure why – and my looming pain was not the focus. Instead, I just stood up ... oooh, ahhh ... and it simply was what it was. What I felt wasn't the pain, it was the effort. What? The feeling was there, but I didn't torture myself with it. It wasn't pain, it was simply reality. And my legs pushed against it. They did their job. I was up. Life goes on. I had a smile on my face.
I'm not saying all is good, all of a sudden. I'm still this old guy and my life is full of challenges. But this click of awareness at the kitchen table has reverberated. Think positive – my God, that's just a cliché. But I don't know how else to put it. It doesn't push away life's difficulties or make life pain-free. It just clears away some of the psychology – the shame and anger, the fear and despair. You know, all those emotions that intensify the hurt.
OK. Life goes on. But loosening the psychological impact pain had on me seemed to matter. I don't mean in a full-blown way. with life now problem-free. I simply found myself, much to my astonishment, letting myself focus beyond my depression and self-annoyance. There was a bit of a sparkle in me, a sense of self-caring, a sense of ... yes, yes, self-respect, which I had angrily snorted out of my mind.
I was, and am, staying at my sister's part of the house, which she shares with her daughter and family. One day when she was off somewhere, and I was alone, instead of simply losing myself on my computer and staying invisible – unwanted – I called my niece and asked if her husband was interested in doing a drawing with me, as he had once mentioned to her. It was Sunday, so they weren't working, so this might be a good time, maybe even the only time. She asked him and his answer was yes.
So I went over there, and we sat together for an hour, maybe more. We danced with drafting pens and colored pencils and magic markers, and I felt a gleeful fullness in me. I wasn't just "the guy they were taking care of" but a participant in their lives. When I came back to Sue's place she was there. She looked and me and said, "You're in pretty good spirits."
And the words stuck. I was. I had reclaimed a sense of agency. I wasn't just living a shrugged-off life of I-don't-matter. I could stand and I could connect. I felt the return of a forgotten self, an abandoned self. And a couple days later, Sue and I went to visit a nearby retirement community – just to look, y'know. Just in case I decided to leave Chicago and move up here.
The place had a slogan: Strength. Purpose. Belonging.
It was also pretty costly, so I probably won't be moving there. But the words pulled something huge together for me, and still do, as I continue to absorb them. They're all of us, standing up together at the kitchen table. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article is a personal column describing the author's physical ailments, surgeries, and psychological coping with aging, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: ‘The most vulnerable’: Rural, inner city communities brace for impacts of Trump's Medicaid cuts
author: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia
content:
‘The most vulnerable’: Rural, inner city communities brace for impacts of Trump's Medicaid cuts

 August 23, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MIKE SUNNUCKS Adams MultiMedia | Section: News 
 
 1323
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Hospitals and medical providers serving rural and lower-income communities are on edge after President Donald Trump's mega bill passed by Congress includes looming Medicaid cuts.Some of them are on the financial edge, literally — and fear the worst.
Trump's Big Beautiful Bill (BBB) will cut close to $1 trillion from Medicaid and Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP) by 2034, according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO).
The government programs offer medical services to low-income Americans. Close to 78.4 million Americans are enrolled in Medicaid and CHIP, 23% of the U.S. population. BBB cuts aim to reduce Medicaid and CHIP roles by 10.5 million people by 2034 via tougher eligibility rules and work requirements
"Everyone's panicked," said Jennifer Mensik Kennedy, president of the American Nurses Association.
She worries about the Medicaid cuts prompting layoffs, hiring freezes, reduced staffing, missed payrolls and hospital closures.
Medicaid reimbursements accounted for 19% of all U.S. spending at hospitals in 2023. That totals $283 billion of the $1.5 trillion Americans spent on hospital care, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.
"Rural hospitals were already in dire straits," Mensik Kennedy said of the financial situation and short financial reserves already facing some small-town hospitals.
New work requirements require adult Medicaid recipients without exemptions for disabilities to work 80 hours per month. The BBB also institutes copays of up to $35 for Medicaid-related doctor appointments. Work requirements go into place in 2027, while the federal funding changes and copays go into effect in 2028, according to an analysis of the BBB's Medicaid impacts by the Hirija & Chau LLP, a Los Angeles-based law firm.
MORE THAN HOSPITALSRural and inner-city hospitals in lower-income areas will feel the brunt of the Medicaid and CHIP cuts, according to health care industry experts and executives.
"They're the most vulnerable," said Peter Kowey, chair of cardiovascular research and a professor of medicine and clinical pharmacology at Thomas Jefferson University.
"They don't have the high-end stuff like cardiovascular surgeries or neurology or orthopedic surgeries that generate a lot of revenue," said Kowey, who has authored a new book, "Failure to Treat: How a Broken Healthcare System Puts Patients and Practitioners at Risk."
Kowey said hospitals have already been struggling since the pandemic and those overly reliant on Medicaid are facing "very fragile" operating margins.
A report by the Center for Healthcare Quality and Payment Reform found that as many 700 rural U.S. hospitals are financially struggling and 300 are at risk of more immediate closure.
David Navazio, CEO of Gentell, Corp. a Philadelphia-based medical company specializing in wound care, said rural hospitals don't have the population or revenue bases to give them financial resilience.
Some hospitals "never recovered" financially from the pandemic when other procedures, appointments and surgeries were canceled or not pursued, he said.
Navazio said the U.S. health system needs more preventive care and more community and other health clinics to serve communities.
"Maybe we have too many hospitals," he said. "There's so much more to health care than hospitals."
But he also worries about how Medicaid cuts will impact health centers in rural and underserved communities with significant Medicaid patient populations..
"Those clinics are the ones who are the most vulnerable to closure," Navazio said.
He called the BBB cuts "short-sighted" and cautioned that the result will be more uninsured Americans putting off health needs until they are more serious, then showing up at emergency rooms.
Navazio said the American health care system still struggles to provide medical services to the uninsured, who are often workers in lower paying sectors or for smaller businesses whose health care plans are not affordable.
"The uninsured are really the working poor," he said.
According to federal data, 27.2 million Americans were uninsured in 2024. That accounts for 8.2% of the U.S. population and is up from 25 million in 2023, according to the National Center for Health Statistics. The CBO estimates the Medicaid pullbacks could increase the number of uninsured persons by 10 million.
Mensik Kennedy and others worry about the creation of more health care deserts with patients having to potentially drive long distances to deliver babies or for more specialized care.
"You are going to see nurses and providers leave," Mensik Kennedy said of the Medicaid cuts' potential impacts on rural and other underserved communities.
"Once they leave those communities, they aren't coming back," she said.
Struggling hospitals could go toward an emergency room-centric model in order to survive, dispatching other practice areas because of the financing challenges.
DEBT CRISISConservative backers of the Medicaid cuts say they are needed to cut out waste and fraud and help curtail federal spending and debt loads.
Medicaid spending will total $873 billion this year, according to federal projections.
In 2023, the federal government accounted for 69% of total Medicaid spending and states 31%.
Medicaid accounts for 18% of total U.S. health care spending (compared to 30% for private insurance, 21% of Medicare and 10% for out–of–pocket payments), according to federal data.
Conservatives favor the Medicaid changes saying they are needed to root out waste and fraud to help better control federal debt, which now totals $37 trillion.
"Along with Medicare, Medicaid is the main reason the federal government is hurtling toward a debt crisis. A debt crisis would trigger significant economic hardship and require drastic cuts to both programs," the conservative Cato Institute said in an analysis.
Cato said U.S. Government Accountability Office (GAO) reports found $31 billion in improper Medicaid payments in 2023 and $500 billion over the last decade.
Critics of the Trump bill say tax cuts in the measure will magnify federal debt and shift money from the poor via cuts to Medicaid and food stamps to the wealthy via tax reductions.
'A DIRTY WORD'There have already been efforts from congressional Republicans to recoup some of the Medicaid cuts and help vulnerable hospitals.
A $50 billion fund was created to help rural hospitals — though skeptics say that falls short of the cuts Medicaid providers will face.
U.S. Sen. Josh Hawley, R-Missouri, wants to double that fund to $100 billion and has introduced a measure to block future Medicaid cuts.
States, who accounted for 31% of Medicaid spending in 2023, could try to fill the void of federal cuts. But that is not easy with state balanced budget requirements and a hesitancy even in Democratic states to raise taxes, including on the wealthy.
"Raising taxes is a dirty word," Navazio said.
Christoph Dankert, chief network officer at Carrum Health (a San Francisco-based health care technology firm), said hospitals and other providers poised to be impacted need to start forging paths forward well before the BBB cuts commence.
"They are going to have a shortfall of funds," Dankert said. "You have to make it somewhere."
He said a drop in Medicare revenue from hospitals and the potential increase in more uninsured, uncompensated care will put upward pressures on private insurance rates.
"It's going to create upward pressure on employer rates," Dankert said.
The American Hospital Association opposes the Medicaid cuts, saying they will reduce access to care and adversely impact "the most vulnerable populations" such kids and those with disabilities.
'COST CONTROLS'
The Medicaid cuts will propel more health care industry efforts to control costs, said Nate Favini, chief medical officer with Pair Team, a California-based digital health company focused on Medicaid.
"Controlling costs is a major priority, and there's recognition that the system has significant inefficiencies in how care is delivered," Favini said.
He said there will also be efforts to help Medicaid patients stay eligible once the work and other eligibility requirements begin.
But financially strained hospitals don't have a lot of wiggle room to take more hits, said Eddie Qureshi, CEO and founder of Rainfall Health, an artificial intelligence-focused health technology firm.
Quareshi said some hospitals have less than 30 days' cash on hand.
"We are going to see some hospitals close because they aren't able to keep up with the changes," he said.
Both Qureshi and Favini say Medicaid and other changes with health care — including a Trump administration's push for more data sharing of medical records and other information — will propel more technology, including AI.
"Our most forward-thinking health system partners recognize they can't continue with business as usual," Favini said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on Medicaid and CHIP cuts, their impact on hospitals, clinics, and patient access to care, which are core health policy and public health issues.

title: Rabies case discovered in Caroline County
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Rabies case discovered in Caroline County

 August 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 143
 Words 

 Read News Document

 On Wednesday, the Caroline County Health Department announced a positive case of rabies in the area of Cool Spring Road near Henderson."The Maryland Department of Health laboratory has confirmed a positive rabid case in the Cool Spring Road area," the department said in a release to the public.
The health department warned residents that any person near or in the vicinity of Cool Spring Road should avoid contact with wildlife, feral cats, unknown animals or any animal that appears sick or to exhibit signs of rabies, including cats and dogs.
The health department also urges residents in the area to make sure their pets and mammal livestock are up to date on rabies vaccinations.
The department urges residents to report potentially rabid animals at 410-820-1600 or the non-emergency line of the Caroline County 911 Center at 410-479-2222.
For more information on the rabies case, visit carolinehd.org/rabies-alert-near-henderson-august-27-2025/.

title: Opioid Restitution Funds to focus on schools and health education
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Opioid Restitution Funds to focus on schools and health education

 August 29, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 518
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CENTREVILLE — With numerous proposed local projects dedicated to opioid awareness and limited federal funding, Queen Anne's County Commissioners prioritized public schools and the department of health educational support programs for opioid restitution funding Aug. 12.The county's Local Opioid Abatement Plan included several proposed projects to utilize local opioid restitution funds provided by the state to combat the opioid crisis. The county only has about $677,000 available in funding, and all the projects outlined total over $1 million, according to County Administrator Todd Mohn.
Queen Anne's County Public Schools Opioid Education Partnership will utilize $209,025 of the opioid restitution funds in preventing youth opioid misuse through a school-based program and student-led awareness campaigns. It also aims to educate the broader community through public events, and distributing data-rich materials.
Queen Anne's County Department of Health Educational Support programs will be provided $89,251 to strengthen overdose education, prevention, and response.
This project also includes a re-entry program for individuals released from the detention center and an expansion to the court-assisted recovery program to provide alternatives to incarceration.
The commissioners reached a consensus to reconsider other programs at a future time as additional resources and partnerships become available.
Counties were awarded Maryland's opioid restitution funds to have autonomy to create plans on how to address avoiding addiction in communities, according to County Health Officer Brice Strang.
Programs that were traditionally funded have been denied funding this year, including the public school program, he said.
Strang is now recommending the Board of Health create a county evidence-based mechanism to support current programming and showcase how it is working in the community, such as the school based programing. Strang recommended using the funding to backfill the programs, and "wait and see" on federal and state funding.
A constant messaging to youth in particular is important, he said, and the commissioners praised the works of the Drug Free Coalition, the Student Ambassadors, and county partnerships.
"One of the things we already know is prevention is cheaper than treatment," Strang said.
Remembering when programs initially began, Commission President Chris Corchiarino noted just how far the community has come in regard to opioid awareness and preventing overdoses.
To continually keep overdose numbers down, Corchiarino said, new initiatives are always needed to keep awareness moving forward and make sure preventive programs stay at the forefront.
"And that forefront is in our schools, for sure," Commissioner Phil Dumenil said.
More information about Queen Anne's County Drug Free Coalition can be found at qacgoespurple.org.
In other business it was noted, phase three of the South Island Trail extension project took one step closer as a construction and paving bid was awarded to David A. Bramble Inc. in the amount of $593,030.
This approximately 3,500 feet portion of the project faced time constraints due to its wooded and wildlife areas and is set to begin Sept. 1.
With a grant through the Maryland Office of Tourism Development, Queen Anne's County Economic and Tourism Development will be taking the show on the road with a mobile visitors center trailer to be purchased from Advantage Trailers for $91,778.
The trailer will serve to elevate tourism throughout the county by strategically placing it in high traffic areas and events. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on opioid restitution funds being used for opioid education and prevention programs, which are public health initiatives, making Health the most fitting category.

title: Mobile crisis services expanding in Southern Maryland
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Mobile crisis services expanding in Southern Maryland

 September 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 512
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Since March, clinicians and peer support specialists with Santé Group have been driving a light blue Ford Escape in Southern Maryland to help resolve immediate behavioral crises and offer resources in the community.St. Mary's County Health Department received a grant from the Maryland Behavioral Health Administration for mobile crisis teams across the state, Tammy Loewe, director of the behavioral health division for local department, said. Mobile crisis teams align with the national Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration practices.
Goals of the mobile crisis teams include providing in-person care and deploying in real time to the location of the person in crisis to begin the process of assessment and treatment, Loewe said.
"We really felt with our expertise, in both urban and rural areas, that coming into Southern Maryland could be a really great support for the community," Sam Richberg, chief of programs for Santé, said.
Phone counselors determine if a person's situation can be deescalated on the phone and be connected with appropriate resources or if a team of a clinician and peer support specialist needs to visit them, Richberg said.
During visits, the team identifies what triggered the call, who is involved and next steps. Peer support specialists use their shared experience to make a connection, Richberg said, and they determine which resources to provide to keep someone from going to the hospital or criminal justice system.
The team follows up the next day, whether it be in-person or over tele-health, Tina-Marie Brown, a director with Santé, said. At the minimum, the team will visit the client once every seven days for two weeks.
"What's great about crisis response services … is the immediacy of the support you get," Richberg said. "You have somebody who then can support you in getting connected to more of that long-term care."
It could be a child acting out and the parent does not know what to do or talking someone out of suicide, Brown said. Santé can also offer support to law enforcement and the community after a tragedy.
Community outreach is key, Richberg said. Letting people know Santé is available is important, but so is making connections with local resources. They have an agreement to start working in Charles County, too.
Maryland has just half of the therapists they need, Brown said. The mobile crisis is a stop gap, meaning they can support individuals until they get help or until help becomes available.
"If we're doing our job well, we should be connecting that person to community resources," Brown said. "The more support someone has, the more successful they're going to be."
The workforce for behavioral health is a statewide concern, Loewe said. St. Mary's County worked with St. Mary's College of Maryland and College of Southern Maryland to promote behavioral health degrees.
As Santé continues to grow in Southern Maryland, they hope to offer suicide prevention work, Brown said.
"It takes a special person for crisis," Brown said. "Not everybody likes it. It's very fast-paced. You never know what you're going to have from one day to the next."
Call the Maryland Crisis Hotline at 988 to connect with crisis teams and resources. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses mobile crisis teams providing behavioral health services, mental health assessments, and suicide prevention, which are core health topics. Public safety is a secondary aspect as the service aims to reduce criminal justice involvement, and education appears due to partnerships with local colleges.

title: Talbot goes purple another year
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Talbot goes purple another year

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Business 
 
 524
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Talbot County is going purple for the ninth year this September to engage the community and youth in standing up against substance use.During the monthlong awareness and education campaign, businesses, organizations and government agencies will be lit up in purple not just in Talbot County, but throughout the Mid-Shore.
The program was founded by Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble to raise awareness about the prescription opioid crisis. Gamble said the program has since changed to reflect the evolving drug trends in the county.
Gamble said he created Talbot Goes Purple to start a conversation the county wasn't having. He said he was speaking at a fundraiser when he had this realization.
"I stood up and I said, 'raise your hand if you talk to your kids about drinking and driving,' and all 400 hands went up. And I said, 'raise your hands if you talk to your kids, your grandkids, about seatbelt use,' and 400 hands went up. And then I said, 'Raise your hand if you talk to your kids about prescription painkillers,' and only 11 hands went up," Gamble said.
For Gamble, these were conversations that parents, guardians and community members needed to be having with their children to give them the proper tools to handle situations involving drugs.
"In my world of policing, 80% of what we deal with is connected to some form of substance abuse," Gamble said.
Maryland has tracked much fewer overdose deaths for the past two years. According to Gamble, there has only been one overdose in Talbot County this year.
However, fentanyl is still a major concern, he said. "We're not seeing any heroin in Talbot County, Maryland that doesn't have fentanyl in it," Gamble said. "We're seeing a lot of cocaine in Talbot County, Maryland that has fentanyl in it."
Educational efforts through September will be extensive, Goes Purple organizers said, and they will address fentanyl along with other substances.
Talbot Goes Purple Coordinator Kelley Callaghan said the broadening of the program's focus to include education on marijuana is more important than ever with a potential dispensary coming to Easton, and Gamble agrees.
"Youth are being hospitalized for marijuana use," Gamble said. "I want parents to understand, you know, the weed they smoked when they were in college 30 years ago is not the same weed today."
Callaghan highlighted alcohol as one of the commonly abused drugs by youth.
There will be posters around Talbot County schools of a real prescription pill next to a fake one, showing how difficult it is to tell the difference.
Teaching the youth about the Good Samaritan Law, which protects individuals from prosecution for minor drug or alcohol offenses when calling 911 for a medical emergency, is a critical part of the prevention tactics, Goes Purple organizers said.
In addition, Talbot Goes Purple provides Narcan trainings and has installed Narcan boxes at several business and trained the employees how to use them. Narcan, or Naloxone, is a medication used during opioid overdoses to reverse or reduce the effects of the drug.
There is also a comprehensive toolkit on the Goes Purple website to help families navigate recovery services and find help regardless of insurance status.
For resources regarding substance use, visit talbotgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community campaign addressing substance abuse, opioid overdose prevention, and related health education, making Health the most relevant category.

title: QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
QAC Goes Purple 2025: standing stronger than ever

 September 3, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 709
 Words 

 Read News Document

 QUEEN ANNE'S COUNTY — QAC Goes Purple is once again rallying the community this season to stand against substance abuse, as county leaders note progress but stress that education must continue.The countywide initiative, launched in 2017, is a collaboration of the Queen Anne's County Office of the Sheriff and the Queen Anne's County Drug-Free Coalition, in partnership with the Opioid Intervention Team and Health Department, Queen Anne's County Public Schools, the county commissioners, the Mid-Shore Community Foundation and other agencies. Its mission is to raise awareness of substance abuse and opioid overdose prevention.
One of the program's first actions was to place six opioid signs across the county, updated weekly to show overdose data. At the time, opioid misuse was on the rise.
In 2018, Queen Anne's County reported 122 overdoses and 16 overdose-related deaths. By 2024, those numbers had dropped to 18 overdoses and four deaths.
So far in 2025, the county has recorded eight overdoses — and no overdose deaths — an encouraging sign, officials said. But they stressed that continued education and prevention efforts are needed to keep the numbers low.
"Even one death due to opioids is too many, and work must continue," coalition members said.
Education, Prevention and Treatment
Through awareness campaigns, free Narcan distribution by the county Health Department, a standard reporting system developed by Queen Anne's County Emergency Services, and the QAC Data Dashboard, local leaders say the effort is showing results.
In 2025, the initiative expanded its banners across the county to more than 100, all carrying the slogan: "Taking a stand against substance abuse."
Progress is being seen "across the board," said Warren Wright of QAC Goes Purple. He credited strict penalties for drug sellers, enforcement against tobacco and liquor outlets that sell to minors, and the strong work of the county's Drug Court.
Also contributing are Prevention Services, Peer Support Workers and the Local Management Board, which is conducting an asset-mapping project. The county Board of Education has added Bodkin life skills programs for younger students. The commissioners are working with neighboring counties to expand treatment services for residents at the Whitsitt Center.
Youth Involvement
Recognizing that most young people make choices about alcohol, tobacco and drug use during middle school, QAC Goes Purple has focused on youth outreach.
A Youth Risk Behavior Survey found that more than 13% of Queen Anne's County high school students reported taking a prescription drug not prescribed to them — a troubling trend that highlights the need for early conversations at home and in schools, officials said.
To reach peers directly, the QAC Drug-Free Student Ambassador Program includes students from public and private schools who design posters, lead team-building events and stage award-winning activities.
"We believe that involvement is key to prevention for our students," Wright said. "Join a team, try a club, and discover your passion. After-school programs and activities are offered through schools, the YMCA and the Giving the Edge Foundation."
Changing Perceptions
QAC Goes Purple emphasizes that substance use disorder is not a choice but a disease that affects the brain. Understanding the science of addiction, officials say, can reduce stigma and encourage compassion.
September is recognized as National Recovery Month, followed by Substance Use Prevention Month in October. International Overdose Awareness Day is marked every year on Aug. 31 to honor those lost and support families affected by substance use disorders.
"We can all make a difference," said Emily Keller, Maryland's special secretary of overdose response. "Hundreds of lives are saved every year from bystanders who had naloxone and knew what to do in the event of an overdose. We have to make sure that anyone who wants naloxone can access it wherever they are and whenever they need it."
Free naloxone is available at the Nielsen Center, 205 N. Liberty St., Centreville.
Upcoming Event
The sixth annual Going Purple Together event will be held Sept. 27 at Church Hill Park from 11 a.m. to 2 p.m. The family-friendly gathering will feature live music, food trucks, face painting, dunk tanks and raffle prizes, while celebrating recovery and raising awareness.
The community is also invited to complete the QAC Goes Purple Marijuana Survey, available at the county Health Department website under the Behavioral Health tab.
"Everyone in Queen Anne's County can keep fighting by knowing the facts, discussing them with loved ones, colleagues and friends," Wright said.
More information is available at qacgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: Maryland kids celebrated in Times Square national Down syndrome video
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Maryland kids celebrated in Times Square national Down syndrome video

 September 6, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 458
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Five kids from Southern Maryland appeared in the annual National Down Syndrome Society Times Square video in New York City on Saturday.The one-hour video will show over 500 photographs including children, teens and adults with Down syndrome from all 50 states and 11 countries, a release from the National Down Syndrome Society said. The photos of Ellie Griffin, Norah Smith, Harrison Bonovitch, Arthur Schaefer and Josiah Gross were selected from more than 2,600 entries in the society's call for photos.
Ellie, Norah and Arthur are from St. Mary's County and Harrison and Josiah are from Calvert County. Their photos will be displayed on two screens in Times Square above Dos Caminos restaurant in Father Duffy Square.
Ellie is 5 and was diagnosed with Down syndrome when she was born, Jessica Griffin, Ellie's mom, said. Ellie was also selected to be in the video in 2022, but this is the first time the family is going to New York to see it.
"I can't wait to see her reaction," Griffin said before the event. "Hopefully she realizes what's happening."
While Ellie might not understand everything that's happening, her 8-year-old brother is excited and "thinks she's famous," the mother said.
Outside of the national society, the family participates with other Down syndrome organizations, Griffin said. They do fundraisers with the Down Syndrome Diagnosis Network and have raised over $20,000 to connect families who are new to the condition, in which a person is born with an extra chromosome causing mild to moderate cognitive disability, developmental delays and physical challenges.
"It's amazing the support that we get through our community," Griffin said.
Griffin is also a parent volunteer with Jack's Baskets, which hand delivers baskets with gifts and resources for families to celebrate babies with Down syndrome.
The Times Square video presentation kicks off the New York City Buddy Walk. The walk has taken place in New York City since 1995 as part of the National Buddy Walk Program.
The National Down Syndrome Society video allows Ellie and the other Southern Maryland residents to advocate the message of inclusion, Griffin said. The photos were taken by 21FIVE Photography by Teresa Tucker, a resident in Southern Maryland who did free photoshoots for the kids to submit to the society.
"Everyone's goal is to support their kids and help them be the best versions of themselves," Griffin said.
Ellie does not have a lot of words, but she is a huge Taylor Swift fan, Griffin said. When Swift plays Ellie screams "Tay Tay" and starts dancing and singing.
"She's been hitting a lot of the words to the songs," Griffen said. "We think it's actually helped improve her language and speech skills."
The presentation was slated to be live-streamed on the National Down Syndrome Society Facebook page from 9:30 to 10:30 a.m. on Sept. 6. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on children with Down syndrome, a medical condition, and discusses inclusion, support services, and a national video by the Down Syndrome Society, making health the most relevant category.

title: Cambridge man urges water caution after 'flesh-eating bacteria' infection
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Cambridge man urges water caution after 'flesh-eating bacteria' infection

 September 11, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 942
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CAMBRIDGE — Facing a life-altering bacterial infection from the local river, a local couple is urging the community to be more informed swimmers.A typical day at the shore turned a couple's lives upside down after a sharp step opened a wound on a man's leg and exposed him to bacteria in the Chester River last summer.
For over a year, Kyle "Slade" Register, of Cambridge has been fighting Vibrio, a "flesh-eating" bacteria found in local rivers.
Register and Audra Williamson were swimming in the Chester River on Aug. 16, 2024 when Register stepped on what they presume was a sharp oyster shell and cut a small, deep gash on the inside of Register's left foot. The couple quickly went to work cleaning the wound with peroxide and rubbing alcohol and scrubbed it with antibacterial soap before wrapping it.
Going to bed as normal, "We never dreamt we would wake up the next morning to his foot being the size of a bowling pin with a red streak starting up his leg," Williamson said.
Register spent a week at the hospital in Easton before being transferred to University of Maryland Shock Trauma, where he stayed for the following month. While there, Register had four surgeries to save his leg.
"It's been a year, and he is still going to wound care twice a week," Williamson said.
Register is unable to work full-time with the wound, as the two-inch gash ended in the entire inside of his left calf and the inside of his left foot being cut out, with a wound vac attached for months.
The couple went from having a "pretty normal life," to losing work and having their lives turned upside down, Williamson said.
Now beginning to get back on their feet, the two are sharing their story as a precautionary tale to others taking a dip.
"We just want to prevent this from happening to others," Williamson said.
According to the U.S Environmental Protection Agency, Vibrio are naturally occurring bacteria found in brackish environments like the Chesapeake Bay and its tributaries, such as the Chester River. In rare cases, swimmers can develop illnesses or infections if an open wound is exposed to polluted water.
A "tough construction worker type," who never thought twice about what was hidden in waterways, Register said his entire view of the water changed after that incident.
A "fish," all his life, Register now looks at the water with "abject sadness."
Taking it one day at a time, the Cambridge couple still drive around the Chesapeake Bay, estuaries, and areas like Blackwater National Wildlife Refuge to look at the water "but I don't go in," Register said.
Looking back on the treatment and recovery he has faced and the journey still to come, "I don't want a parent to feel that pain," Register said and seeks to share his story with others.
Not to scare people, but to help them understand the possibilities, Register said. "The public needs to be more educated about this," he said.
Williamson encouraged checking out the local environmental organizations information and the EPA website before swimming or boating.
Register welcomes the opportunities to share his story and can be reached at sladeregister81@gmail.com.
According to Shorerivers' Swimmable ShoreRivers Bacteria Monitoring Program Report, "Is it safe to swim in the river?" is one of the most common questions Riverkeepers hear from community members. There are inherent risks with coming in contact with water in a living estuary, and ShoreRivers works to understand the bacterial levels associated with enterococci, an EPA recommended indicator for human health risks.
Enterococci includes more than 17 species of fecal bacteria and is found in the intestines of warm-blooded animals. High levels of enterococci can indicate elevated risks for human contact with pathogens and other bacteria, such as E-coli. While there are natural bacteria levels in local rivers due to wildlife and decomposition, there are also pollution sources such as failing septic systems and faulty sewer lines, pet waste, mishandling of boat waste, and some organic fertilizers that can pose threats to human health.
"There are additional risks with open water swimming that we do not regularly monitor, including vibrio, toxic algal blooms, and other biological and chemical toxins," according to the report.
ShoreRivers' seasonal bacteria monitoring program regularly monitors nearly 50 sites where people frequently come in contact with water, including popular swimming locations, marinas, yacht clubs, and towns. Swim Tester volunteers collect water samples every Thursday morning from Memorial Day to Labor Day. Riverkeepers then analyze the samples and distribute data on bacteria levels in the river, aiming to provide the public with the information needed to make educated decisions about their contact with the water.
The Swimmable ShoreRivers program utilizes the standardized EPA criteria for recreational swimming of 104 Colony Forming Units (CFU)/100ml for analyzing a single bacteria sample. Anything equal to or higher than 104 CFU is a failing sample, and anything below 104 CFU is a passing sample. Not all test sites are designated swimming areas.
According to Shore Rivers, bacteria levels can change, particularly as a result of significant rain events.
ShoreRivers always recommends following best practices when recreating in local waterways including rinsing off after swimming, avoiding swimming for 24–48 hours after a rain event, and staying out of the water with open cuts or wounds to minimize exposure to potentially harmful bacteria.
As part of its ongoing work to protect and restore local rivers and creeks, ShoreRivers weekly bacteria monitoring reports are posted every Friday from Memorial Day to Labor Day at www.shorerivers.org/swim.
Though the seasonal Swimmable ShoreRivers testing has wrapped up for this year, a full report on each regularly monitored site is expected in October.
Information on how to prevent and respond to possible infections, can be found in the Maryland Department of the Environment. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a Vibrio bacterial infection, medical treatment, and health risks, making Health the primary focus, with secondary relevance to public safety warnings and environmental water quality.

title: 'It's rewarding and motivating': Eastern Shore resident speaks on recovery
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'It's rewarding and motivating': Eastern Shore resident speaks on recovery

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 573
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Norm Townsend spent his entire life on the Eastern Shore, growing up in Easton and spending half of his life in Cambridge. Since starting his sobriety journey in 2017, he said his "life has gotten 100% better."For Townsend, recovery is a daily practice. He participates in Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous, has a sponsor, sponsors four others and has worked and re-worked the 12 steps over and over.
"We never complete it because once we finish the steps, we just go through them over again, and every time we go through them again, there's something else that we work on," Townsend said.
Townsend frames recovery as a lifelong lifestyle rooted in spiritual principles. He believes choosing the right peers in the 12-step rooms are critical. "Vigilance is the key to success," Townsend said.
He's been in and out of recovery since May of 2017, relapsing for a few years following his first time getting sober. He now works as a peer support specialist at Grace Street Recovery in Easton and has adopted the philosophy of recovery as a lifestyle.
As a peer support specialist, Townsend connects individuals with housing or treatment options. "It's rewarding and motivating seeing people still stuck out there in a spot that I was at," he said.
Though he finds the work rewarding, it's also difficult. "It's kind of like a double-edged sword. You get attached to people and try to help, you know, and some of them don't make it," Townsend said.
He described addiction as a disease where drugs or alcohol are a symptom of an underlying issue, saying it's like having a hole that needs to be filled.
"You have to make sure you're filling that hole with the right things, which is like spiritual principles, the program, being honest," he said. "Because the disease can show up in other ways."
For Townsend, acceptance really came with the fourth of the 12 steps, which is when he wrote down an inventory of his life. He said he no longer feels guilt or shame because he's no longer the person on that piece of paper anymore.
He's stopped doing the things that once caused him shame.
"I'm a totally different person than that. And that's the blessing of this is our message, is hope. Our promise is freedom from active addiction," Townsend said.
In his sobriety, Townsend takes pride in having stability at work and being an improved parent to his two kids and partner to his girlfriend.
Townsend also expressed his gratitude toward Talbot County Sheriff Joe Gamble for the work he does for the recovery community.
"I mean, he's a huge resource and a huge asset to the recovery community here in Talbot County," Townsend said. "You know, he does a lot of behind the scenes stuff that people don't know about. He really cares and that's that's a plus."
He is also appreciative of the Talbot Goes Purple initiative, which was spearheaded by Gamble to raise awareness about substance abuse and prevention. Townsend said it allows him to remember those he's lost to the disease and to think about how far he has come.
His advice for people who are seeking to get sober but may not know how is to not be afraid to ask for help.
"The best thing you can do is just ask for help, man. There are plenty of resources out there and people that would do anything for you to help you get on the path that they're on," Townsend said. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on addiction recovery, peer support, and substance‑abuse resources, which are primarily health‑related issues.

title: Suicide Prevention Walk at Perry Point attracts 525 participants
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content:
Suicide Prevention Walk at Perry Point attracts 525 participants

 September 12, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 356
 Words 

 Read News Document

 PERRY POINT — More than 500 people participated in the 3rd annual Suicide Prevention Walk on the Perry Point Veterans Administration Medical Center Campus in Cecil County on Thursday morning, continuing the year-to-year climb in numbers.September is Suicide Prevention Month, and Thursday was World Suicide Prevention Day.
The annual event, which is part of the VA's initiative to end veteran suicide by, in part, raising community awareness of the subject, attracted approximately 200 walkers in 2023, according to planners. That number hiked to about 300 walkers last year, they reported.
On Thursday, marking a gigantic leap, 535 people participated in the Suicide Prevention Walk on the medical center campus, including VA employees — leadership, clinicians, staff — and VA volunteers. Military veterans, their families and community members also walked the route during the event.
In addition to raising awareness about the help available to prevent suicide, the walk helps reduce the stigma associated with suicide and mental health challenges.
Along the path of the walk, with a route that started outside the chapel and ran through sections of the campus, stations were set up and they offered activities like drumming, painting rocks, creating hope boxes, and petting ponies from one of the VA's community partners, Chesapeake Therapeutic Riding in Harford County.
In addition to the walk, there was a Health & Resource Fair for veterans in the gym.
Each year, there is a unique, commemorative T-shirt featuring artwork by one of the veteran patients.
U.S. Army Veteran Nicole Spencer (Army 82nd Airborne) created the artwork on the T-shirts that were given to the people who participated in Thursday's event, according to a VA spokeswoman, who commented, "Nicole began exploring her creative talents in recent years, through multiple tough health challenges, and says it helped her get through some long stays in the hospital."
The slogan for this year's event was "Hope Through Connections."
Veterans can sign up for VA health care at V-A-gov and ANY Veteran in crisis can call 988 and press 1 for free, 24/7, confidential help.
Among other activities the VA Maryland Health Care System has planned for Suicide Prevention month is a Tree of Life/Day of Remembrance ceremony on September 29. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.
