title: 'Make Rural America Healthy Again': health program seeks feedback
author: Lily Tierney
content:
'Make Rural America Healthy Again': health program seeks feedback

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 219
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The One Big Beautiful Bill Act, which was signed into law in June, created the Rural Health Transformation Program, also known as "Make Rural America Healthy Again."The state is currently seeking feedback from residents, particularly rural Marylanders and those who serve them. In addition, local health departments will host listening sessions to understand community needs and solicit ideas and recommendations. Feedback on the program will close on Sept. 30.
The program will provide $50 billion to 50 states over the course of five years. Maryland is projected to see $100 million of those funds. However, the state still needs to apply for the program in order to receive the money.
Half of those funds will be distributed based on rurality, quality of the application and state policy, while the other half will be distributed equally among all states upon approved applications, according to Maryland Department of Health's website. Once applications are approved, funds will be distributed from 2026 to 2030.
The strategic goals of the program are prevention and management of chronic disease, behavioral health, sustainable access, workforce development, innovative care and tech innovation.
The dates of the listening sessions can be found at health.maryland.gov, and questions regarding the process or feedback on the program can be sent to mdh.transformruralhealth@maryland.gov. There is also an option to mail in responses on the website. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a state‑wide rural health transformation program, funding, and public feedback sessions, which directly relates to health policy and services.

title: Color run brightens rainy day in Kent County
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content:
Color run brightens rainy day in Kent County

 September 15, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com | Section: Local News 
 
 345
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHESTERTOWN — Painted sneakers and damp, smiling faces could be spotted on Sunday morning down South Cross Street. The rain did nothing to stop walkers and runners of all ages from participating in the 2025 5K Color Fun Run/Walk, benefiting Kent Goes Purple.Kent Goes Purple is a substance abuse awareness and prevention initiative of the Kent County Sheriff's Office and Chestertown Rotary Club, engaging the community and youth to stand up against substance abuse.
Now into its seventh year, the race began bright and early at Wilmer Park, extended down South Cross Street, turned at John Brown Road then returned to the park for a finish.
It kicked off with purple foam bubbles shooting courtesy of Willy Woo Woo Productions and a burst of blue paint at the finish line coating everybody. People scattered playfully away, ducking under the police tape heading for the road.
Along the route, participants, if they asked for it, were doused in more paint by over-eager students. Roadside, the Chestertown Elks Club provided water and encouragement. Police did a great job ensuring participants were safe from traffic as mothers walked their children in strollers, friends ran beside each other and dads jogged with their daughters.
After the race, the Purple Jamboree was held at the park. Kids danced and played in the foam machine of Willy Woo Woo, who provided some sports games, popcorn, cotton candy and snow cones.
Paul Gunther's Catering offered cheeseburgers and grilled chicken sandwiches.
Along the walkway toward the water, Shore Community Outreach Team were on-hand to administer health advice and blood pressure checks, the Elks informed people of their kids Drug Awareness Program handing out Frisbees, coloring books and other items. Recovery in Motion and the The AF Whitsitt Center offered assistance and information about their programs.
Andy Meehan Chestertown Rotary Club member said, "We had a very enthusiastic turnout. Over 130 people signed up and with volunteers and vendors that's another 30. People had a great time."
They all enjoyed themselves but are hoping for a sunny day next year come race time.
For information about Kent Goes Purple check out kentgoespurple.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a community 5K run that promotes substance‑abuse awareness, provides health advice and blood‑pressure checks, and highlights a public‑health initiative, making Health the most fitting category.

title: Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one
author: Amelia Blades Steward
content:
Local testicular cancer survivor shoots for a hole in one

 September 16, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Amelia Blades Steward | Section: Events 
 
 867
 Words 

 Read News Document

 According to Johns Hopkins Brady Urological Institute, testicular cancer is one of the most common cancers in young men, with nearly 10,000 new diagnoses each year in the United States. It is highly curable when it first develops but can quickly spread if not treated promptly.Andrew Dorbin of Preston is a husband, father and testicular cancer survivor who hopes to educate men about the risks and symptoms of testicular cancer at the "Putts Fore! Nuts" miniature golf tournament on Oct. 18 from 11:30 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Embers Island Mini-Golf in Ocean City. The rain date will be Oct. 25.
Dorbin was diagnosed with late-stage testicular cancer (Choriocarcinoma) in the spring of 2023. It then metastasized to his lungs and abdomen.
While undergoing multiple rounds of chemotherapy, he was overwhelmed by the generosity of his family, friends and community, who rallied to support him and his family through his diagnosis and treatment. That experience of compassion and care lit a fire in him.
"During my longest inpatient stay at Johns Hopkins Hospital, I witnessed other patients facing their battle alone without the same support system I had. That was hard for me to stomach. It made me realize that I wanted to give back when I was able and build something that could offer strength, resources and connection to others navigating their fight against testicular cancer," Dorbin said.
"Honestly, I'm not particularly good at regular golf — I'm only there for my friend's comic relief — but I've always enjoyed miniature golf and came up with this funny tournament name on one of the sickest days of my treatment," he said.
The idea eventually grew, and Dorbin founded the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund, a component fund of Chesapeake Charities Inc., a Maryland-based nonprofit. The fund is focused on raising awareness, providing education and building a supportive community fighting this disease.
He is committed to making testicular health a topic that young men are not afraid to talk about and ensuring that no one faces cancer without a community standing beside them. The tournament is the first step to accomplishing that.
"I chose an amazing partner in Chesapeake Charities to help make my dream a reality. The money that was used to found this venture came from what was left over from my personal GoFundMe campaign, making this essentially a 100% community-funded initiative," Dorbin said.
The fund's fundraising efforts will go toward community networking opportunities and mental health and wellness programs to ensure no one feels like they are facing the testicular cancer fight alone. Dorbin hopes his educational outreach will encourage young men to challenge the stigmas and pay attention to their health.
"We are encouraging our communities of young men, ages 14 to 35, to be aware of their bodies and to take action when something doesn't feel right," he said.
Dorbin reflects on his journey, sharing, "My journey almost ended before it started. When I found the lump, I almost didn't act. It seems petty now, but I was worried about the cost of my health insurance deductible and thought it was nothing serious. Through the encouragement of a friend who was a nurse, I decided to get it checked out. If I had not acted as quickly as I did, I'm not sure I would be sitting here today."
He said that, like him, men in their early 20s and 30s feel they are invincible and that they will not develop any major medical issues.
"No one wants to go to the doctor when they are young. Also, I had never been shown how to correctly check myself for abnormalities in my testicles. Self-examination is key to early detection," he said.
Dorbin hopes that teens and adults will participate in the tournament while learning more about the disease and how to protect themselves and their loved ones. He shares that the event will also create community connection — helping people learn who the disease is affecting, what support people need and connecting people to resources in the community.
"This event is going to be a blast. Participants can expect to play two rounds of mini-golf, all while challenging their knowledge, luck, and putting skills. Hole Hecklers — professional comedians will set up a mock sports casting both at one of the miniature golf holes and roast participants as they putt. We also have a variety of prizes and awards that will make the event enjoyable for everyone. For me, the best part is that you don't have to be standing on the podium to walk away a winner," Dorbin said.
In the future, Dorbin hopes that the Wayfinders Testicular Health Fund can support outings for survivors of testicular cancer and help build a community of survivors, since many men still suffer in silence with the stigma attached to the disease.
"This launch would not be possible without the incredible generosity of my friends, family, and neighbors here on Maryland's Eastern Shore. Their belief in this mission, and in me, has carried me through the toughest years of my life," he adds.
Sponsorships are still available for the event. Registration information and sponsorship opportunities are available at wayfindersthf.org. Participants are limited, and registration will be available online on Sept. 18. Registration is non-refundable.
For further information, contact Andrew Dorbin at wayfindersthf@gmail.com. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a testicular cancer survivor raising awareness, providing education on early detection, and promoting health resources, making health the primary focus.

title: Inside Caroline County's fight against substance use
author: Staff Writer
content:
Inside Caroline County's fight against substance use

 September 19, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Headlines 
 
 106
 Words 

 Read News Document

 "Caroline Goes Purple" is a big initiative.When the proclamation was made at the Caroline County Commissioners meeting at the beginning of this month, it made me think about all the work the county does to make residents aware of substance use.
I talked to multiple county officials about services available, different programs and what is so important about "Caroline Goes Purple."
All county officials gave me great answers, but one stuck out the most — the work of substance use awareness is bigger than just one month. Its a 24/7 effort.
You can read more about the county's efforts in my story below. Thanks for reading.

title: Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
Caroline County officials share why substance use awareness is bigger than just a month

 September 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 793
 Words 

 Read News Document

 DENTON — While all Caroline County substance use awareness programs acknowledge the importance of "Caroline Goes Purple" in September, they know the work is done all year-round.The Caroline County Health Department credits this work for a dramatic reduction in overdoses.
According to Health Department officials, in 2023, Caroline County experienced 19 overdoses. In 2024, the number was less than 11 overdoses, and that trend seems to be continuing this year.
When number is under 11, the county is not allowed to share the exact number due to state regulations, officials said.
The efforts to reduce overdoses are celebrated during the month of September, when the county holds multiple substance use awareness events to connect residents to services the county provides. Jessica Tuel, director of Caroline County Behavioral Health and director for Caroline Goes Purple, said all these events are designed to show residents they're not alone.
"I think that people need to understand that a lot of these events are obviously to bring education and prevention services, but it's also to provide connection to those who are experiencing substance use," Tuel said. "We have a motto here. It is 'the opposite of addiction is not sobriety, it is human connection.' So, by bringing these things to the community, number one, it gives a level of education and prevention services, but it also helps those who have been through it or going through it know that they're not alone."
This is a goal stakeholders in Caroline County try to meet outside of September.
Monthly, the county and several municipalities hold joint meeting, called the Drug Free Caroline Group, to close gaps in service so the county can be strong year-round.
"We have a local drug and alcohol council meeting once a month to discuss trends that's happening," said Sloane Franklin, Caroline County state's attorney. "It has the law enforcement, courts, mental health, and substance abuse counselors, clergy, county behavioral health or substance abuse programs… We talk about grants that might be available to our partners to go out, and I seek those grants so they can continue to provide services to these people."
These services include a "safe station" located at the Caroline County Sheriff's Office.
The safe station allows an individual to come into the Sheriff's Office and say, "I need help." An off-duty officer will then search the person and confiscate any paraphernalia without charging the person.
The Sheriff's Office also has an on-site peer, Kristie Thompson, five days a week in partnership with the Sante Group. Thompson goes into the community and makes residents aware of options available.
Thompson said the goal is to get the individual experiencing substance-related difficulties into inpatient treatment.
"Our partnership and relationship with Sante Group is is definitely a high point for the county as far as being able to provide this service to citizens of Caroline County," Caroline County Sheriff Donnie Baker said. "As far as working out of this building, having one of their employees here being able to people who are in distress needing support services or wanting to get off controlled dangerous substances, I think that is definitely a high point when you can take somebody and give them the services they need."
The Health Department is another community partner that helps residents be aware of the dangers of substance use and their options. Tuel highlighted some of the services the Behavioral Health extension offers.
"We have a level one outpatient mental health and substance use program," Tuel said. "We serve a lot of different people throughout various stages of substance use. We provide medication-assisted treatment, as well and we have clinicians in the schools. We do mobile treatment for adults and for kids at the both high schools, and we're expanding into the middle schools. We try to offer as many services as we are able to as a public health system."
Tuel said the key to reducing overdoes in the county has been including peers who have lived the experience to help others still struggling.
"I think that in the last couple of years, we've done a really great job of including peers," Tuel said. "Peers are those who have lived experience and are on the other side of it. They've really given us a great perspective and hope that we're doing the right thing and that there is success in this.
"I think that sometimes as first responders, and sometimes people in our field, what happens is we get very discouraged because we don't see the hope at the end. Having peers embedded in a lot of these services, like at the sheriff's department and in our services at the Health Department and throughout the community, it really even gives us hope that we're doing the right thing and that we're on the right path and that people can heal and they can get better."

title: We need each other to sharpen conversation skills
author: MELINDA BURRELL
content:
We need each other to sharpen conversation skills

 September 20, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MELINDA BURRELL | Section: Columns 
 
 516
 Words 

 Read News Document

 September, and "back to school," is a great time to sharpen skills. When life feels as complicated and fast-changing as it seems right now, it's particularly good to build our communication skills.Better communication gives us stronger relationships, and stronger relationships help us navigate challenging times.
A few insights from neuroscience are especially helpful.
Humans evolved to survive in groups. Because of that, we worry about how well we're fitting in with our group. We're constantly looking for clues about what others think about us.
If someone belittles us, shuts us out, or treats us unfairly, our Spidey sense goes off. We fear it means we're not part of the group, which is dangerous for our survival. We sense a social threat, and social threats are so urgent for us that they activate the same brain circuits as physical threats.
Management guru David Rock developed the SCARF model to describe these key social situations in which we can either feel socially threatened or rewarded.
Essentially, we're hardwired to crave five things: status (being valued by others), certainty (having information to predict the future), autonomy (having some control over our lives), relatedness (feeling connected to others) and fairness (being treated reasonably).
If we get those five things, we relax. Our defenses come down, and we can talk openly and creatively with others. Sounds like a basis for a rich conversation, right?
However, if we don't get those things, we feel threatened. We tend to shut down and lose our ability to think rationally. A Case Western Reserve University study showed that being rejected immediately lowers people's IQ by 25% and their reasoning ability by 30%, while also making them more aggressive. Sounds like a basis for a fight.
So how do we build our skills to create positive SCARF conditions in our interactions and avoid creating negative ones?
First, think about how often you do the following, in both team and family settings. Give yourself a "SCARF score." Then brainstorm ways you can increase your SCARF score.
Affirm others' status: Go out of your way to acknowledge other people, especially when they contribute something to a team or family situation. Listen and ask questions that show you're interested. Don't publicly give negative feedback or compare people, especially family or team members.Provide certainty: Share information that helps others to plan, such as expectations or constraints for an event or a family vacation. Explain decisions. Don't unexpectedly change plans or forget to follow through on promises.Offer autonomy: Delegate decisions and tasks where you can, so that others share control over joint projects, whether job-related events or family routines. Offer options for people to choose between. Don't always be the problem-solver, but instead encourage others to resolve issues.Foster relatedness: Deliberately and regularly create time to be together, including meals (without devices!). Don't exclude members of your team or family from shared events.Uphold fairness: Apply rules consistently to everyone and offer everyone a voice in decisions. Don't be silent when you've made a mistake or been unfair.
September temperatures are cooling. Let's help tempers cool as well! Build your SCARF skills and enjoy richer, more fulfilling conversations and connections.
We need each other. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on improving communication skills and mental well‑being using neuroscience insights, which aligns best with the Health category (mental health/social well‑being).

title: Compass Regional Hospice Fashion Show raises funds for local care
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.comANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Compass Regional Hospice Fashion Show raises funds for local care

 September 26, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.comANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 519
 Words 

 Read News Document

 STEVENSVILLE — Compass Regional Hospice welcomed more than 200 guests to shop, bid on auction items and enjoy lunch while benefiting local hospice care during its annual fashion show Sept. 18 at Kent Island Resort. The sold-out event showcased selections from Compass Closet, the organization's retail consignment boutique, with prominent community members serving as volunteer models. "We are excited to reach out to more of the community," said Jessica Sherbrooke, volunteer manager. This year marked the first time the event was held at Kent Island Resort, providing more space for the growing attendance. Guests shopped a pop-up boutique featuring items from Compass Closet and bid on donated auction pieces while community celebrities modeled the boutique's featured selections. Compass Closet has offered affordable fashion finds to benefit the hospice's mission since 1991. Volunteers carefully select standout pieces throughout the year to feature in the annual fashion show, with all modeled outfits available for purchase. The fashion show has been a community fundraiser for Compass for at least 30 years, according to Heather Guerieri, chief executive officer. Compass Regional Hospice is celebrating its 40th year of providing care to patients and families in Queen Anne's, Kent and Caroline counties. "The community always comes out for a great time and shows their full support," Guerieri said. The consignment boutique operates entirely through volunteers, who Sherbrooke described as essential to Compass' mission. Leading up to the event, Compass highlighted volunteers through fashion show model spotlights on social media. Compass Closet is located in Kent Towne Center in Chester. More information about Compass Regional Hospice is available atcompassregionalhospice.org

title: Don't base medicine on politics
author: Staff Writer
content:
Don't base medicine on politics

 September 27, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Editors Inbox 
 
 599
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As two pediatricians with over 80 years of combined practice, we are witnessing with increased concern the direction health care for children in our country is taking. The Trump Administration's public health decisions, in particular those of the Secretary of Health and Human Services, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., appear to be based more on the results of a political calculus than established medical facts and experience.Indeed, we recognize that medicine is not free of erroneous practices. For centuries, blood-letting was considered a necessary adjunct to the treatment of serious illness. George Washington was bled multiple times on his death bed without success. Up until recently, we recommended that all families have syrup of Ipecac on hand to give to a child who had ingested a possible poison. This was found to be counterproductive and the practice discontinued.
Possibly the most important pediatric issue that RFK has questioned has been with regard to vaccines.
Starting over 100 years ago, vaccines began to be an essential part of childhood health management. The result has been a dramatic increase in the survival of children. Before widespread vaccine use, death from infectious diseases in childhood was common. It is estimated that more than one in five children in the United States died before five years of age of infection in the early 1900s. Of the eight most common infections, seven are now prevented by vaccination, and the death rate from these diseases has almost vanished.
In many cases, increasingly so at the present time, vaccines are approved only after study in the laboratory and with live patients. Longitudinal study is a further safeguard. An oral vaccine against the diarrheal illness cause by rotovirus is a good example where a rare adverse event was observed in practice and the vaccine was withdrawn, reformulated and reintroduced. The currently approved vaccine is considered to be much safer than the original formulation.
Vaccines are incredibly safe. RFK mis-uses data from the Vaccine Adverse Reporting System to scare parents into believing that there have been multiple childhood deaths caused by vaccines. With our 80 years of experience, neither of us has seen a vaccine-related event that caused pediatric death. Furthermore, he has continued to contend that vaccines, in spite of multiple studies to the contrary, cause autism.
The question can be raised as to why does RFK carry forth this program of mis-medicine?
As a very public person, we can look to his own life for possible answers. It is known that at some time in the past, RFK Jr. harbored a parasite in his brain. This has apparently been shown to be inactive. However, he retains evidence that his brain contains a cyst with calcification. In addition, he suffers from a disability called spasmodic dysphonia. It should be noted that this rare disability is not due to a local vocal cord dysfunction but is the result of a central neurologic, i.e. brain, abnormality. Finally, he has reported that he had evidence of heavy metal (mercury) poisoning that required medical treatment. Mercury poisoning is a serious problem and can cause neurologic damage as the people of Minamata, Japan, can attest.
Is it not reasonable to ask whether a person who has almost dictatorial power with regards to our children's health has compromised neurologic function? The problem here, as we mentioned above, is that any discussion of RFK and his bizarre behavior and decisions is deflected by the underlying political ramifications of such questioning. We ask, in all due deference, should our children's health and even survival be determined not by science, but by a single person's political beliefs.
DR. BRIAN J. CORDEN
DR. JUDITH P. GIESKE
Easton 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses medical issues, vaccine safety, and critiques political influence on pediatric health, which aligns directly with the Health topic.

title: Five counties unite for recovery awareness event at Church Hill Park
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Five counties unite for recovery awareness event at Church Hill Park

 September 30, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: News 
 
 534
 Words 

 Read News Document

 CHURCH HILL — Standing united as one community in support of recovery and awareness across the area, Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Inc. hosted its annual five county collaborative Going Purple Together at Church Hill Park Sept. 27.Organizations and agencies from neighboring counties of Queen Anne's, Talbot, Kent Caroline, and Dorchester came together to show the community all the resources available for substance recovery, mental health, addiction, and support.
Annually supporting recovery across the Mid-Shore region, the 2025 Going Purple Together event offered a blend of, fun, education and community engagement, with local vendors, activities, and the message of continually learning about substance abuse, overdose, recovery, peer support, and prevention.
Highlighting important community resources in a fun, casual environment, festivities were complete with DJ, food trucks, giveaways, family fun activities and performances by Hula Hoop Love.
Building awareness through engagement
Recognizing substance abuse awareness and prevention is more nuanced than "Just Say No" community engagement is the first step in addressing issues.
By building awareness in a fun environment, the community can be proactive and not reactive, said Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Judge Lynn Knight, a founder of the Queen Anne's County Circuit Court Assisted Recovery and Treatment program.
Ten years ago substance abuse resources did not exist in the county like they do today, and the growth in support is tremendous, she said.
Personal stories of recovery
Showcasing the possibilities of recovery straight from those who have lived it first hand, peer support specialists shared their personal experiences to help inspire and encourage those in need.
One such peer, Kaylee Whitby, of Federalsburg, noted for the longest time her personal story was a continual cycle riddled with active addiction, treatment, jail, and legal issues.
Finally after an attempt on her own life, Whitby fought to give herself a new way of living because "it was obvious my way was not working."
Through continual effort and the support of peers, Whitby was able to join in recovery services that finally made a lasting impact on her recovery journey and ultimately her life.
Whitby voiced gratitude for the opportunities offered through supportive recovery houses, including security, accountability, growth, and networking connections still part of her life today.
"Recovery saved my life," she said. Because of recovery Whitby learned to surrender and make amends to rebuild relationships. Whitby was able to be the mother that her children deserved and be the person she wanted to be.
Knowing there were others out in the community with their own similar experiences helped shape Whitby and she was eager to pay that forward to inspire others and be part of that journey.
"Today I chose to live," Whitby said.
Comprehensive support services
Understanding the many avenues that go hand in hand with recovery, organizations connected the community with the tools for support including behavioral and mental health, social services, gambling help, out and inpatient services, as well as resources for loved ones of those facing diseases of addiction.
Mid Shore Behavioral Health, is proud to continually work closely with community and county health departments and administration to erase stigma and further advocacy said Alisha Saulsbury, forensic mental health program manager.
Seeing people smile proud of themselves on their recovery journey makes it all worthwhile, Saulsbury said.
More information about Mid Shore Behavioral Health can be found at midshorebehavioralhealth.org. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community event promoting substance abuse recovery, mental health resources, and addiction awareness, which aligns primarily with the Health topic.

title: Notice a copperhead? Leave it alone
author: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com
content:
Notice a copperhead? Leave it alone

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Ilana Williams iwilliams@somdnews.com | Section: News 
 
 732
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Steve Irwin was Brittani Long's idol growing up. Too bad the copperhead snake that bit her foot didn't get the joke.Long, a resident in Mechanicsville, got bit by the snake when she checked on her chicken and ducks after work one evening in July, she said. It was too dark to see the copperhead snake in her path, which was between a shed and her back deck stairs.
"I knew they existed," Long said. "But I never would have expected to see one."
When the first paramedic arrived, Long received epinephrine and Benadryl, she said. At the hospital, she was given an IV and morphine, but not CroFab, a type of antivenom.
Copperhead snakes are one of two venomous snakes in Maryland, Beth Schlimm, Maryland state herpetologist, said. The other is the timber rattlesnake, which is primarily in the western part of the state.
Copperheads are tan or a light bright with darker blotches being an hourglass or a Hershey's Kiss shape.
The active season for most snakes, including copperheads, is April through October, Schlimm said. During the fall, snakes look for places to spend the winter.
MedStar Health in St. Mary's County treated 18 people for snake bites so far this year.
Swelling can progress quickly, which affects the doctor's decision to give antivenom, Dr. Maria Lawrynowicz, emergency department doctor at Medstar Health in St. Mary's County, said.
If bitten, it's recommended to take off jewelry and immobilize the joint to slow the venom. Doctors will mark where there is redness and swelling and do measurements on the area that was bitten to see how fast swelling progresses.
If the doctor decides to administer CroFab, they start with four vials, Lawrynowicz said. Each vial can cost between $3,000 to $6,000. A repeat dose is given every six hours depending on the swelling, blood count and ability to clot blood, which is tested every few hours.
"This isn't something we give to everyone because it's extremely expensive," Lawrynowicz said.
Anyone who receives antivenom goes to the intensive care unit for 24 hours to monitor swelling, blood pressure and dizziness, the doctor said. If patients are seen for a small copperhead bite and they don't receive antivenom they usually can go home after six to eight hours with measurement marks.
There will be local symptoms around the bite like puncture marks, redness, pain, swelling and bruising, Lawrynowicz said. Around a quarter of copperhead bites are dry bites, meaning the snake gives a warning shot and does not release any venom.
"If you're going to get bit by a [poisonous] snake, a copperhead is one to get bit by," Lawrynowicz said.
More severe bites can affect the whole body over the course of hours, she said. These symptoms include dizziness, low blood pressure, local tissue destruction and bleeding and oozing from the site.
"I was terrified," Long said. "I kept it elevated the whole time to keep the main swelling away from my foot."
Long experienced swelling up her leg to her thigh, she said. Once the swelling went down, her leg was bruised for three or four weeks.
University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center treated three people since the start of 2025 for copperhead bites, Dr. Maxwell Ginsburg, medical director and chairman of the Department of Emergency Medicine at the center, said. Each of them required the use of CroFab.
"Copperhead bites are not something the medical center sees often, but it is something they are aware of and always have the antidote for," Ginsburg said. "The sooner you get started, the better the outcome will be."
For any snake bite, do not suck out the venom, cut into the wound, apply a tourniquet, shock the area or apply ice to the area, Lawrynowicz said. After getting bit, immobilize the joint then go to the emergency room.
"Don't mess with snakes," Lawrynowicz said. "If you're hiking, stick to the trails … if you do get bit don't try to get the snake."
Copperheads are often found in spots with lots of leaf litter or wood and rock piles, Schlimm said.
It's best to keep yards maintained and clean. If homeowners have bird feeders or cat food outside, keep them away from the house. During the summer and at night, wear closed-toed shoes during yard work, don't reach into dark areas, wear garden gloves and try to use a rake to pull debris.
"It's not something to be afraid of," Schlimm said. "It's just a species to be aware of and to be cautious around." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily discusses medical treatment, symptoms, and advice related to copperhead snake bites, which aligns with health coverage.

title: 'To save lives, break the silence': Speakers share suicide prevention experiences
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
'To save lives, break the silence': Speakers share suicide prevention experiences

 October 2, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com | Section: State News 
 
 662
 Words 

 Read News Document

 The aim of the day was pretty basic — "to save lives, break the silence and remind every person that hope is within reach."The Southern Maryland Suicide Prevention Summit, a four-hour session, was a way to share strategies to stop someone from ending his or her life.
Hosted by Unstoppable You Ministries Inc., the event was held Sept. 27 at University System of Maryland's Southern Maryland location in California.
The ministry's founder, Jennifer Foxworthy, said her organization provides services to deal with the impacts of homelessness, human trafficking and domestic violence, noting that "suicide" is a looming demon in all of those adverse situations.
To the attendees of the event, which was free to the public, Foxworthy warned "some parts of the presentation may be heavy."
The event's two keynote speakers, in fact, articulated the gravity of the issue in their brief presentations.
Kim Klump's story was about her son, Jesse, a senior at Snow Hill High School on Maryland's Eastern Shore who died by his own hand in 2009. Klump noted Jesse was an athlete, scholar and student leader.
"This is not someone you would expect would take his life," she said.
Klump admitted that "in hindsight" she saw signs that her son was consumed with "depression."
"He gave precious possessions away," Klump recalled.
Her son also kept a journal, which was found later and revealed some of his anxieties of the present and future.
Since her son was an avid kayaker and had worked at The Pocomoke Canoe Company, Klump and others organized a fundraiser called "Jesse's Paddle," which raises funds for scholarships in his memory.
Klump said that while the fundraiser is a good way to keep her son's memory alive, she decided it wasn't enough. That's when she decided to start a prevention program in schools.
In addition to teaching coping skills, the Jesse Klump Suicide and Awareness Program started an open conversation.
"Every conversation has the power to make a difference," Klump said.
Last school year the awareness program visited four high schools and saw nearly 1,500 school students. This past summer the program hosted a "summer eco-therapy camp," which included such challenging activities as kayaking, canoeing and rope-climbing.
Klump said the organization uses grant funding to fund its programs.
Pressures of serving the nation
The summit's second keynoter, Navy Capt. Byron Lee, began his talk on a light-hearted note, passing a beach ball to attendees and engaging them in a game of "bump, bump, catch."
"We all react to things differently," Lee told the audience, adding that things that bring stress into people's lives aren't much different than the things that make people happy.
Lee's jovial demeanor turned emotional when he revealed that at one point in his 28-year armed forces career he had considered taking his own life.
"Nothing looked positive, nobody knew," Lee said.
He was able to get help on the base he was assigned to from a mental health expert.
Lee said that with its pressures to be ready to react and serve as a protector, while dealing with the pressures of assignment moves, raising a family and maintaining personal health, members of the military are emotionally vulnerable.
"All of those things were weighing on me," he said.
Lee provided 2023 statistics from the U.S. Department of Defense (now the Department of War) that showed that year there were 523 suicides in the nation's military, which was 9% higher than the previous year. The data also showed firearms were the primary method for carrying out a suicide.
In noting her own prior experience in the armed forces, Foxworthy said, "We may look big and strong but we often suffer in silence. It's important to know your resources."
Nearly 20 vendors participated in the summit, including the health departments of all three Southern Maryland counties, the Maryland Department of Health Behavioral Health Administration, service members, veterans and their families, as well as the Charles County Center for Children and Community Crisis Services Inc.
For more information about Unstoppable You Ministries, go to www.unstoppableyouministries.org.
For immediate, confidential mental health support, call or text 988 to reach the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

title: A visit with Easton’s maternal wellness advocate
author: Lily Tierney
content:
A visit with Easton’s maternal wellness advocate

 October 8, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Headlines 
 
 133
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Samantha Basham Loza greeted me with a cup of coffee and a warm smile as I joined her at the Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center she opened last year.She showed me around the beautiful building and explained the uses for each room. A massage room, a therapy office, a lactation consultation space, a large area downstairs where they hold classes, and Loza's office, where we sat and chatted for an hour.
As soon as we started talking, her passion for maternal wellness was evident.
Loza and I are both alums of American University, and graduated with degrees in journalism. She wore many hats, most of them in healthcare and sales, before opening the Village.
Read about Loza's journey and the Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center in below. Thanks for reading and have a great day!

title: Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Wellness center offers support for mothers on the Shore

 October 9, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 661
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center opened its doors last October to provide women on the Eastern Shore with a single, trusted source for various services.Samantha Basham Loza was inspired to create a space like this after having her first child in the height of the COVID-19 pandemic. She was astounded by the lack of resources, education and community she had during this time.
"I was so blindsided by the entire experience, and it was really frustrating because I consider myself a highly educated person that works hard to find the right resources," Loza said. "And the fact that I couldn't even find what I needed to help me at each stage of this process was just completely shocking."
The entire process of giving birth was scary for Loza. She was at a hospital in Anne Arundel County and was given an epidural that made her completely numb from her neck down, which she said caused her to have a panic attack.
Loza said her daughter was immediately transferred to the NICU after delivery.
Because she was was numb from the epidural, the baby was crowning without Loza realizing or feeling it, and none of the doctors or nurses noticed. This caused Loza's daughter to have meconium aspiration syndrome. According to John's Hopkins Medicine, meconium aspiration syndrome occurs in 5 to 10% of births.
"I was reflecting on that entire experience thinking like, 'How is this the standard?'" Loza said.
With her first child, Loza said she didn't have the knowledge base on the process of giving birth, breastfeeding or managing hormonal changes. She described the experience as isolating.
"We don't talk about pregnancy often enough, and how isolating it can be, and all the changes and all the sacrifices. We don't talk about fertility issues often enough. We don't talk about miscarriages enough. We don't teach any of it," Loza said.
She said her goal with the wellness center is to start these conversations and create community while doing so.
The center offers an array of classes and playgroups for children. There are courses for pregnant women and new moms, and the University of Maryland's obstetrics practice comes in to talk about fertility and prenatal care quarterly.
In addition, the wellness center has birth doulas, massage therapists, lactation consultants, a speech language pathologist, a pediatric nurse practitioner and a craniosacral therapist, who will be starting in November.
"A really big misconception about the name of the business, The Village Maternal Holistic Wellness Center, is that holistic means crunchy and it doesn't," Loza said. "It just means we're considering you as a whole person."
Loza defined a doula as a non-medical support person who provides educational, physical and emotional support during pregnancy, birth and postpartum and also helps connect clients with resources.
The center recently received a grant from the Talbot County Health Department to fund the training of 18 new doulas, four of whom are bilingual and two of which whom exclusively speak Spanish. The grant is also assisting the doulas with Medicaid credentialing.
When Loza got pregnant with her second child, she decided to have a home birth midwife, one of the first contacts she made when looking into starting her business.
Loza said her pregnancy and birth with her son was a completely different experience than with her daughter.
"It was so personal. She knew exactly where I was coming from. She knew exactly what was happening with my mental state, and what I was eating and all the things. And she always had a recommendation for a book to read, or YouTube videos to watch or things like that," Loza said.
"Though she planned to deliver at home, she was transferred to the Easton Hospital because her son's heart rate was low. Her midwife stayed by her side and advocated for her throughout the process.
After having two very different birthing experiences, Loza has become passionate about educating pregnant women about the entirety of the process. She hopes to expand the centers services by opening a nonprofit arm in the near future. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a maternal wellness center offering health services, doula support, lactation consulting, and prenatal education, making health the primary theme, with education as a secondary aspect.

title: Working Artists Forum raises $14,000 for breast cancer treatment
author: Konner Metz
content:
Working Artists Forum raises $14,000 for breast cancer treatment

 October 10, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 342
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Waterfowl Festival building was decked out in pink last weekend, including over 50 works of art on display for a special breast cancer fundraiser.The Working Artists Forum held its second annual Pretty in Pink event Oct. 3 and 4, raising funds for the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health's Clark Comprehensive Breast Center.
Stacey Sass, co-chair of the fundraiser, said around $14,000 was raised over the two-day event. Between the forum and the Washington Society of Landscape Painters, nearly 60 works of art were on display and for sale. More than 20 sold, Sass said.
Some pieces were full of pink or pink-adjacent colors, while others sported a small speck or dot of pink.
"Our mission this weekend is not only to raise money, but to educate everybody about the symptoms, treatments and support of those facing breast cancer," Sass said in opening remarks on Oct. 3.
The Clark Comprehensive Breast Center, located near Route 50 and off of Idlewild Avenue, delivers professional treatment and support to women with breast cancer and other breast diseases.
Dr. Kathryn Kelley, the center's director, said 2025 "has been a year of transition and really positive growth" for the center.
The team has made 137 new breast cancer diagnoses and completed over 12,000 imaging studies for women on the Mid-Shore, Kelley said.
"You can tell how hard our team is working to care for our patients in our five-county area," Kelley said, referring to Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties.
On Friday, the center's former director, Dr. Roberta Lilly, was honored for her longtime leadership. Lilly retired first in 2020 after 13 years as director and again in June after serving a stint as interim director.
Dr. Chris Levey, a radiologist with Shore Regional Health, credited Lilly with having the initial vision to create the Clark Comprehensive Breast Center.
"What truly defines her is the way she made her patients feel," Levey said. "Across every platform, she earned consistent five-star ratings, praised not only for her surgical skill, but also for listening, explaining and treating each patient as an individual." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a fundraiser for breast cancer treatment and includes education about symptoms and care, making health the primary focus, though it involves an art event.

title: Circle of giving expands impact: Community backs programs focused on recovery, rescue and feeding families
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content:
Circle of giving expands impact: Community backs programs focused on recovery, rescue and feeding families

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com | Section: Life 
 
 700
 Words 

 Read News Document

 As part of its mission to understand community needs and leverage collective resources in support, the Kent Island Giving Circle awarded funding to several organizations across Queen Anne's County.Those recognized during the group's biannual meeting Oct. 6 at the Chesapeake Bay Environmental Center in Grasonville are dedicated to substance abuse recovery, controlling feral cat populations and feeding local families.
Not My Child
After the heart-wrenching loss of her husband's son, Anthony Reno Jr., to fentanyl poisoning at age 21, Not My Child Inc. was founded to fight the heroin and opioid epidemic, said Executive Director Laura Reno.
"Growing from a need to do more with grief, Not My Child seeks to provide access and unwavering support for individuals in recovery and their families," Reno said.
The organization's name comes from a common misconception — that addiction "won't affect my family." Reno said Not My Child works to build inclusive communities where individuals in recovery can thrive without stigma or barriers.
"Addiction is not a choice, and when one person struggles with substance use disorder, the entire family struggles," she said.
With community support, including from the Giving Circle, Not My Child has launched its Project Restart program, which connects individuals in recovery with potential employers, job training and education.
Recognizing that those in recovery often face limited opportunities, Reno said the program aims to "break the cycle and develop meaningful success stories instead."
Beginning in November, Not My Child will offer a series of licensed-therapist and peer-led support groups, including Choose Hope, dedicated to loved ones of individuals struggling with substance use disorder.
Awareness campaigns and events also partner with local organizations such as Celebrate Recovery, Queen Anne's County Goes Purple, the Giving the Edge Foundation, Compass Hospice and the Jacob Sloan Foundation.
"While we can't undo tragedies, by reducing stigma and providing resources, together we can choose how we respond," Reno said.
Saving Future Feral Cats Inc.
When it comes to community cats, Inge Peters' phone is always buzzing.
As founder of Saving Future Feral Cats Inc., Peters is dedicated to reducing overpopulation and easing the suffering of abandoned cats in Queen Anne's County.
To humanely rescue and rehabilitate abandoned cats, the organization operates a trap-neuter-vaccinate-return program to help maintain healthy feral cat populations.
"We believe it is our responsibility as a community to care for the cats that we as humans have abandoned, failed to spay or neuter, or forced to live outdoors," Peters said.
For cats that cannot be adopted, Saving Future Feral Cats places them as barn cats.
The group also partners with other animal welfare organizations for education, fundraising and outreach.
Peters said she has transformed her home into "a rescued cat oasis."
"It is their home now," she said.
The nonprofit relies on a core group of volunteers and is always seeking more — even those who simply want to stop by and socialize with the cats.
"There is nothing more decompressing than petting a cat," Peters said.
Feed A Family
As a community-based food program, Feed A Family demonstrates that even once-a-year actions can make a big impact.
Sponsored by local churches and supported by community donations, Feed A Family provides door-to-door delivery and pickup of Thanksgiving food boxes filled with all the essentials and trimmings for a memorable holiday meal, said representative Bobbie Bell.
A key part of the program is its support for local food pantries, helping relieve their workload during the holiday season.
"Through our collections, food banks can supplement food for other weeks of the year and give their volunteers a much-needed break," Bell said.
While Feed A Family does not yet have official 501©(3) status, it partners with local organizations and serves as a drop-off site for communitywide food efforts to ensure no family goes hungry during the holidays.
"We are blessed with such a bounty," Bell said.
The organization is always seeking volunteers to sort, package and deliver donations. Leading up to Thanksgiving, "Turkey Tags" can be picked up at local churches, businesses and schools to help provide food for families in need.
Currently serving residents from Kent Island to Centreville, Feed A Family hopes to expand north into Sudlersville with additional support, Bell said.
The Kent Island Giving Circle, established in 2022, meets twice a year to support local organizations that serve community needs. The group recently celebrated its 50th member.
More information is available at kentislandgivingcircle.org 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on community programs addressing substance abuse recovery, feeding families, and animal welfare, with the primary emphasis on health-related services such as addiction support and recovery.

title: Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer
author: Staff Writer
content:
Broomsticks look to sweep away breast cancer

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 167
 Words

 Witches and warlocks paddled down the Miles River in costume Wednesday, combining Halloween spirit with breast cancer awareness and early detection education.The inaugural witch paddle at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel raised $28,200 for Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center. As paddlers floated downriver, survivors and medical professionals shared crucial messages about screening.
Chelsey Townsend, diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer at 28 in December 2023, credited her doctor, Audrey Drummey, with saving her life through proactive genetic testing. Now one year cancer-free, Townsend encouraged women to prioritize early screenings and self-examinations.
Dr. Drummey, of the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group, emphasized that routine mammograms should begin at age 40, or earlier for those with family history.
As UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings noted, self-examinations are crucial because "no one knows your body like you do."
Reporter Lily Tierney captured the humor and seriousness of the witch paddle in the story below. It is just one of many stories online and in The Star Democrat today.

title: Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Broomsticks battle breast cancer in first witch paddle

 October 17, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Lily Tierney | Section: Local News 
 
 424
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Witches and warlocks floated down the Miles River on adorned paddle boards and kayaks for broomsticks and dressed in witches hats, wigs and costumes.The first ever witch paddle to support Breastcancer.org and Clark Comprehensive Breast Center took place at the Oaks Waterfront Hotel on Oct. 15 and raised $28,200, just shy of its $30,000 goal.
The event was a nice mix of Halloween fun and education on breast cancer awareness and early screening measures from doctors, volunteers and those who have experienced the disease firsthand.
As the witches paddled down the river at leisure, survivors and doctors spoke to attendees.
Chelsey Townsend, who is now one year cancer free, received the devastating news that she was diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in December 2023 at the age of 28.
Townsend got her diagnoses after genetic testing that revealed a breast cancer gene mutation, which prompted her to get an early mammogram. She credits her doctor, Audrey Drummey, for saving her life.
Drummey is a doctor in obstetrics and gynecology at the University of Maryland Shore Medical Group in Easton. During the event, Drummey highlighted the importance of proactive genetic evaluation and early detection, especially if the disease runs in the family.
She emphasized the importance of access to genetic testing in health care and leveraging available resources.
Drummy said routine mammograms should start at age 40 unless there is a family history of breast cancer in which earlier screening may be recommended and potentially covered by health insurance.
In addition, she said a healthy diet, regular exercise, intaking less than seven alcoholic drinks a week and breastfeeding are good preventative measures.
For Townsend who said she doesn't like to be vulnerable, it was important to reframe her vulnerability as a strength. As she told her story, she was nervous and emotional while recounting her experience as a breast cancer survivor.
She encouraged attendees to check in on their friends post-treatment saying that community is incredibly important because a diagnoses like this can instill fear and change your perspective entirely.
"People think that we go through this experience, and when it's over, that we're OK. And we are OK, we survived, but for your mental health it's still something where every little thing that goes wrong, there's still that fear," Townsend said.
Townsend does not want others to live in fear, which is why she encourages other women — like her two sisters — to do self breast exams and early screenings. UM Shore Regional Community Health outreach specialist Catalina Billings encourages self examinations because "no one knows your body like you do." 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a community event raising funds and awareness for breast cancer, includes medical advice, screening recommendations, and survivor stories, which aligns most closely with the Health topic.

title: Mallard Bay nursing assistant honored
author: Staff Writer
content:
Mallard Bay nursing assistant honored

 October 18, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Business 
 
 254
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mary Camper, a certified nursing assistant at Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab in Cambridge was chosen as the Mid Shore Nursing Assistant Advisory Council's 2025 CNA of the Year. The awards ceremony took place at the Health and Education Center of the University of Maryland Shore Regional Health in Easton on Sept.30.Camper has been a CNA for 46 years. She was nominated by Mallard Bay and described as "the embodiment of what health care should be," whose work ethic, leadership and professionalism "set the standard for those around her."
Camper was chosen from among 17 nominees across the region: Akai Cephas, Emma Dwyer, Katt Gray, Alexia Kelley, Megan McKeever, Jocelyn Rafael, Lisa Swain, Teaira Thompson, UM Shore Medical Center at Easton; Brandy Fanton, Dixon House Assisted Living; Crystal Godley, Lori Perry, UM Shore Medical Center at Chestertown; Da'chell Hains, Candlelight Cove Assisted Living; Debora Copper, Complete Care at Corsica Hills Nursing Home; Jessica Krieger, Home Instead; Mary Camper, Mallard Bay Nursing and Rehab; Monica Roberts, Compass Hospice; and Sa'niya Ennals, Heartfields Assisted Living at Easton.
The selection criteria for determining the winner included work ethic, leadership skills, professionalism, compassion for others, teamwork, dedication to health care, good attendance, friendliness with family and visitors, work flexibility, safety skills and professional image.
The Mid Shore Nursing Assistant Advisory Council supports health care in the community by promoting the nursing assistant profession. The council helps nursing assistants improve their skills by providing resources and networking and hosts the annual "CNA of the Year" to recognize outstanding certified nursing assistants.

title: State overdose official tours Mid Shore programs
author: Staff Writer
content:
State overdose official tours Mid Shore programs

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 258
 Words 

 Read News Document

 Mid Shore Behavioral Health Inc. welcomed Maryland Special Secretary of Overdose Response Emily Keller on Sept. 23 for a regional visit focused on recovery efforts in the Mid-Shore region. The visit was part of a statewide initiative to connect with organizations providing substance use prevention, awareness and treatment programs.Keller began at Foundations Recovery House, meeting with alumni, residents and Executive Director Tabitha Gross. Discussions centered on peer support, trauma-focused care and wraparound services for families. Residents and staff emphasized how Maryland Recovery Net funding and extended stay resources have been critical during early recovery stages.
Keller then toured Chesapeake Voyagers Inc., speaking with peer support specialist James Carter about fostering peer wellness, advocacy and connection for individuals with mental health and substance use challenges. They discussed sustainable funding, workforce support and collaboration to strengthen peer-led recovery services.
At Mid Shore Behavioral Health, Keller participated in a briefing highlighting regional programming addressing substance use and behavioral health needs. Topics included crisis bed availability, harm reduction strategies, problem-solving courts and coordinated recovery initiatives.
Local addiction authorities and health officers from Caroline, Dorchester, Kent, Queen Anne's and Talbot counties shared jurisdiction-specific updates, outlining challenges and successes. Keller engaged with leaders about unique county issues and recognized local teams' dedication.
"Organizations in the mid-shore are demonstrating the tremendous power of collaboration as we work to reduce overdose in Maryland," Keller said. "I applaud our local partners in the mid-shore and across the state for their tireless efforts to support individuals on their recovery journeys and for showing what we can accomplish when we work together."

title: Easton Orthopedic Center temporarily closed due to MRI recall
author: Konner Metz
content:
Easton Orthopedic Center temporarily closed due to MRI recall

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Konner Metz | Section: Local News 
 
 156
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — The Orthopedic Center in Easton is temporarily closed due to an MRI recall, according to a University of Maryland Shore Regional Health official.Spokesperson Trena Williamson indicated the center — which provides X-rays, physical therapy, rehabilitation and surgeries — closed Tuesday after being made aware of a "vendor-issued stop use recall affecting the MRI machine" at the facility.
"Due to the complex nature of MRI technology and out of an abundance of caution, the decision was made to temporarily close the building while the issue is evaluated and addressed," Williamson wrote in a statement Wednesday morning.
Williamson said Shore Regional Health officials are working with the vendor's technicians "to ensure the machine is safely shut down, serviced, and restored as soon as possible." The Orthopedic Center is located at 510 Idlewild Ave.
Safety of patients and staff is "of the utmost importance," Williamson said. Patients are being notified about rescheduling appointments, she added.
This story has been updated.

title: Cardiologist marks 40 years on Eastern Shore
author: Staff Writer
content:
Cardiologist marks 40 years on Eastern Shore

 October 22, 2025 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD)

 Author/Byline: Staff Writer | Section: Life 
 
 286
 Words 

 Read News Document

 EASTON — Jeffrey Howard Etherton has spent four decades providing cardiac care on Maryland's Eastern Shore, and this summer University of Maryland Shore Regional Health and UM Shore Medical Group celebrated the milestone.Etherton, who earned his medical degree from the University of Maryland School of Medicine in Baltimore in 1985, established device-based interventional cardiology, electrophysiology and cardiac research programs at Peninsula Regional Medical Center on the lower Eastern Shore after completing his residency at University of Florida Health Shands Hospital in Gainesville, Florida.
He returned to the University of Maryland as a cardiology fellow three years after graduating and received additional training at the Baltimore Veterans Affairs Medical Center. He also served briefly at Bethesda Naval Medical Center during Desert Storm.
Before joining UM Shore Regional Health, Etherton co-founded Delmarva Heart LLC and the Delmarva Heart Research Foundation. He directed cardiology services at multiple institutions and served as radiation safety officer for nuclear cardiology programs.
Etherton joined UM Shore Medical Group — Cardiology in 2016 and sees patients in Easton and Cambridge. He is board certified in cardiovascular disease.
That year, he launched the Interventional/STEMI Program at UM Shore Medical Center at Easton. During construction of the cardiac catheterization laboratory in 2017, Etherton worked alongside builders to ensure the facility met standards for patient safety and innovation. The cardiac cath team has since treated more than 1,000 STEMI heart attack patients.
A fellow of the American College of Cardiology, Etherton has received the Bausch & Lomb National Science Foundation Award. He is active in the Association of Military Surgeons of the U.S., the Maryland Medical & Chirurgical Society and the Wicomico County Medical Society.
A U.S. Navy Reserve veteran, he was commissioned as a lieutenant in the Medical Corps in 1985. 

 © Copyright © 2025 Star Democrat, Chesapeake Publishing Group (Adams Publishing/APGMedia). All rights reserved.

llm_classification.explanation: The article profiles a cardiologist’s 40‑year career and contributions to cardiac care, which directly relates to medical and health topics.
